summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend have exchanged public jabs after Townsend was subbed on in the 83rd minute of Tottenham’s 0‑0 draw with Burnley, prompting Merson to criticize his England call‑up on Twitter. Townsend later scored a stunning equaliser for England against Italy, leading Merson to admit his mistake and praise the goal, though he still questioned Townsend’s squad inclusion. Townsend responded on Twitter, calling Merson’s criticism “not bad for a player that should be nowhere near the squad.” Despite the back‑and‑forth, tensions eased, but Merson again poked fun at Townsend after Tottenham’s draw at Turf Moor.

Chelsea have formally offered to sign FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, a 22‑year‑old Japan international who has played for the club since 2013 and has 37 appearances, 16 goals, 11 caps and one international goal.  The deal, reportedly worth around £4 million, would see Muto join Chelsea in the summer and then go on loan to Vitesse Arnhem next season; it is unrelated to the club’s £200 million sponsorship with Yokohama Rubber that will begin in 2015‑16.  Muto, who just graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has not yet decided whether to move but says the offer is an honour; he has scored 13 goals in his debut season, earned a spot in the J‑League best XI, and is currently in good form with three goals in four games.  Chelsea are also considering a pre‑season tour of Japan.

Babies who receive antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight or obese by age two, a large Finnish study of over 12,000 healthy children found, with one in five boys and one in ten girls showing excess weight; repeated prescriptions before age two further increased the odds, and boys were also slightly taller than those who had not taken antibiotics. While the study did not prove causation, researchers suggest that antibiotics may kill gut bacteria that normally consume food, freeing more calories for the body and possibly raising appetite. Lead author Dr Antti Saari warned that early antibiotic exposure could contribute to the global childhood obesity epidemic and stressed the need for judicious use, noting that over‑prescription also raises risks of resistance, eczema, digestive problems, and future superbug outbreaks.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, falling and dropping his rifle while his bearskin coat was knocked off; the incident was captured on a tourist’s camera, and the embarrassed soldier quickly scrambled to his feet as colleagues marched past, while a holidaymaker, David Meadwell, recorded the mishap and noted the guard’s embarrassment and the crowd’s gasps. The guard, wearing full regalia and boots with metal protectors, was caught in front of hundreds of tourists watching the daily ceremony, and the Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E, Lifetime and History are collaborating to simulcast a 2016 remake of the 1977 miniseries “Roots,” retelling the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and enslaved in America, with LeVar Burton—who played Kinte in the original—as co‑executive producer. The new version is billed as “original” and “contemporary,” drawing heavily from Alex Haley’s novel and consulting scholars of African and African‑American history for authenticity. Executive voices include History’s Dirk Hoogstra, who emphasizes the saga’s impact on new viewers, and Mark Wolper, son of the original producer, who frames the project as a continuation of Kunta Kinte’s legacy. The remake aims to reach a younger audience amid contemporary milestones such as Barack Obama’s presidency, the Oscar win for “12 Years a Slave,” and ongoing racial tensions. Burton notes that many young Americans are unfamiliar with the original series and its significance.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler that palace aides at Clarence House tried to force him into an orgy in January 1978, when he was 27. Lawler says he was pinned to a chair, groped, and subjected to a series of sexual advances by several male staff members on his first day, after walking into a bedroom to look for a pen. He left the job the same day, and his complaints were ignored for months before he finally contacted palace officials again after a 2023 inquiry into alleged child‑abuse cover‑ups. The complaint was eventually forwarded to Scotland Yard, and a retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement, citing work at Balmoral. The Palace has pledged to cooperate fully with the police probe, while a police spokesman declined to comment further as investigations continue.

Jesse and Melissa Meek of Happy Valley, Oregon, revealed they are expecting a child in a 1.7‑million‑view YouTube rap video set to the “Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air” theme, where they humorously discuss their quick conception, family pressure, and the surprise of a positive test. The clip, filmed in five takes, ends with the couple sharing a sonogram and hints at a follow‑up video after the gender is known. They created the video to inform distant loved ones and were astonished by its viral success. Jesse, a great‑great‑grandson of pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and Melissa had previously posted a video of his reaction to the pregnancy news, while a similar Fresh Prince‑themed announcement was made by a couple in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, last year.

A gray jacket and full‑skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in the 1939 classic *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills; the outfit, featuring a black zigzag applique, has faded from its original slate blue‑gray to light gray. The dress was part of James Tumblin’s extensive private collection of more than 300,000 film artifacts, which he acquired for $20 after spotting it at the Western Costume Company. The auction also drew attention to other high‑priced pieces from the film, including Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s suit jacket and trousers ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). The sale highlighted the enduring legacy of the 75th‑anniversary‑celebrated film based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel.

A two‑year‑old boy fell 10‑12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing; he was rescued by his parents before firefighters arrived, suffered only minor bumps and bruises, and was treated in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach or attack him, and zoo officials say the animals were likely frightened. Witnesses were shocked at the parents’ actions, and the zoo plans to press child‑endangerment charges against the family while closing the exhibit.

A speed camera that had been decommissioned in 2013 for obsolete technology was recently re‑oriented to point at a house on Wellington Road in Birmingham, yet it has not been operational for more than two years; the council is aware of the change, will send an engineer to the site and may remove the camera, and has confirmed that it will not be included in a forthcoming digital‑technology pilot, while the homeowners were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt has confirmed he will run for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. The six‑time Olympic gold medallist said he is fit, healthy and ready to compete, expressing pride in representing Jamaica and hoping to bring “sprint magic” to the event. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed Bolt’s availability and noted the country’s strong relay tradition, while the full Jamaican team list will be released shortly.

Neymar and teammate Dani Alves, along with Neymar’s sister Rafaella, attended Barcelona’s Euro League basketball match against Real Madrid, where Barça edged a 85‑80 win. The same weekend Neymar captained Brazil to a 1‑0 victory over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, while Barcelona’s football side had just won El Clásico, moving four points clear at the top of La Liga under Luis Enrique. Neymar and his teammates are set to return to La Liga on Sunday for a match against Celta Vigo, and the match saw a brief altercation when Gary Medel appeared to stamp on Neymar.

Italy is experiencing a surge of desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with the coast guard rescuing 8,480 people between Friday and Monday and receiving 20 SOS calls on Monday alone; a Save the Children spokesman warned that up to 400 migrants could be missing after a ship carrying 550 people allegedly capsized 80 miles off Libya, though the coast guard has found no evidence of such an incident or any survivors. The Italian Coast Guard has intensified operations, using boats and planes, but has yet to locate bodies or confirm a specific capsized vessel. According to the International Organization for Migration, Italy recorded over 10,000 arrivals in the first quarter of 2015 and rescued about 2,000 at sea during the first weekend of April, with most migrants this year coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria via Libya; at least 480 have died since the start of the year due to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler boats, or abandonment by crews, and a single day last week saw 978 migrants rescued in the Mediterranean.

Arsene Wenger is pleased that Chilean striker Alexis Sanchez has chosen Arsenal over Liverpool, noting the forward’s instant impact with 19 goals this season and praising his adaptability, work‑rate and fighting spirit. Wenger admits he does not know why Sanchez opted for the Emirates Stadium, but suggests Liverpool’s interest may have been tied to their pursuit of Luis Suárez from Barcelona, hinting that the move could have been used as leverage in negotiations. He also downplays speculation about Raheem Sterling’s future, commending Brendan Rodgers for steering Liverpool after Suarez’s departure and Sturridge’s injury, and highlighting the Reds’ 100‑goal season as a testament to their success.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, the four‑time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will try to break the cycling hour record on 7 June at London’s Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark).  The 35‑year‑old, who has just finished his Team Sky career at the Paris‑Roubaix 253.5 km race, aims to cover the greatest distance in 60 minutes, challenging the current record of 52.491 km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February.  Wiggins expects a 6,000‑strong crowd, with tickets on sale from 19 April (£49, £39, £29) and the event to be broadcast live on Sky Sports.  He will also compete in the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire for his eponymous team before preparing for the hour attempt, while other contenders such as Alex Dowsett (Manchester, 2 May) and previous record‑holders Jens Voigt and Matthias Brandle have also made notable attempts.

Serena Williams, the world No 1 and twice French Open champion, won a tough Fed Cup singles match against Italy’s Sara Errani 4‑6 7‑6(3) 6‑3, extending her career record against the Italian to 8‑0, but admitted the clay‑court season had been an eye‑opener and that she was not as prepared as she thought, noting she had been playing like on hard court and will need to adapt. The 33‑year‑old, who recently captured her 19th Grand Slam title at the Australian Open, said her dominance could see her claim all majors this year, though the French Open remains her least successful slam. Despite the singles win, the U.S. lost the doubles rubber 6‑0 6‑3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, dropping the tie 3‑2 and being relegated to World Group II; captain Mary Joe Fernandez urged the team to work harder to regain elite status, and Williams congratulated Italy’s captain Corrado Barazzutti after the defeat.

River Plate are eager to bring back former striker Radamel Falcao, who began his career with the club in 2001, scored 34 goals in 90 appearances, and left in 2009 for Porto; the club’s vice‑president Matías Patanian says they “dream of Falcao” and that the doors are open. Falcao is currently on a season‑long loan at Manchester United, where he has scored only four Premier League goals, and it is unclear whether United will activate the purchase option or he will return to Monaco. Despite his club struggles, he has been in good form for Colombia, netting three goals in two matches to equal the national record of 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the 19‑year‑old X Factor finalist, has become the official face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” dry‑shampoo campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The partnership, arranged by the MILES agency, features campaign images of Henderson in a range of hairstyles against a blurred city backdrop and a TV advertising rollout that includes her single “Mirror Man.” Henderson has expressed excitement about working with a product she regularly uses, while Mark Hargreaves of Crown Talent & Media Group praised the natural synergy between the artist and the popular brand.

A billboard in Kenosha, Wisconsin, featuring Officer Pablo Torres and his dog and thanking the community, has shocked Aaron Siler’s family and friends after Torres shot and killed the 26‑year‑old on March 14 when Siler allegedly armed himself during a pursuit; Torres is on leave while the investigation continues. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, is seen by Siler’s supporters as a disrespectful “thank‑you” for the killing, prompting calls for its removal. The police association says it was meant only to thank the community for its support amid recent incidents, including Torres’s earlier justified shooting of Terry Knight, which was cleared by the district attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed and three militants were killed in clashes near the Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur, with Iranian forces reporting that the attackers crossed from Pakistan; the militants, identified as Jaish al Adal—a Sunni anti‑Iranian group active in Balochistan that targets Shiites and seeks to curb Iranian influence—claimed responsibility, and Iranian officials have asked Pakistan to apprehend the surviving assailants. Jaish al Adal has previously carried out attacks on Iranian territory, including a 2013 incident that killed 14 border guards near Saravan, prompting Iran to criticize Pakistan for failing to control the group. The Pakistani government condemned the attack as terrorism, stated it was investigating the incident, and pledged to arrest any militants who enter its territory.

The passage reports that Japan’s Air Self‑Defense Force has never detected an extraterrestrial UFO, a fact confirmed by Defense Minister Gen Nakatani during a Diet session when he explained that jets are scrambled only when an unidentified object is detected, and that such objects are usually birds or other non‑aircraft. The question prompting the statement came from former wrestler‑turned‑lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who has a varied background as a WWE star, political figure, and entrepreneur, and who himself claims to have seen a UFO but is uncertain about alien existence. Inoki’s inquiry follows earlier discussions, such as a 2007 debate by Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba on the legal implications of defending against an outer‑space invasion under Japan’s pacifist constitution. The article also notes Japan’s recent unveiling of the warship Izumo, its largest since World War II.

A 35‑year‑old passenger, Jin Pai, was injured at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport when a porcelain toilet he was standing on collapsed and shattered, cutting his leg and buttocks. He was found bleeding on the floor, called for help, and was taken to a local hospital where he received dozens of stitches. Authorities deemed the incident accidental; Jin initially claimed he was squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation. Police spokesman Bo Chiang warned that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15‑year‑old girl discovered a hidden camera under the sink in her bathroom, which police traced back to him; prosecutors say he sexually abused the girl over a four‑year period, filming her and other minors while they showered, and that he had purchased the camera specifically to record her undressing. Rebbie faces charges of aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy, and investigators recovered 41 videos, 34 of which show victims showering, some with close‑up images of genitalia. The victim reported that Rebbie had watched her while she was undressing and sleeping and had molested her from age nine to thirteen. The relationship between Rebbie and the victim’s family is unknown; he is being held on a $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new book, roughly titled *Daughter and Salaryman*, showcases a series of father‑daughter portraits in which the fathers, dressed in sharp suits, leap into the air while their teenage daughters stand beside them, smiling directly at the camera; the images aim to let the typically serious fathers display a playful, heroic side, though some older fathers show slightly pained expressions, and the photographs, set against various Japanese landmarks, have already attracted considerable online interest.

Paul Downton’s sacking as England’s managing director has shifted focus to the start of the County Championship, but attention quickly turns to Kevin Pietersen, who appears thoughtful yet jovial in a Surrey team photo at the KIA Oval before the new season. The 34‑year‑old, who was controversially removed from the England side in 2014 and last played internationally during a disastrous Ashes tour, is now back with Surrey in hopes of re‑entering the Test squad as England aim to regain the Ashes this summer. Surrey’s campaign begins at Glamorgan on April 19, with a pre‑season MCC University match against Oxford MCCU, and Pietersen’s photo session includes teammates Chris Tremlett, Stuart Meaker, Jason Roy and Jade Dernbach, as he jokes with photographers and expresses his ambition to return to the England set‑up.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club fighting relegation, fired Brazilian former defender‑turned‑coach Ze Maria twice in one week—first on Wednesday after a poor run, then again after a 2‑0 defeat to FC Botosani that left the team 16th and six points from safety. The 41‑year‑old, who earned 25 caps for Brazil, had been reinstated by owner Angelo Massone before the loss, but the result prompted Massone to appoint Serbian Vanya Radinovic as his replacement.

Nabil Dirar, a former Monaco teammate of Radamel Falcao, says the Colombian striker is likely regretting his season‑long loan to Manchester United, where he has scored only four goals and struggled to reach his pre‑injury form after a serious knee injury. Dirar notes Falcao was unhappy in France and believes he would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League. United would need to pay £46 million to make the move permanent, but given Falcao’s limited output, the club is unlikely to exercise the option.

New Zealand police are seeking help to identify a very tall man who robbed a Union Street dairy in east Christchurch on Saturday, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt. Security footage shows him demanding cash from the owner’s daughter, throwing the cash register to the ground, and taking the till drawer with about $1,500 in cash. No weapons were reported, and the robber remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers at 0800 555 111 or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24‑year‑old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 after a 15‑year‑old student accused her of an inappropriate relationship that included kissing and allowing the boy to touch her breasts in April of the previous year; she was suspended and placed on administrative leave. She was arrested again on Monday for a second 15‑year‑old who alleged that Granado had sex with him on two consecutive nights in January in her car, a claim that came to light after a school police officer investigated a possible relationship. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail and released on a $50,000 bail, with the school district noting that she remains on administrative leave and cannot work with students or be on school property.

A video that has attracted more than half a million views shows a large American crocodile calmly swimming through the marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, holding a dead black dog with a red collar in its jaws; the dog belonged to a local bike shop owner. New Zealander Tim Weston, who was on holiday with his wife when the attack occurred, described the crocodile keeping the dog for hours and later noting that the animal was still present a couple of days later. The clip was posted on the Bogged Facebook page and sparked horror reactions online, while experts note that crocodiles are common in the area’s mangroves and a nearby sanctuary, and that urbanisation has brought them closer to humans.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid relegation after a 2‑0 defeat to Southampton, noting that despite only six wins so far he hopes eight or nine will suffice to survive. He praised his side’s first‑half performance but blamed a Ward‑Prowse penalty and a late Graziano Pelle strike for the loss, and highlighted the six remaining games—including tough fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United—as the key to staying up. Bruce cited long‑term injuries to key players such as Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic and Robert Snodgrass as a major factor in the team’s struggles, while reminding his squad that positivity and effort are essential. Meanwhile, Southampton’s win moved them to fifth, and Ronald Koeman’s side also climbed the table, though Koeman had to address a penalty‑related issue involving Sadio Mane.

Teacher Ian Guffick was banned from teaching after he instructed pupils at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, to alter their SATs exam answers after the session had finished, and he himself changed several scripts before they were sent off. An investigation by the local education authority confirmed that pupils and Guffick had made changes outside exam conditions, leading the Department for Education to annul the entire school’s 2014 SATs results. Guffick admitted the misconduct, was forced to resign, and was later prohibited from the classroom for at least two years by Paul Heathcote on behalf of Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, with a 28‑day window to appeal to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, the Danish goalkeeper who has struggled for playing time at Manchester United, recently celebrated his marriage to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, whom he wed in a beach ceremony in Mauritius and with whom he shares a son; the couple frequently share photos on Instagram, with Lindegaard posting a sunny day out and Beqiri showcasing her modelling work and new haircut to her 17,000 followers. Despite joining the Premier League in 2010 from Aalesunds, Lindegaard has made only 19 league appearances for United over five seasons, remaining third‑choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdés, and has been told he can leave the club, though a move to FC Midtjylland fell through over a price dispute.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once illuminated Yankee Stadium from 1976 to 2008 failed to sell at a Sotheby’s auction, where they were expected to fetch $300,000–$600,000 but only drew a $260,000 bid from a Sotheby’s employee; the letters are owned by former Yankee Reggie Jackson, who bought them after the stadium’s final game in 2008 and hopes a new generation will own them. In the same auction, a late‑1960s New York Mets bullpen car—estimated at $20,000–$30,000—sold for $112,500.

Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe that, as professionals, they must behave appropriately, after Sterling was caught inhaling nitrous oxide and both were photographed smoking shisha. He spoke to them in his office, said they will not be disciplined and wants to put the incident behind them, stressing the importance of their responsibilities for the team’s welfare. Rodgers also noted that Steven Gerrard is available for the FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa after a three‑match suspension, and that his priority is to steer Liverpool into their first FA Cup final of his reign, while he remains undecided on recalling Gerrard for the Sunday match at Wembley.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after the international break, posting a relaxed photo with his dog and reflecting on his home comforts. The Arsenal playmaker, who helped Germany win 2‑0 over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier, is now preparing for the Premier League clash with Liverpool. Signed from Real Madrid for £42.5 million in 2013, Ozil missed Arsenal’s last game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start at the Emirates. Despite rumors of a Berlin nightclub visit, Wenger dismissed them. Since returning from injury, Ozil has tallied four assists and three goals, and he says he’s finally adapting to English football, enjoying the continuous schedule and fitting “perfectly” into the demanding league.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has denied rumours that Luis Enrique will be replaced, saying the club is “very happy” with the manager who signed a two‑year deal last summer and is only six games from the La Liga title. Bartomeu praised Enrique’s preparation after the Champions League win over PSG and highlighted his contract running until 2016, noting that Barcelona still has a chance to win three trophies. In the recent league match, Enrique’s side comfortably beat Valencia, with goals from Luis Suárez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long‑term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay until the summer of 2020 after having 14 months left on his previous deal. The new terms are expected to be around £100,000 a week, making him the third major signing to secure an extension that season after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. The 24‑year‑old England midfielder, who has delivered 13 assists and seven goals this campaign, is poised to potentially take over as club captain when Steven Gerrard departs, while talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume only after the season ends.

Filipe Luis, who joined Chelsea on a three‑year deal from Atlético Madrid last July, says he wants to stay at the club until his contract ends despite the Spanish side’s interest in re‑signing him, noting he has struggled to cement the left‑back position at Stamford Bridge. He has represented Brazil in recent friendlies against France and Chile, and now turns his attention to the Premier League title run‑in, where manager José Mourinho insists the team remain focused and avoid resting on their laurels, a challenge Luis acknowledges but says the squad is prepared to meet.

Nathan Hughes had his three‑match ban overturned on appeal after a disciplinary panel had initially suspended him for a reckless collision that knocked out Welsh winger George North during a match against Northampton on March 27. The red card was rescinded and the panel concluded there was no intent or foul play, allowing Hughes to return immediately, though he was omitted from the next Aviva Premiership squad. North, who had been knocked out for a third time in two months, was stretchered off and advised to rest for at least a month. The appeal was supported by many, including Wasps staff and former England players, who criticised the original sanction as a “total joke.”

A dramatic red sunset over Washington’s skyline, captured by Seattle native Tim Durkan and shared on CNN iReport, was caused by smoke from wildfires that erupted in southeastern Siberia when farmers burned grass in their fields. Strong winds on April 14 spread the flames, destroying dozens of villages before rescue crews contained them, but the lingering smoke was carried across the Pacific by atmospheric winds. The fine particles filter out shorter‑wavelength light (greens, blues, yellows, purples), allowing red and orange hues to dominate the sky, especially at sunrise and sunset; as the smoke eventually dissipates, air quality will improve and the fiery sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her brand‑new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway just over a month after purchase, only to have it recovered by police after a tip from Mick Sexton, who recognized the vehicle and returned it with new red rims, red side detailing and orange accents on the steering wheel. Schoenig posted a photo on Facebook thanking the thieves for “pimping” her car, while noting she will have it professionally cleaned to remove cigarette and marijuana odors. To honor Sexton, she is creating a smoothie called “Sexton on Wheels” at her restaurant The Hot Pot, featuring banana, pineapple, peach and coconut cream, and a friend Marlene Trice praised her vibrant, humorous personality.

Manchester City’s star players, including Sergio Agüero, David Silva, Yaya Touré, Joe Hart and James Milner, face £500,000 bonuses that will be forfeited if the club fails to reach the Champions League group stages, a risk tied to their incentivised contracts designed to keep the club within financial‑fairplay limits; the team sits fourth in the Premier League, four points ahead of Liverpool, and must win a qualifying round to secure Champions League entry, with about £12 million at stake, while manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted the season has collapsed after a poor run of results and early cup exits, and the club is now looking to sign world‑class talent such as Paul Pogba as rivals Manchester United also pursue high‑profile signings.

Manchester United’s Under‑18s edged Altrincham 1‑0 in a “mini‑derby” at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring a curling free‑kick after a 25‑yard drive from Cameron Borthwick‑Jackson hit the crossbar; the match, played for free with about 1,000 spectators, featured 13 of 22 players as English (10 Mancunians) and mirrored the first‑team’s formation, while Marcus Wood and Rashford had chances for City and Javairo Dilrosun added a stoppage‑time free‑kick for the visitors; United’s win keeps them two points behind leaders Middlesbrough, and City’s injury‑plagued side has lost both playoff matches, prompting FA chief Greg Dyke to lament the lack of first‑team opportunities for home‑grown talent.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a “legend of the game” after the Italian earned his 147th cap in a 1‑1 draw with England, while Hart himself celebrated his 50th international appearance, noting he is still learning and is inspired by Buffon’s longevity; he highlighted his pride in reaching 50 caps at his age, his earlier Under‑21 and first‑cap milestones, and expressed a desire to keep playing well for both club and country.

Chipotle has partnered with Postmates to enter the $70 billion food‑delivery market, offering online and mobile delivery in 67 cities with a 9 % service charge and Postmates fees starting at $5, while the chain previously declined other third‑party services; the move follows similar collaborations by Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald’s, and Burger King, and has attracted attention from political figures such as Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, who have been spotted dining at Chipotle locations.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8‑year‑old Martin Richard who was killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, wrote a Boston Globe column urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all 30 charges related to the attacks. They describe the profound grief, injuries, surgeries, and ongoing trauma their family has endured, and argue that keeping the death penalty would prolong painful appeals and keep their children haunted. The Richards request that Tsarnaev be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of release or appeal, emphasizing that they are speaking only for themselves and that ending the pursuit of capital punishment would allow them to move forward. The bombing killed three people, wounded about 200, and Tsarnaev’s brother Tamerlan was killed in a police shootout two years earlier.

A custom‑built Boeing 747‑8 has been transformed into a £400 million luxury home for a billionaire, a project that took three years to complete. The jet, normally capable of carrying 600 passengers, now features a grand dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a lounge and state room, a master bedroom with a large bed and sofa, a conference‑style office, and an aeroloft on the top deck that holds eight full beds for guests. The interior is designed to resemble a high‑end hotel, with porthole‑style windows, a private chef’s kitchen, and spaces for television viewing, allowing the owner to entertain dozens of guests while enjoying the comforts of a private residence in the sky.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station, successfully placing the Dragon in orbit and docking it to deliver more than 4,300 lb (1,950 kg) of supplies—including research equipment and an ISSpresso espresso maker—while the ISS crew spent about five weeks unpacking it before loading over 3,000 lb of experiments, trash, and other items for return; the Dragon will then be guided to splashdown in the Pacific off California. The launch also marked SpaceX’s sixth mission to the ISS and its second attempt of this particular flight, after a weather‑scrubbed launch the day before. In a separate effort, SpaceX attempted to land the first stage of the Falcon 9 on a floating droneship for the first time, but the rocket tipped over after landing; the company had previously failed in January when the rocket exploded on impact, and it plans to continue refining sea‑landing techniques with the ultimate goal of eventually landing rockets on land to reduce launch costs through reuse.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the inaugural wedding held at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside Las Vegas’s Westgate Hotel, a venue that once hosted over 830 Elvis shows. The chapel was launched through a contest co‑hosted with NBC’s Today show, offering one Elvis‑obsessed couple the “ultimate wedding” on Thursday, April 23, 2024, which includes a free reception, a two‑night hotel suite, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who helped design the chapel, stressed that no impersonators are allowed and that the venue is “first‑class.” Couples wishing to be the first to wed there must submit a video or photos with an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice‑captain Jordan Henderson, who played his 47th league match in a 2‑0 win over Newcastle United, equalled the record for appearances in the top five European leagues and said Liverpool can now challenge Manchester City, who sit four points ahead, after regaining form following poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Henderson praised the team’s performance, noting the importance of the win and the need to keep improving. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen added a second from a defensive error, securing the victory; Newcastle had a penalty appeal that was denied. The win was seen as a vital step in Liverpool’s Premier League campaign and a boost in their race for Champions League qualification.

Roma ended a four‑month home winless run by beating Napoli 1‑0 in Serie A, with Miralem Pjanic scoring in the 25th minute after a swift counter‑attack and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis making a series of crucial saves in the second half. The win keeps Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in second place, while Napoli’s winless streak—now five matches—extends and the club remains fifth in the table. Security was tight for the match, with Campania residents barred from tickets and 1,000 police officers deployed, but no incidents were reported. Roma were without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, yet Pjanic’s goal and de Sanctis’s heroics secured the victory.

Doncaster Rovers’ recent season has been uneventful, with the Yorkshire club stuck in mid‑table League One mediocrity. Their latest match, a 0‑0 draw against Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium, offered little excitement, as Fleetwood’s playoff hopes had faded. The game’s lack of action left Doncaster’s media team with a challenge compiling highlights, resulting in a brief 27‑second video that included only 14 seconds of actual match footage—just the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux, who posts videos of his fish on YouTube, regularly massages a blood parrot cichlid by cupping it in his hand and stroking its body, a behavior that the fish seems to enjoy and that keeps it relaxed and still; the fish will swim away briefly but quickly return for more touch, even circling his fingers and following him to the surface when he withdraws his hand. Giroux had to remove two other fish that bullied the cichlid, and he now feeds it frozen blood worms by hand, which has made the fish more sociable and dependent on daily interaction—he spends at least fifteen minutes each day playing with it. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid first bred in Taiwan in 1986, thus demonstrates a notable capacity for tactile bonding with humans.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery temperament, has returned to the England squad after a year of ups and downs, including a wrist injury from punching a locker at Kensington Oval and a clash with Marlon Samuels in the second Test; coach Peter Moores has urged him to channel his aggression, balancing natural exuberance with controlled play to produce runs and wickets. England’s management wants to keep Stokes in the side as much as possible, allowing him to develop while occasionally rein‑in him, and is also considering the role of spinner Adil Rashid, though the team prefers to field both Stokes and Chris Jordan, recognising that the summer will rarely require two spinners and that these exciting players should grow into the international game.

Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifying clash with Belgium on 12 June at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out 33,000 tickets, with both sides sitting on 11 points from five games and Belgium topping Group B on goal difference. The match follows Wales’ 3‑0 win over Israel, highlighted by Gareth Bale’s free‑kick, which has raised hopes that Chris Coleman’s side could secure one of the two automatic spots for the finals in France. The FAW confirmed the sell‑out after a surge of demand, and the team has opted for the smaller Cardiff venue rather than the 74,500‑seat Millennium Stadium, a change barred by UEFA rules within 120 days of the fixture.

England coach John Peacock has announced the squad for the UEFA European Under‑17 Championship in Bulgaria, with the defending champions set to face Italy, Holland and the Republic of Ireland in Group D and opening their campaign on 7 May. The 100 % qualifying record and recent Elite Round victories over Romania, Norway and Slovenia have secured England’s place, and the squad features Premier League talents such as Chelsea’s Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal’s Chris Willock (first call‑up) and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool’s Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold (recalled after missing the qualifiers). The roster includes goalkeepers Paul Woolston and Will Huffer, defenders Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay Dasilva and Tayo Edun, midfielders Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland and Chris Willock, and forwards Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi and Ike Ugbo, with England’s next matches scheduled against Holland on 10 May and Ireland on 13 May.

Manchester City are eager to sign 14‑year‑old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is hailed as one of the club’s brightest prospects and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona; the Belgian starlet turned down a move to La Masia at 12 to keep his studies, but has continued to impress, prompting City to negotiate a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock as manager Manuel Pellegrini looks to build for the future by snapping up the hot property.

A 33‑year‑old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, on March 28, with injuries to her head and neck. Her body was discovered by the London Ambulance Service after she had been living in London, having previously worked in London, Paris and Miami, and she had a website advertising her services. A 23‑year‑old man was arrested in connection with the murder, bailed, and ordered to return for further questioning, while Scotland Yard is appealing to anyone who may have seen or interacted with Santillan in the hours before her death. Police have not confirmed whether her escort work was central to the investigation but have pledged to solve the case.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, revealed on The Jeremy Kyle Show that a family friend and long‑time housemate, convicted burglar Jamie, stole £207 that she had set aside for a £500 gravestone for her unborn child, Daniel James. After confronting Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, Dawn requested a lie‑detector test, which confirmed Jamie’s guilt. The revelation left her devastated, leading her to burst into tears and storm off the stage, while her partner—also named Jamie—comforted her afterward.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis—most women and children, the rest ill or elderly—on Wednesday, a move coordinated with Arab tribal leaders and received by Peshmerga forces who sent the freed people to Irbil; officials reported 217 or 228 released, while the commander Rassol Omar cited 228. This follows earlier releases of Yazidi children and the elderly after ISIS’s 2023 summer takeover of northern Iraq’s towns, which forced hundreds of thousands of minorities, including the 500,000 Yazidis (less than 1 % of Iraq’s population), from their homes. The group’s conquest of Sinjar triggered a humanitarian crisis, with many Yazidis trapped in the mountains or fleeing to Syria, and reports of mass killings, rape, and enslavement of female captives; an international coalition responded with airdrops, rescues, and U.S. and allied airstrikes beginning in August.

Harry Kane’s season has been highlighted by his animated celebrations on and off the pitch, as the Tottenham striker, who has broken into the first team and earned a place in Roy Hodgson’s England squad, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new Copa90 animation titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?” compiles still photographs of his most memorable moments—including a long‑range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal versus Arsenal, his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle, and the goal that came on his England debut—into a dynamic visual tribute released ahead of the awards ceremony where he will compete with Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, publicly backed manager Brendan Rodgers after a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four, arguing that a single game should not dictate Rodgers’ future and that the squad still has the potential to improve and return to Champions League qualification. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, highlighted the challenges of integrating new players and the importance of right signings, while also reflecting on his own upbringing in Bootle and his commitment to helping under‑privileged areas through coaching and philanthropy.

Four‑year‑old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport when security officers, deemed “over‑zealous” by his father Phil, flagged the toy as a security risk after it appeared on the X‑ray. The boy was frisked and forced to surrender the gun, which the family had packed in his hand luggage for a flight to Lanzarote. Phil criticized the checks as “ludicrous,” noting they were late and could not argue, and the family later bought a replacement on eBay after returning from holiday. The airport apologized, offered to mail the toy back, and cited government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited weapons, stating that no such items may be permitted through security.

A 31‑year‑old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife, listing detailed “requirements” such as a non‑drinker, non‑smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good at cooking and in bed, who enjoys the outdoors but can also be a “princess.” He describes himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, 175 cm tall, with brown hair and eyes, who owns property, loves cars, bikes, traveling, sports, fishing, and camping, and offers accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, free gym membership, and other benefits, promising to “blow cash” on his partner and that all reasonable offers will be considered. The Daily Mail Australia attempted to contact him but was unsuccessful.

Greg Dyke, the FA chairman, is pushing a proposal to raise the minimum number of home‑grown players in Premier League squads from eight to twelve and to redefine “home‑grown” as having trained in England for three years before age 18 rather than before 21. The plan has the support of five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven‑Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren—who warn that rejecting the changes will leave England behind other footballing nations and limit the talent pool at the top level, noting that only 36.8 % of Premier League starters were eligible for England selection. They point to a new generation of players such as Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling and Harry Kane as evidence that England can produce talent, but argue that these players are not being given enough opportunities. The proposals face opposition from the Premier League.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, has just given birth to Ross Poldark’s daughter, a development that has sparked excitement among fans who are eager to see the Cornish gentleman settle down, though his heart appears off the market. The show’s recent episodes have been criticized for a rushed pregnancy timeline, jumping from an announcement to an eight‑month status and then to birth within minutes, mirroring a similar quick progression with another character, Elizabeth. Social media reactions highlight both the drama’s appeal and the unrealistic pacing, with tweets joking that pregnancies in Poldark “expect to have it in the next 10 minutes.”

Nigel Pearson has told Leicester City to stay calm and ignore their relegation rivals after a brief revival that saw the Foxes win back‑to‑back games, including Jamie Vardy’s injury‑time winner at West Brom, leaving them three points from safety but still bottom of the Premier League table. Pearson stresses that the team’s future depends on their own performances, warning against shifting focus to other clubs’ fortunes and urging players to concentrate on their own matches to secure a realistic chance of survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia’s Sakhalin Island across the Pacific to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous 10,190‑mile record held by a humpback whale. Oregon State University scientists tracked the journey, noting that Varvara visited three major eastern gray whale breeding sites, including Mexico, suggesting she may be an eastern gray rather than a western one—an insight that could mean the already‑scarce western gray population (estimated at 150 individuals) is even smaller and that genetic distinctions between the two groups warrant re‑examination.

Residents on the east coast of Hokkaido’s Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu were surprised to find a new stretch of land that emerged overnight, with 1,000‑foot‑long seabed rising 30–50 ft above sea level and measuring roughly 1,000–1,640 ft long by 100 ft wide; geologists attribute the sudden appearance to a nearby landslide triggered by melting ice and snow that pivoted the underwater area into the air, a process that produced no audible sounds or tremors, and authorities do not expect further expansion, noting it is distinct from earthquakes and unrelated to the recent Kathmandu quake, while marine life such as seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the new mass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied reports that he will leave Paris Saint‑Germain in the summer, insisting he loves the club, the city and his teammates and that there is no reason to depart. He said he wants to sign a new contract and is ready to play whenever called upon, even after a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc when he was dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea. Despite the club’s interest in Barcelona star Dani Alves, van der Wiel remains committed to PSG and has no plans to leave.

Carlos Tevez has informed Juventus that he wishes to terminate his contract early in order to return to his former club Boca Juniors, with Boca’s president Daniel Angelici confirming the deal is close but contingent on the contract ending in 2016; Tevez, a 31‑year‑old former Manchester City striker who has scored 17 goals this season and is the Serie A top scorer, has expressed a desire to finish his career at Boca, a sentiment echoed by his international manager Tata Martino who says the move would not affect his Argentina prospects, while Juventus, though reluctant to lose a prolific striker, have accepted his wish and begun searching for replacements.

Bayern Munich’s 6‑1 Champions League win over Porto at the Allianz Arena saw the German side dominate from the start, leading 5‑0 at half‑time and securing a semi‑final berth with goals from Thiago Alcântara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso and a brace from Robert Lewandowski, while Porto, who had entered the match with a two‑goal advantage from a 3‑1 win in Portugal, were swept aside. Amid the excitement, manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in the left leg of his grey trousers, exposing his underwear and joking about buying new ones, and he also abandoned his blazer in the later stages of the game.

A multi‑vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway 2 km south of Fernvale involved ten people, including four children. Three cars collided on a Wednesday afternoon, and a 40‑year‑old man and a five‑year‑old boy were the first to be air‑lifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest and shoulder injuries. A 27‑year‑old woman and a six‑year‑old girl were later flown out with arm and abdominal pain, while six others—including an infant and two young girls—were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations and two females escaped injury. The highway was closed with south‑Fernvale diversions; emergency crews freed a trapped driver with hydraulic cutters, and the Rescue 500 helicopter transported patients to hospital. Police said the road would remain closed for a few hours.

Arsenal face Chelsea in a Premier League showdown on Sunday, with Mesut Ozil excitedly showing off a new Apple Watch he bought at an Apple store, posting a comparison to Michael Knight from *Knight Rider* and noting the watch will go on sale the next day; Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 appearances this season, is expected to start as Arsenal trail Chelsea by 10 points with six games left. The Gunners have also welcomed back Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench in the FA Cup semi‑final, and club legend Ray Parlour has praised Wilshere’s potential while warning that his fitness record remains a concern.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee the Manchester derby at Old Trafford, despite a season‑long record of sending off three players from United and City (though only two red cards this season, both to United – Tyler Blackcett and Luke Shaw). He also dismissed City captain Vincent Kompany in a Euro 2016 qualifier, leaving Kompany suspended for the Wales match. Clattenburg, who has faced accusations of bias toward van Gaal’s side, is regarded as one of the Premier League’s top referees alongside Michael Oliver. The derby comes after United’s recent five‑game winning streak and a 3‑0 victory over Tottenham that put them a point ahead of City, who have slipped from title contenders to a fourth‑place chase. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official.

Bob Katter, the federal MP for Kennedy, has drawn criticism after posting on his party’s website that the Queensland Government believes former Labor MP Billy Gordon will resign following domestic‑violence accusations and a revealed criminal past, calling Gordon a “little black puppet on a string.” Katter, who is of Lebanese descent and claims to have faced racism from both major parties, defended the remark as a reflection of his own experiences and a critique of what he sees as the government’s racial overtones. The statement sparked backlash on social media, with users condemning the terminology. Katter also noted that Gordon, who was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party but will remain in parliament as an independent, could avoid becoming a puppet like former independents Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott.

Dayna Dobias, a 19‑year‑old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy and uses energetic dancing videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. She has produced several clips—including one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to show that people with disabilities can lead normal lives, drive, attend college, and enjoy the same activities as everyone else. Dobias also speaks motivationally at local schools and hopes her work will shift how the television, film, and fashion industries represent people with disabilities.

Orlando City, coached by former Everton and Manchester City striker Adrian Heath, has shown interest in Manchester United’s Mexican international Javier Hernandez, who could be a major commercial draw for the Florida‑based club’s large Latin‑American fanbase. Hernandez, who struggled during his loan at Real Madrid, is also being pursued by eight European clubs—including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan—with United reportedly willing to sell him for around £8 million. Meanwhile, United has offered a revised contract to 19‑year‑old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted attention from clubs such as Paris Saint‑Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord after rejecting the initial offer; Pereira was on the bench in United’s recent match against Aston Villa.

At around 12:15 am on Saturday, a group of at least three men attempted to car‑jack a white Dodge Charger at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles, pulling a gun and taking the driver’s gas tank; they then poured gasoline over the vehicle and set it ablaze while two passengers were inside. The driver, who remains unidentified, was not injured, and the car’s front end was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, the suspects are still at large, and surveillance footage is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his state license after admitting to bartering sex for services and performing exorcisms on patients, and he signed an agreement that bars him from applying for reinstatement for at least ten years. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing these charges, noting that Manuel also advised patients to stop taking prescribed medication. Despite the misconduct, he has received a perfect five‑star rating from the three patient surveys available on HealthGrades.com, and his practice’s address listed on Yelp appears to be a residential home in Lamoni.

A Russian SU‑27 intercepted a U.S. RC‑135U reconnaissance aircraft over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew describing the Russian pilot’s close, high‑speed maneuvers as unsafe and unprofessional; Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denied, and the Pentagon announced it would file a diplomatic complaint. The incident echoes a similar close pass a year earlier over the Sea of Okhotsk, and highlights the frequent encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft in northern Europe and the Russian Far East‑Alaska region.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains inside a truck safe, was stolen from the rear right passenger‑side window of his car parked overnight in the parking lot of Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama’s visit to Utah. Police believe the thief broke the window, used a rope or cable to free the case’s handle, and then used another vehicle’s momentum to break the lock, leaving skid marks, rope fragments, and a broken case handle on the pavement. The agent also lost a gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools, some of which were found at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains unrecovered. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, the rifle’s serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Center, and the Secret Service was notified before the presidential trip, though it could not confirm any security changes.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in the dining room of his Canberra home, allegedly stomping on Freebody’s head, cutting his throat and stabbing him multiple times.  A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, examined Costa and testified that his state of mind had been deteriorating, with dementia and alcohol abuse contributing to a confused, fluctuating mood that he believed made Costa unable to understand his actions or their consequences.  Mullen cited evidence such as a trail of faeces from the scene to the toilet and Costa’s triple‑zero calls as proof of his impaired mental state.  Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa had feigned memory loss, a claim Mullen denied, and the jury’s verdict could hinge on whether Costa’s unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley’s decision to take a 10th‑minute penalty against Burnley, a spot‑kick that was saved by Tom Heaton after Barkley chose the spot over veteran Leighton Baines, who boasts a 15‑of‑16 Premier League record. Martinez said Barkley was entitled to request the duty and that he values having several players capable of taking penalties, noting that if Romelu Lukaku had been on the pitch he would have taken it. The miss did not cost Everton, as Kevin Mirallas later scored the only goal of the 1‑0 win, and Martinez praised Barkley’s responsibility in stepping up.

Two passengers were found dead in a stateroom on the Holland America Line ship ms Ryndam while it was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and the cruise line says the deaths appear to be a murder‑suicide. The cabin was secured and the FBI was notified; authorities are investigating. The ship had departed Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14‑day Southern Caribbean cruise. Cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin door.

Former Holland forward and former assistant coach Patrick Kluivert has guided Curacao to a successful start in 2018 World Cup qualifying, taking the Caribbean side into the second CONCACAF round after a 4‑3 aggregate win over Montserrat (a 2‑2 second‑leg draw following a 2‑1 victory in Willemstad). Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, previously worked with Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup and was a 1998 World Cup semi‑finalist as a player and assistant coach. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16, and the first‑round tie saw Charlton Vicento score in the 87th minute to secure the win.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan legend who has won 15 trophies—including a Champions League, five Serie A titles, four Coppa Italia, four Supercoppa, and the 2010 FIFA Club World Cup—now plays for Leicester City, where he sees the club’s fight to stay in the Premier League as “another cup” and a trophy‑level objective. Signed on a one‑year deal after leaving Italy, Cambiasso remains optimistic despite Leicester’s seven‑point deficit at the bottom of the table with only eight games left, noting that he watches teammates daily and believes they can avoid relegation. He has also enjoyed a successful spell at Real Madrid during the Galácticos era and earlier stints at River Plate, and he reports being happy in the East Midlands with his family and eager to secure more points for the Foxes.

Gemma, a 23‑year‑old mother of two children under five, has handed both infants to her 52‑year‑old mother Debbie when they were four months old and is now facing a potential ban from seeing them. Debbie, who has been caring for the children after social services threatened removal, says Gemma’s constant drinking, partying, and use of the legal high MKat make her unfit and uncaring. Debbie also accuses Gemma of stealing an iPad from one child and selling it, a claim confirmed by a lie‑detector test, and notes that Gemma has a history of theft and underage drinking dating back to age 13. With Gemma unemployed and prioritising parties over motherhood, Debbie, who has raised the children alone and appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show, is preparing to cut Gemma off from the house and from any contact with the grandchildren.

After Chelsea’s Eden Hazard opened the scoring with a 1‑0 goal at Stamford Bridge, Sky Sports pundits argued that the build‑up had involved a foul: Chelsea captain John Terry’s strong challenge from behind on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao sent the Colombian to the ground, after which Cesc Fabregas collected the loose ball and passed to Oscar, whose back‑heel set up Hazard’s finish. Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp and Graeme Souness agreed that play should have been stopped for Terry’s rough tackle, with Souness describing it as a “decent forearm smash” and Redknapp noting that the challenge should not have gone unpunished.

A tour bus for Lady Antebellum caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas after a rear tire blew out, but all passengers—including singer Hillary Scott, her husband, the tour manager and the driver—were safely evacuated before the flames engulfed the back lounge, leaving only her Bible intact. The incident was filmed by Michael Barnett and posted to CNN iReport, while Scott posted a photo of the charred bus on Instagram, thanking God for everyone’s safety. The other band members were not on the bus, and Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a space‑laser system that would harvest sunlight on orbiting satellites, convert it into laser light with semiconductors, and beam it back to Earth to boost solar panels and provide emergency power, with initial Scottish trials successful and plans to test in Portugal; he notes the beams would be far less powerful than fictional lasers and raises concerns about control. Meanwhile, Tokyo researchers at Riken propose mounting a laser on the ISS to target and deorbit space debris up to 62 mi away, using pulses to push small pieces into the atmosphere where they burn, a system also too weak to serve as a weapon.

Stephen Munden, a 54‑year‑old convicted paedophile with learning difficulties and autism, vanished from a psychiatric unit after leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, and has been missing since 6.15 pm Tuesday. He was detained under a Mental Health Act hospital order following a 2023 conviction for sexually touching a three‑year‑old girl and for ten unrelated offences involving indecent images of children. Munden, described as 5ft 8in tall, heavy‑built, dark‑haired, may have shaved his beard before fleeing; images of him with and without facial hair have been released. Police have launched a manhunt, urging anyone who has seen him to come forward.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts that former Clippers owner Donald Sterling had given to his former companion, Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling, after she sued him for targeting wealthy older men and receiving a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, a $1.8 million duplex and other items such as a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 blender and a $12 lace thong. Shelly’s lawyer celebrated the ruling as a victory for the Sterling family and a precedent allowing an injured spouse to recover damages from a recipient of ill‑begotten gifts. The case followed Sterling’s downfall after an audio tape surfaced in which he berated Stiviano for posting photos with African‑American figures, including Magic Johnson, and the NBA’s Adam Silver subsequently banned Sterling, fined him $2.5 million and terminated his ownership rights.

Thierry Henry criticised Arsenal’s transfer window, saying the club must sign a goalkeeper, centre‑back, defensive midfielder and a top striker to have a realistic title chance, and he questioned whether Olivier Giroud can lead them to the Premier League crown despite his 14 goals, citing Chelsea’s successful summer signings of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas and Costa as a benchmark; Henry noted Arsenal sit third, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand, and urged Wenger to create a competitive squad capable of winning the league.

A young woman abused by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child, testified in Sydney’s District Court that the abuse has left her terrified of future relationships, depressed, and having attempted suicide; she had kept the abuse secret until Van Ryn was caught, after which she felt compelled to speak out, fearing stigma and the lasting impact on how she relates to men.

Serge Gnabry, a 19‑year‑old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that has kept him out of first‑team action since the March 2014 Champions League match against Bayern Munich. He has played a full 90 minutes for the Arsenal Under‑21 side in a 1‑0 defeat to Reading, and says he is feeling better and better, confident that he has overcome his injury and is ready for the next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23‑year‑old accountant from Reading who worked for Pretty Green and had studied accountancy at the University of Birmingham, fell to his death from a 70‑foot cliff in Penarth, South Wales, after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. The incident occurred after a night out in Cardiff with friends, during which they tried to use an ATM and then fled the cab when they lacked sufficient cash; the taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, chased them but stopped because he could not see where they were going. Phillips leapt over a fence in the dark, became disoriented, and fell to the rocky base of the disused Northern Promenade, where his body was found the next day by a dog walker. Coroner Andrew Barkley ruled the death accidental, noting that Phillips had no knowledge of the danger ahead and that the fall was likely due to disorientation. He had returned to Wales for Christmas, staying with his mother in Cowbridge, and had planned to stay at a friend’s house but could not afford the journey.

Thousands of holidaymakers were left without compensation after a passport‑delays fiasco that saw the HM Passport Office’s backlog swell to over half a million passports, yet the agency still posted a £42 million surplus and awarded managers up to £3,500 in bonuses; ministers refused a blanket refund for those who paid extra for fast‑track services or missed trips, and only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April last year and January this year, totalling £203,066 (average £92.68, largest £5,463, smallest £1), while the Office could not disclose how many were rejected due to a database failure and rejected a Home Affairs Committee demand for universal compensation, citing precedent.

A 1930s semi‑detached house in Horfield, Bristol, remains untouched for over 80 years and is up for auction on April 30 at the County Ground, with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. The property boasts original features such as stained‑glass windows, oil‑fired central heating, a mint‑green and black bathroom with original tiles, wooden floor, yellow wallpaper and green sink, a wood‑panelled hallway, vintage kitchen cupboards, a brick open‑face fire, and a dated kitchen sink. The hallway shelf displays original tins of Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate and Lyle sugar and Colman’s Mustard, while the living room windows feature coats of arms. The house has been upgraded with double glazing, but potential renovation costs may deter developers, though it could appeal to families with a passion for antiques.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith, but became the San Francisco 49ers’ starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He stayed the starter for the remainder of the season and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy‑drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45‑mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that links the New Jersey Turnpike (I‑95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish‑language terrestrial television network that is owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn grew up in Leytonstone, East London and near Colchester, Essex, attending Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and later formed Blur; the band’s debut album *Leisure* came out in 1991 to mixed reviews, but their self‑titled 2001 release achieved worldwide success, drawing on alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop. Albarn’s first solo studio album, *Everyday Robots*, was released on 28 April 2014, co‑produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is Somalia’s capital and its most populous city, serving as the seat for many of the country’s key national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a track by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut EP, *Broken*, which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has earned a BAFTA nomination.

Shooter is a franchise centered on Bob Lee Swagger, a former Force Recon veteran and expert marksman. In the 2007 film, Mark Wahlberg portrays Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit. The TV series, starring Ryan Phillippe, follows Swagger living in exile until he is drawn back into action after discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16 2004 to May 21 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first‑degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people—Abigail Ann Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Earl Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary La Bianca—most notably actress Sharon Tate, all carried out by his followers under his direction; he also received first‑degree murder convictions for the killings of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea, and following his conviction recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began acting on television in 1974 with a brief role in *Little House on the Prairie* directed by his father. He made his film debut in *Taps* (1981) and gained recognition in the 1980s with roles in *Fast Times at Ridgemont High* (1982), *At Close Range* (1986), *State of Grace* (1990), and *Carlito's Way* (1993). Penn rose to prominence with *Dead Man Walking* (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and a Best Actor award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received further Oscar nominations for *Sweet and Lowdown* (1999) and *I Am Sam* (2001), and won Best Actor Oscars for *Mystic River* (2003) and *Milk* (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), known as “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer celebrated as the greatest batsman ever, and after retiring he continued to shape the sport for three decades as an administrator, selector and writer.

L.A. Reid has held top executive roles in the music industry, serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000, 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007); he began his career with Greta in 1990 and co‑founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016 he performs with Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B‑Real and DJ Lord. The passage also notes that Rage is a German heavy‑metal band formed in 1984 by Peter “Peavy” Wagner.

The Millers was a multi‑camera sitcom that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015, producing 34 episodes across two seasons before the network announced its cancellation on November 14, 2014, after only four episodes of the second season had aired.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1 1933 – September 13 2006) was a Texas Democrat who served as state treasurer before becoming the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995; she delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, was noted for her outspoken feminism and sharp one‑liners, and was defeated for re‑election in 1994 by George W. Bush, making her the state’s second female governor. The passage also briefly mentions another Ann Richards (October 1 1935 – April 1 1982), an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released an EP titled *A Reminder* in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, born Jeanette Helen Morrison on July 6, 1927, and who died on October 3, 2004, was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios (1783–1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Panama as sovereign states independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil’s Triangle, is a loosely‑defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are reported to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith, taking over as the San Francisco 49ers’ starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season after Smith’s concussion. He finished that season as the starter and guided the team to its first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they were defeated by the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as starter in 2013, Kaepernick led the 49ers to the NFC Championship Game, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a nonpersonal, openly sponsored audio or visual marketing communication used to promote or sell products, services, or ideas, and it differs from personal selling because the message is not directed at a specific individual. It is delivered through a range of mass media, including traditional outlets such as newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as newer platforms like search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts written by Noël Coward, and it was adapted into a 1931 American Pre‑Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice. He entered Plato’s Academy in Athens at about seventeen or eighteen and remained there until around thirty‑seven (c. 347 BC). After Plato’s death, he left Athens and, at the behest of Philip II of Macedon, began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16 1982, is an American former arms dealer who has also worked as a musician, inventor and entrepreneur. He created the BeatBuddy guitar‑pedal drum machine and now serves as CEO of the music‑technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Los Angeles Lakers for 13 seasons, being selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft. He won a championship and the NBA Finals MVP in his rookie year and captured four additional titles during the 1980s. After a brief retirement prompted by player protests, he returned in 1996 at age 36 for 32 games before retiring for the third time. Recognized by Ebony magazine in 2009 as one of America’s most influential black businessmen, Johnson has diverse business interests and was a part‑owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994 by Jack Black and Kyle Gass, who have released three albums—Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012)—and first gained popularity in 1997 when they starred in their eponymous television series and began supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and, after the 1603 union of the crowns, England and Ireland as James I until his death. Though Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with distinct parliaments, judiciary, and laws, he pursued a single parliament for both realms, succeeding largely in Scotland but encountering major obstacles in England, including the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and repeated clashes with the English Parliament.
