Big Brother 2017, the eighteenth series of the British reality show, is hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster and voice‑over artist born in 1967. Bentley has been the voice of the UK version of Big Brother since its 2000 launch, also handling continuity announcements for Channel 4 until 2011 before moving to Channel 5 for the revived series; his Geordie accent and extensive voice‑over work have made him one of Britain’s most recognised voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked German federal state bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland (Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships), and the Czech Republic (Karlovy Vary, Liberec, and Ústí nad Labem Regions). It is the tenth largest of Germany’s sixteen states, covering 18,413 km², and the sixth most populous with about 4 million residents. Saxony’s history stretches over a millennium and it lies in the heart of the former German‑speaking part of Europe. The state is also noted for quality wine production; together with the Saale‑Unstrut region, it is one of Europe’s northernmost wine regions and one of only two of Germany’s 13 wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball stadium situated in Cincinnati’s East End neighborhood in the United States, and “In the End” is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown launched her solo career by releasing the track “I Want You Back” in collaboration with Missy Elliott, issued through Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in lead roles, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar supporting; it released on 1 July 1994, became the second highest‑grossing Indian film that year, earned nine Filmfare nominations in 1995, and is noted for its chart‑busting songs, while Raveena Tandon replaced the late Divya Bharti who had originally been cast and had shot many scenes before her death.
"Hourglass" refers to both a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure and the title of singer‑songwriter James Taylor’s fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer and actor best known for writing the 1987 action hit *Lethal Weapon* and for making his directorial debut with *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang* in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth film in the James Bond series and the final one to feature Roger Moore in the role of MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua is Indonesia’s largest and easternmost province, covering most of western New Guinea. It was formerly known as Irian Jaya (and earlier as West Irian or Irian Barat) and at one time encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors claimed his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez launched her music career in 1999 with the album *On the 6*, featuring the chart‑topping single “If You Had My Love.” In 2001 she released her second album *J.Lo* and starred in *The Wedding Planner*, becoming the first woman to top both the album and film charts in the same week. After her second divorce, a high‑profile relationship with Ben Affleck inspired her 2002 album *This Is Me… Then*, while the 2003 film *Gigli* flopped. She later married Marc Anthony, achieved box‑office hits such as *Shall We Dance?*, and had twins in 2008. Following a quieter period, she resurfaced in 2011 as an *American Idol* judge and released the massively successful single “On the Floor,” one of the best‑selling tracks ever.

A working animal is a domesticated animal kept and trained by humans to perform tasks such as guiding, pulling, milking, or herding; examples include guide dogs, draft horses, logging elephants, and other assistance animals. These animals are typically close relatives of humans or are trained to provide tractive force or cooperative behavior. Occasionally, wild animals are tamed and trained for novelty or entertainment, but they usually lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament that characterize true domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct‑to‑video comedy directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary‑Kate and Ashley Olsen. Billboard magazine also publishes the Top Latin Albums chart, which is considered the most important chart for Spanish‑language full‑length albums in the U.S. market, and the weekly Regional Mexican Albums chart, a genre‑specific ranking of Mexican music releases.

Vedam, meaning “Chant” in English, is a 2010 Telugu‑language Indian drama written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring a cast that includes Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II, stylized as MIIB, is a 2002 American science‑fiction action comedy film featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.
Sancho Panza is a fictional squire in Miguel de Cervantes’ 1605 novel *Don Quixote*, who offers humorous, proverb‑laden commentary throughout the book, known as sanchismos.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian‑American science‑fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role, directed by Ron Underwood.
Hedda Gabler premiered on 31 January 1891 at Munich’s Residenztheater, with Henrik Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company headquartered in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born on 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., nicknamed Juve, is a professional Italian football club based in Turin, Piedmont, founded in 1897 by young Torinese students including first president Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico. It is the country’s second‑oldest active club after Genoa’s 1893 section, has worn a black‑and‑white striped home kit since 1903, and has played at various venues, most recently the 41,507‑seat Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis appeared in supporting and minor roles during the late 1990s and early 2000s, featuring in films such as *Kate & Leopold* (2001) and *Far from Heaven* (2002), as well as the television series *Law & Order: Special Victims Unit*.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model and former pornographic film actress who has been dubbed the world’s most famous adult entertainment performer and “The Queen of Porn.” She began her career in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a professional basketball team that competes in the National Basketball Association as a member of the league’s Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event that ran from 1983 to 2000, initially shown on closed‑circuit television and later on pay‑per‑view, and was produced by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) before being taken over by World Championship Wrestling (WCW). From the 1960s through the 1980s, Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) traditionally staged major shows on Thanksgiving and Christmas, mainly at Greensboro Coliseum. Notable editions include the 1985 third annual event, the 1987 fifth annual event, and the 1997 fifteenth annual pay‑per‑view.

Jack Ryan Falahee, born February 20, 1989, is an American actor best known for portraying Connor Walsh on the ABC legal drama *How to Get Away with Murder* and Benjamin Stringfellow on the PBS historical drama *Mercy Street*.

Seohyun (Seo Ju‑hyun, born June 28 1991) is a South Korean singer and actress who debuted in August 2007 as a member of the highly successful girl group Girls’ Generation and its subgroup TTS. In addition to group activities, she has acted in stage productions such as *Moon Embracing the Sun*, *Gone with the Wind* and *Mamma Mia*. On January 17 2017 she released her debut solo mini‑album, *Do n’t Say No*, becoming the third member of Girls’ Generation to launch a solo career.

The Apple II is an 8‑bit home computer that was one of the first highly successful mass‑produced microcomputers, introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). It was designed primarily by Steve Wozniak, with Steve Jobs overseeing the foam‑molded plastic case and Rod Holt developing the switching power supply. The Apple II series, trademarked as “Apple ][” and later rendered as “Apple //,” is a family of home computers that pioneered text‑command microcomputer products. Wozniak, born August 11 1950 and nicknamed “Woz,” is an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur who co‑founded Apple Inc.

A&E, formerly known as Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel that serves as the flagship property of A&E Networks, a joint venture equally owned (50 % each) by the Hearst Corporation and Disney’s ABC Television Group, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company.

L.A. Reid has held top executive positions in the music industry, serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group. Veeram (Valour) refers to two distinct Indian films: a 2014 Tamil action movie directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 epic historical drama written and directed by Jayaraj.

Home for the Holidays is the title of two unrelated American films: a 1972 made‑for‑television horror movie directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972; and a 1995 feature film that stars Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.

John Hovig Dolmayan, born July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British‑American record label that functions as a division of Universal Music Group.
Sikkim is a state located in the northeastern region of India.
Christa McAuliffe began her teaching career in 1983 as a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire.
Ronald Bilius “Ron” Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama written and directed by Mike Binder and produced by his brother Jack Binder, distributed by Columbia Pictures and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

Sheryl Lee appeared in Café Society in 2016 and later completed the Showtime revival of Twin Peaks in 2017, reprising her role as Laura Palmer, while Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in the 2016 Broadway production of Wicked.

"Same Old Love" is a track by Selena Gomez from her 2015 second studio album *Revival*. The album debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, and its first three singles—“Good for You,” “Same Old Love,” and “Hands to Myself”—each reached the top of the U.S. Mainstream Top 40 chart.
Weekly Idol is a television program hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal, a rock music genre, emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s mainly in the United Kingdom and the United States, and by the late 1970s the new wave of British heavy metal, featuring bands such as Iron Maiden and Saxon, continued to develop the style.
Ashton Kutcher appeared in several romantic comedies, including *Guess Who* (2005), *A Lot Like Love* (2005), *What Happens in Vegas* (2008), and *No Strings Attached* (2011).

Topman is a high‑street men’s clothing chain that is part of the Arcadia Group, which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans and Dorothy Perkins. At the dawn of the Industrial Revolution, the development of mining and metallurgical industries transformed Wales from an agricultural society into an industrial nation, and the exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield spurred rapid population growth.
Tool is a band that has earned three Grammy Awards, toured globally, and released albums that have topped charts in multiple countries.
YouTube is an American video‑sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California, and it ranks as the second most popular site worldwide according to Alexa Internet.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born 22 November 1968, is a Danish actress who works in theatre, television, and film.

The Armenian Genocide, also called the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of about 1.5 million Armenians—primarily Ottoman citizens—within the Ottoman Empire and later the Republic of Turkey. Similar campaigns targeted other indigenous Christian groups, notably the Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, in the Assyrian and Greek genocides, which some historians view as part of the same overarching genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley, born 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster and voice‑over artist.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19 1946, is an American politician who served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001; his first inauguration took place on January 20 1993 on the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle, born 20 October 1956, is an English director, producer, screenwriter and theatre director best known for films such as *Shallow Grave*, *Trainspotting*, *The Beach*, *28 Days Later*, *Sunshine*, *Slumdog Millionaire*, *127 Hours* and *Steve Jobs*. *The Beach* (2000) is an adventure‑drama directed by Boyle, adapted from Alex Garland’s 1996 novel of the same name with a screenplay by John Hodge.

The 14th Dalai Lama, born Lhamo Thondup (Tenzin Gyatso) on 6 July 1935 in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet (then part of Qinghai province, Republic of China), was identified as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and formally recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama in 1939 near Bumchen. He is the current Dalai Lama and, following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, fled to India where he now lives as a refugee.

Miracle at St. Anna is a World War II film set in German‑occupied Italy, following four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who find refuge in a small Tuscan village and develop a bond with its residents; the narrative is framed as a flashback, with one survivor recalling the events in a 1980s New York setting.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, born November 27, 1957, is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

Many religious traditions practice a mendicant lifestyle, such as Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, Sufi dervishes, and Jain and Buddhist monastic orders. A monk, derived from Greek “monachos” meaning solitary, is someone who follows religious asceticism through monastic living, either alone or with others. The Mod Squad was an American crime drama television series that aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American film that blends science fantasy, western, action, and horror elements, and it is directed and co‑written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona is a southwestern U.S. state that is the sixth largest and 14th most populous, admitted as the 48th state on February 14, 1912. The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is NASA’s highest award, presented by the President on the recommendation of the NASA Administrator. Kentucky is renowned for its horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal mining, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco production, bluegrass music, college basketball, and as the birthplace of Kentucky Fried Chicken.

The Penibaetic System, also known as Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética, is the southernmost of the three mountain‑range systems that make up the Baetic System in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos is an apparel brand that sells a complete range of men’s clothing, including suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear and accessories. Muslims hold that the Quran was revealed by God to the Prophet Muhammad through the angel Gabriel over a span of roughly 23 years, beginning on 22 December 609 CE when Muhammad was 40 years old and concluding in 632 CE, the year of his death.

The human brain, together with the spinal cord, forms the central nervous system. It is divided into the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum, with the cerebrum being the largest part. Beneath the cerebral cortex lie key structures such as the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and subthalamus; limbic structures including the amygdala and hippocampus; the claustrum; various nuclei of the basal ganglia; basal forebrain structures; and the three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy‑drama film set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is an American family‑oriented television network that offers a mix of programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how‑to shows, hunting and fishing, children’s programs, and other features.

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (1908‑2001) was an Australian cricketer famed as “The Don” and widely regarded as the greatest batsman ever; even after retiring and becoming reclusive, his views were highly sought and he remained a national icon, with Prime Minister John Howard declaring him the “greatest living Australian” in 2001.

Margaret Hilda Thatcher (13 October 1925 – 8 April 2013) was a British stateswoman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990, making her the longest‑serving British prime minister of the 20th century and the first woman to hold the office; she became Leader of the Opposition in 1975 after defeating Heath in the Conservative Party leadership election, thereby becoming the first woman to lead a major UK political party.

Randy Mario Poffo (November 15 1952 – May 20 2011), known professionally as “Macho Man” Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator best remembered for his work in the World Wrestling Federation (now WWE) and later in World Championship Wrestling.
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4 1948, is an American singer, songwriter and actor whose career has spanned more than five decades.

EA Black Box, originally known as Black Box Games, was a video game developer located in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada. It was founded in 1998 by former employees of Radical Entertainment and was subsequently acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

Baiae was an ancient mineral‑spring resort on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples, overlooking Mount Vesuvius. Nearby, the Roman town of Herculaneum (Ercolano) was destroyed by Vesuvius’s 79 AD pyroclastic flows and its ruins now lie in the commune of Ercolano, Campania. The area around Naples is rich in historic sites, including the Palace of Caserta and the ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum, and the passage notes that famous ruins exist worldwide—from China, the Indus Valley, and Judea to Zimbabwe, as well as Greek, Egyptian, Roman, Incan, and Mayan sites.

No Country for Old Men is a cat‑and‑mouse drama featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin, set in the 1980 desert of West Texas and following a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran. Tommy Lee Jones is also known for roles such as Texas Ranger Woodrow F. Call in *Lonesome Dove*, Agent K in the *Men in Black* films, Sheriff Ed Tom Bell in *No Country for Old Men*, Two‑Face in *Batman Forever*, William Strannix in *Under Siege*, a Texas Ranger in *Man of the House*, rancher Pete Perkins in *The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada* (which he directed), Colonel Chester Phillips in *Captain America: The First Avenger*, CIA Director Robert Dewey in *Jason Bourne*, and Warden Dwight McClusky in *Natural Born Killers*.

Palo Alto, pronounced [ˌpæloʊ_ˈæltoʊ] or [ˈpalo ˈalto], derives its name from the Spanish words palo (“stick” or colloquially “tree”) and alto (“tall”), meaning “tall tree.” It is a charter city situated in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, within the San Francisco Bay Area of the United States.

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born Albert Lawrence Einstein on July 22, 1947, is an American actor, filmmaker, author and comedian. The film *Finding Dory* was directed by Andrew Stanton with co‑direction by Angus MacLane, and its screenplay was written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code transmits text as on‑off tones, lights, or clicks that a skilled listener can understand without special equipment, and its character lengths are inversely proportional to their frequency in English to increase speed. It is less affected by poor signal conditions than voice and remains comprehensible without a decoder, which is why many amateur radio repeaters use it even for voice traffic. In emergencies, Morse can be sent with improvised, easily keyed methods, making it one of the simplest and most versatile telecommunication techniques.
Alexandra Anna Daddario, born on March 16, 1986, is an American actress.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12 at 21:47 UTC, registering a magnitude of 6.5. The Hindu Kush is an 800‑km mountain range that runs along the Afghan‑Pakistan border from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan, and was historically called the Caucasus Indicus or Paropamisadae in Ancient Greek. It contains many snow‑capped peaks, the tallest being Tirich Mir (7,708 m) in Pakistan’s Chitral District.
Ripon College in Wisconsin had a student population of roughly 840 in 2015, with most students residing on campus.

Fox Sports is a global brand encompassing sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and other media that are either controlled or partially owned by Rupert Murdoch’s family. Murdoch, as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation—the world’s second‑largest media conglomerate—maintained full control over the company and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, following the conglomerate’s split on 28 June 2013. Both 21st Century Fox and News Corp are owned by Murdoch and his family through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is a U.S.-based women’s apparel brand that offers tomboy‑styled clothing.
Bessie Smith (April 15 1894 – September 26 1937) was an American blues singer.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics that develops methods and technologies for converting spoken language into text, drawing on research from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.
Aleister Crowley (born Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875 and died 1 December 1947) was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer.
Poldark is a British‑American drama television series that premiered on BBC One on 8 March 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, released on 20 October 1995, stars Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol and was filmed in India, London and Switzerland from September 1994 to August 1995.

The passage distinguishes two individuals named Tim Roth: Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director; and Tim Roth, born 6 December 1975, is a guitarist, backing vocalist, and the sole remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and the couple had three children.

Sean Penn, who debuted in the 1981 drama *Taps*, has earned two Academy Awards for Best Actor—first for *Mystic River* (2003) and second for *Milk* (2008)—after a career marked by diverse roles in films such as *Fast Times at Ridgemont High* (1982), *At Close Range* (1986), *State of Grace* (1990), and *Carlito's Way* (1993). He gained prominence with *Dead Man Walking* (1995), earning his first Oscar nomination and a Best Actor award at the Berlin Film Festival, and received further nominations for Woody Allen’s *Sweet and Lowdown* (1999) and *I Am Sam* (2001). His 2007 biographical drama *Into the Wild* also received critical acclaim and two Oscar nominations.

Volcanic outgassing formed Earth’s early atmosphere and oceans, but the atmosphere lacked oxygen and was hostile to modern life. As the planet cooled, a solid crust developed and liquid water appeared on the surface. Plate tectonics continues to shape oceans, continents, and the life they support, while human‑dominated biospheric changes now significantly affect the atmosphere, ozone layer, greenhouse gases, soils, air, and water quality. Water covers 71 % of Earth’s surface.
Nuuk, pronounced [nuːk] and also known as Godthaab, is the capital and largest city of Greenland, situated within the municipality of Sermersooq.

The sequel to *How to Train Your Dragon* is written and directed by Dean DeBlois and features the original voice cast—Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz‑Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig—alongside new additions Cate Blanchett (Valka) and Djimon Hounsou (Drago), with Kit Harington also joining the lineup.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy directed by Peyton Reed and written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, featuring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson and David Hyde Pierce; it parodies 1950s–60s sex comedies, especially the Doris Day–Rock Hudson films Pillow Talk (1959), Lover Come Back (1961) and Send Me No Flowers (1964). A television adaptation of the same title aired in Taiwan on China Television (CTV) from 31 January to 23 May 2010 every Sunday 22:00–23:30, and on Gala Television (GTV) Variety Show/CH 28 from 2 February to 30 May 2010 every Sunday 20:00–21:30.
The album “Paris” by Paris Hilton blends various musical styles, incorporating elements of reggae, soul, and pop rock into its production.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy directed by Ivan Reitman that stars Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young and John Candy. The film also served as an early significant role for actors such as John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn and Judge Reinhold, while Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield and Bill Paxton made early appearances.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, as well as Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her track “Love or Lust,” which was featured in Bill Duke’s film *Deep Cover*, and for providing choruses on several classic West Coast rap songs, including Snoop Dogg’s “Gin and Juice” and Dr. Dre’s “Let Me Ride.”

The University of Mississippi has roughly 55 % of its undergraduates and 60 % of its total student body originating from Mississippi, with 23 % of students identified as minorities, and its international student population represents 90 different nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet‑Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy is an actress best known for her roles in television and web series, notably playing Jenny Matrix in the web series *Video Game High School* from 2012 to 2014, co‑starring as Anna Martin in the 2015 Lifetime dark comedy‑drama *Unreal*, and portraying Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller *Quantico*.

Martin Van Buren (December 5 1782 – July 24 1862) was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841, the eighth Vice President from 1833 to 1837, and the tenth Secretary of State from 1829 to 1831, all under President Andrew Jackson. A key organizer of Jackson’s 1828 campaign, Van Buren briefly ran for and served as Governor of New York before resigning to become Secretary of State; after resigning in 1831, he helped Jackson resolve the Petticoat affair and was then given a recess appointment as U.S. minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey, hosts Rutgers University – Camden, which began as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and the Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a Great Lakes and Midwestern state that ranks tenth in population among the 50 U.S. states and 11th in total area, making it the largest state east of the Mississippi River. It is unique as the only state composed of two peninsulas, a feature that contributes to its status as a leading destination for recreational boating. As a constituent political entity, Michigan is one of the 50 states that make up the United States of America.

Penguin Books revolutionised publishing in the 1930s by offering inexpensive paperbacks sold in high‑street stores such as Woolworths for sixpence, thereby making high‑quality fiction and non‑fiction accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film Australia was filmed in several Australian locations, including Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country‑music singer, songwriter, actor and philanthropist who helped make country music a worldwide phenomenon. “Excuse My French” is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. “Excuse My French” is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on his experiences in a public middle school after returning from Saudi Arabia; the film was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board, prompting Salama to adjust the script while preserving its core concept of religious discrimination.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 independent dance film *Make Your Move*, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired South Korean‑American production.

"Bad Romance" is a 2009 single by American singer Lady Gaga from her third EP, *The Fame Monster*. After an illegal demo leak, Gaga debuted the finished track at Alexander McQueen’s Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009 and released its cover art, after which the song topped charts worldwide and sold 12 million copies, making it one of the best‑selling singles ever. The title also refers to a 2011 independent drama film, *Les Mauvais Romans* (Bad Romance).

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, featuring major franchises such as Shrek (and its prequel‑spinoff Puss in Boots), Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, along with other notable titles like Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013), and Home (2015). In addition to its film catalog, the studio produced the Netflix‑exclusive computer‑animated fantasy series Trollhunters, created by Guillermo del Toro and co‑produced with Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank (born 8 August 1966) is a British former professional boxer who fought from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr. (born 18 September 1989), is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super‑middleweight title since February 2017, previously won the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016, and as of May 2017 was ranked the world’s fifth‑best super‑middleweight by BoxRec, seventh‑best middleweight by The Ring, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush, born July 8 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson and activist best known for her roles in the films *John Tucker Must Die* (2006), *The Hitcher* (2007) and *The Narrows* (2008).

Rupert Murdoch serves as chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. His younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch, born 13 December 1972, is an Australian, British and American businessman who is CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc. Murdoch previously held full control as chairman and CEO of News Corporation, the world’s second‑largest media conglomerate, and its successors News Corp and 21st Century Fox following the company’s split on 28 June 2013.
In 2013, Gal Gadot ranked as Israel’s second‑highest earning actress/model, trailing only Bar Refaeli but surpassing Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with the bulk of her income derived from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR), also called Creedence, was an American rock band that performed during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually identified through a radiographic examination, commonly known as an x‑ray.
The South Wales Coalfield, called Maes glo De Cymru in Welsh, is a large coal‑rich area in south Wales, especially within the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental club competition organized by CONCACAF that features the top football clubs from North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was originally established in 1962 under the name CONCACAF Champions Cup.

Mary of Teck became queen mother after King George V died in 1936 when her eldest son Edward ascended the throne, but he abdicated that same year to marry Wallis Simpson; she then supported her second son Albert, who became George VI and reigned until his death in 1952, and Mary herself died in 1953 during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
Poseidon, a film released in 2006, earned approximately $181.7 million worldwide at the box office, on a production budget of $160 million.

The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first presented at the 1996 ceremony, and the record for most wins is held jointly by Omar Epps and Joe Morton, each having won the award three times.

Human trafficking involves the trade of people primarily for forced labour, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimates that forced labour alone generates about $150 billion in annual profits (2014 data), with 14.2 million people (68 %) exploited for labour, 4.5 million (22 %) sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10 %) subjected to state‑imposed forced labour.
Rio is a 2011 film, and its sequel, Rio 2, was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I (1708–1765) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife wielded the real authority, while the earlier Francis I (1494–1547) was the first Valois king of France, nicknamed “Francis of the Large Nose” and “Knight‑King.” He fought Charles V in the Italian War of 1536–1538, and after failing to defeat him, forged a controversial Franco‑Ottoman alliance with Suleiman the Magnificent.

Peking University (PKU), located in Beijing and a member of the C9 League, is China’s first modern national university, founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking to replace the ancient Taixue/Guozijian; it originally served as the country’s highest educational authority and is consistently ranked as the top higher‑learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his distinctive appearance, including friendly mutton chops, his gravelly voice, and his unique bass playing style.
Global warming poses significant human risks, threatening food security by reducing crop yields and forcing the abandonment of populated areas as sea levels rise.
Australia is a 2008 Australian‑American‑British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former NFL quarterback who played 13 seasons, mainly for the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a wide range of cultural expressions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, and superstitions, as well as traditional practices such as food-making and craft-making. It also features oral traditions like tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining, and it also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones, the author, won the 1952 National Book Award for his debut novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was quickly adapted into a film and later a television series. James Jones, the basketball player, averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earned Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All‑State honors, won three NBA championships (two with the Heat and one with the Cavaliers), reached the NBA Finals seven consecutive years with LeBron James in 2017, finished third in NBA three‑point percentage in the 2007‑08 season, and won the Three‑Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, the American Film Institute ranked Humphrey Bogart as the greatest male star of classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the technique for creating animated images, and it is used in the American fantasy television series Trollhunters, which was produced for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and made by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, which became effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in *Doctor Who* from 1974 to 1981, a tenure longer than any other actor in the role, and for narrating the comedy series *Little Britain*. He has also lent his voice to commercials, video games, audiobooks, and various television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site, known for its cleanup project, also hosts the Columbia Generating Station, a commercial nuclear power plant, and research facilities such as the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official appointed by the president to serve as the executive branch’s spokesperson, especially on matters concerning the president, senior executives, and policies. The position does not require Senate confirmation, yet it remains a prominent non‑Cabinet post because of the frequent media briefings that inform the public.

Kentucky, nicknamed the “Bluegrass State” because of the bluegrass that thrives in its fertile pastures, contains a prominent Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky that includes the major cities of Louisville and Lexington. The state is renowned for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film that stars Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston; Preston also appeared in the films The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper who was formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
Despacito was released on May 5 2017 in two distinct versions: an electronic remix produced by the American trio Major Lazer together with Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban remix produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event that ran from 1983 to 2000, first produced by the National Wrestling Alliance and later by World Championship Wrestling. It began as a closed‑circuit television broadcast before becoming the first NWA event to air on pay‑per‑view in 1987, a shift prompted in part by WWF’s exclusive pay‑per‑view strategy for Survivor Series that same year. The 1985 edition aired live on closed‑circuit, and in 2014 the WWE Network re‑released the 1983‑1986 Starrcades, along with later shows, in its pay‑per‑view section, rating them TV‑MA for the violent content of matches such as the “I Quit” bout between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. The 1997 Starrcade marked the fifteenth iteration of the event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first Star Trek series created specifically for the streaming service, and it marks the franchise’s first new series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers and Washington Redskins, and also competed in the World League of American Football with the Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French refers to both a debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, which draws on Salama’s experiences teaching at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia; the passage also notes that Benjamin Paul Ballance‑Drew, born 22 October 1983 and better known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip‑hop recording artist, actor, film director and producer.
A floppy disk, also called a diskette, is a disk storage medium made of a thin, flexible magnetic disk encased in a rectangular plastic shell lined with fabric to keep dust out.

Guatemala suffered chronic instability and civil strife during the mid‑to‑late 19th century, and from 1960 to 1996 endured a bloody civil war between a U.S.-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military carried out genocidal massacres against the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments designed for grasping and holding objects; outside the medical context they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The series “The Closer” launched its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, following a sixth season that had earned it the title of cable’s highest‑rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the protagonist of the ABC drama *Lost*, which aired from September 22 2004 to May 23 2010 over six seasons and 121 episodes, with the first season averaging roughly 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey, born November 4 1969, is an American actor who has focused on dramatic roles since 2011, appearing in films such as *The Lincoln Lawyer*, *Bernie*, *Killer Joe*, *The Paperboy*, *Mud*, *Magic Mike*, *The Wolf of Wall Street*, *Dallas Buyers Club*, *Interstellar*, *The Sea of Trees*, and *Free State of Jones*. The 2012 film *Mud* features McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer best known for his books, notably *Deep Blues*, his music journalism for the New York Times and *Rolling Stone*, his production work on blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film *Deep Blues*, and his clarinet performances with the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912–1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author and engineer best known for completing Mount Rushmore after his father, sculptor Gutzon Borglum, died in 1941; Gutzon had designed and overseen the monument from 1927 until his death, with Lincoln assisting, and upon Gutzon's March 1941 passing, Lincoln assumed leadership of the construction project.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 follows a group of teens—Clarke, Bellamy, Octavia, Jasper, Monty, Raven, Finn, John, and Wells—who are among the first people from the space habitat “The Ark” to return to Earth after a devastating nuclear apocalypse, while also focusing on key adults such as Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke’s mother), council member Marcus Kane, and Thelonious Jaha, the Ark’s Chancellor and Wells’ father.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering humanitarian aid project that, despite later financial difficulties, proved highly successful and influential, raising significant awareness and funds while offering valuable lessons that inspired subsequent initiatives such as Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is a highly influential Indian filmmaker who is credited by the media with revolutionising the Tamil film industry and reshaping the overall profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was presented by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln‑Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. These debates, also called the Great Debates of 1858, were seven public exchanges between Republican Senate candidate Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Douglas, attracting large crowds from neighboring states, especially in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, because the slavery issue was of national significance.

Easy A (stylized as easy A) is a 2010 American teen comedy directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and featuring a cast that includes Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941) is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She launched her career with *Interview with the Vampire* in 1976 while living in California, and wrote sequels to the novel in the 1980s; although early reactions were mixed, she gained greater critical and popular acclaim during that decade. Rice was married to poet and painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

Camden is a city located in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 census population of 77,344, making it the state's 12th most populous municipality. Historically, at the start of the twentieth century its residents were largely European immigrants, and the city is defined as a large, permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller‑drama film *The Canyons*, which was directed by Paul Schrader and received critical derision.

The Lincoln‑Douglas Debates, also called the Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven public discussions between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic candidate, held in seven towns across Illinois.

Homer is the ancient Greek author credited with the Iliad and the Odyssey, the central works of Greek literature, while The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8 1974 – February 2 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered on February 2 2013 by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four‑piece rock band formed in 2001 that combined Soundgarden frontman Chris Cornell with Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals) and drummer Brad Wilk. Wilk, who began his career with Greta in 1990 and co‑founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991, has been the drummer for both Rage (1991–2000, 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007) and, as of 2016, plays in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B‑Real and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine itself was formed in 1991 and originally consisted of rapper/vocalist Zack de la Rocha, bassist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monaé Robinson, born December 1 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who operates her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and is signed to Atlantic Records. In 2010 she released her critically acclaimed debut full‑length studio album, *The ArchAndroid*, a concept sequel to her first EP, which was issued through Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. The University of Mississippi draws a large portion of its student body from the state, with about 55 % of undergraduates and 60 % of the total student population coming from Mississippi; 23 % of students are minorities, and international students represent 90 different nations.
The series “Flaked” was renewed in July 2016 for a six‑episode second season, which is set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served twice in the New York State Assembly (1784–1785 and 1798–1799), was appointed New York State Attorney General from 1789 to 1791, then served as a U.S. Senator from New York between 1791 and 1797, ultimately reaching the apex of his career as Vice President.

Soyuz is a Soviet rocket and spacecraft series developed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s, still in use today. It was created to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with eight unmanned test flights followed by the first 19 manned missions. The Soyuz design succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally intended for the Soviet manned lunar program.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine disbanded after internal tensions caused vocalist Zack de la Rocha to quit, leading him to a low‑key solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007; that same year the original band reunited and performed at Coachella, and their fourth studio album, Renegades, had been released on December 5 2000 by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30, is a free‑float market‑weighted index comprising 30 well‑established, financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors, which is listed on the BSE, is one of the constituents of the SENSEX and is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with an estimated 92.7 million people making it the world’s 14th‑most‑populous country and the ninth in Asia. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000 its economic growth rate has been among the highest globally, and in 2011 it topped the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam remains one of only four one‑party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film that marks John Gatins’ directorial debut, with Gatins also serving as the writer.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who, through two dramatic acts of violence against the British, was executed at the age of 23 on 23 March 1931, and subsequently became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.

Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi‑language biographical sports drama *Dangal*, directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan, which centers on a wrestling competition.

James VI of Scotland (born 19 June 1566) became James I of England and Ireland when the crowns united on 24 March 1603, ruling both sovereign kingdoms—each with its own parliament, judiciary, and laws—until his death on 27 March 1625. Though personally ruling both realms, he strongly advocated a single parliament for England and Scotland, yet encountered numerous difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress who began as an original core cast member of the long‑running soap *Shortland Street*. She is best known for her roles as the Amazon Ephiny in *Xena: Warrior Princess*, Cynthia Ross in *The Cult*, and Shota in *Legend of the Seeker*. Her other credits include the 2009 film *Separation City*, the Australian series *Rake*, and a portrayal of Sydney underworld figure Kate Leigh in *Underbelly: Razor*. In recent years she gained prominence as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama *Wentworth*, a role she played for four years until her departure in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who has starred and co‑starred in films such as *Tommy Boy*, *Black Sheep*, *Joe Dirt*, *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, *Grown Ups*, and *Grown Ups 2*. *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser* is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and written by Spade and Wolf.
Angela Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed critical reviews but achieved commercial success, debuting at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 with 258,000 first‑week sales, becoming Lady Gaga’s second consecutive U.S. chart‑topper, and eventually selling 757,000 copies in the United States; worldwide it sold 2.3 million copies, making it the ninth best‑selling album of 2013.

In 2006 John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, *Stadium Arcadium*, which was also the last album to feature him; he confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, introduced the policies now called Thatcherism, a legacy that remains contentious; she is widely regarded as one of Britain’s most influential and celebrated politicians, despite ongoing debate over her economic and political doctrines.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan, born February 5 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who has also written weekly columns on a wide variety of topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, besides his acting work, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of Spain’s autonomous community of Valencia (the Valencian Community or Valencian Country) and is the country’s third‑largest city, after Madrid and Barcelona, with roughly 800,000 residents in the city proper and a metropolitan population of 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers is a character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film adaptation and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The television series *Make It or Break It* was announced to have concluded on April 26, 2012, with its third season serving as the final season, and the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary sub‑field of computational linguistics that converts spoken language into text, drawing on linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. It powers a range of voice‑driven applications such as voice user interfaces, call routing, home‑automation control, search, data entry, structured document preparation, general speech‑to‑text processing, and aircraft voice input. The field’s progress is reflected in a surge of academic research and widespread industry adoption of deep‑learning techniques, with major companies—including Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC—publicly basing their core speech‑recognition technology on deep learning.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic‑book store owner who co‑founded the San Diego Comic‑Con International, serving as its chairman from its inception in 1970. The convention began as the Golden State Comic Book Convention, created that year by a group of San Diegans—including Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, Mike Towry, and Alf—and was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France’s Dubuisson matched overnight leader Van Zyl of South Africa with a 67 to finish 16 under par, while Rory McIlroy also shot a 67, moving to 15 under and tying Thailand’s Kiradech Aphibarnrat; McIlroy’s round featured an eagle on the 12th, a birdie on the 11th and an eagle on the 13th after a shaky start that saw him three‑putt on the 3rd and 10th, prompting a putter‑throw. He noted that his recent 67s have felt different and hopes for a low round tomorrow. The former world number one, who ruptured a ligament in his left ankle in July and missed several events, returned to defend his US PGA title at Whistling Straits in August, played three FedEx Cup playoff events, and began the new PGA Tour season tied for 26th at the Frys.com Open; he is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years, currently leading England’s Danny Willett by 271, 214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open, while English pair Chris Wood (‑13) and Richard Bland (‑12) were tied for second overnight, positioned fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman told the BBC that a meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires concrete solutions and a spokesperson for the royal family, noting that Crown Prince Salman al‑Khalifa is viewed as a reformist while hardliners around the unelected prime minister oppose concessions that might fuel further demands. He stressed that dialogue is now necessary and that the seven‑point plan agreed with the crown prince before GCC troops intervened on 14 March 2011 was abruptly cut off. The al‑Wefaq leader highlighted young protesters’ loss of faith in mainstream opposition parties, but argued that working with royal reformists is the only viable path, and urged the UK to publicly pressure the government rather than rely on private appeals. He also called for the release of 13 opposition figures jailed on likely torture‑derived evidence, warning that excluding them would doom any dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a months‑long illness, with a private funeral and a later memorial service. A pioneering early‑music conductor, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and led it for about 30 years across six continents, producing over 200 recordings—including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments—and a celebrated 1980 Handel Messiah with Emma Kirkby that BBC Music Magazine ranked among the top 20 recordings of all time. Educated at Cambridge under Rafael Puyana, Mary Potts, Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, he began as a keyboard player and musicologist with Sir Neville Marriner’s Academy of Saint Martin‑in‑the‑Fields and was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London. He served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, taught at Harvard, held an honorary professorship at Cambridge and a professor‑at‑large position at Cornell, and was widely praised by colleagues such as Christopher Purvis, Richard Egarr, Emma Kirkby and David Thomas for his generosity, scholarship and dedication to historically informed performance.

In the year to the end of March 2015‑16, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a five‑victim drop from the previous 12 months and the lowest figure since 1976, with only one case unresolved as of 31 March 2016. The Homicide in Scotland report noted that 51 % (29 cases) involved a sharp instrument, almost all knives, and 31 % of accused were identified as under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson praised the decline but urged continued education, enforcement, community support and investment to deter violence, while Labour’s Claire Baker cautioned that earlier “record‑low” figures had been revised upward, sexual crime remains at a 45‑year high, and violent crime, including attempted murder and serious assault, rose 27 %. The 2014‑15 homicide count was 59, later revised to 62 after reclassification.

Bournemouth lost 2‑1 to Sunderland, becoming the first Premier League team to fall to the Black Cats this season, with Dan Gosling’s goal giving them a brief lead after a three‑game goal drought. Manager Howe blamed a lack of confidence, noting the club had scored six goals against Hull before the two matches and lamented that they had yet to score in a recent sequence of chances. Sunderland’s goals came from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and despite playing with ten men after Steven Pienaar’s dismissal, Bournemouth failed to find an equaliser. Howe said they had had enough chances to win three games, accepted that football sometimes turns out that way, and stressed the importance of moving on.

Mr Abbott told Australian media that the only way to stop people dying at sea is to “stop the boats,” citing Australia’s policy of detaining migrants in offshore processing camps and resettling them elsewhere; the New York Times called the policy brutal, “inhumane” and legally dubious, warning European leaders against adopting similar measures. Abbott dismissed the tragic image of Syrian child Alan Kurdi as “very sad” and insisted Australia has halted illegal boats, while his remarks comparing the Islamic State to the Nazis angered Australian Jewish groups, who condemned the comparison as “injudicious” and stressed the difference between terrorism and state‑run genocide; Abbott later defended his comments but said he was not “ranking evil.”

Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo, warning it would halt talks unless Moscow stops bombing the city; Russia, in turn, condemned the U.S. move and accused Washington of shifting blame for the collapse of last month’s truce. Aleppo has suffered heavy aerial bombardment since the ceasefire ended two weeks ago, with the main trauma hospital in the rebel‑held eastern part struck a third time, hundreds of civilians—including children—killed, and about 250,000 people trapped. U.S. State Department spokesman John Kirby announced the U.S. would suspend its participation in bilateral channels with Russia, citing Russia’s failure to meet commitments and its and the Syrian regime’s military course that targeted critical infrastructure and blocked humanitarian aid, including a 19 September attack on an aid convoy that Moscow denies caused. Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova expressed regret over Washington’s decision, claimed the U.S. had not met key conditions, and noted that the U.S. had been told to return home from a planned Geneva meeting to coordinate air strikes against jihadist groups, though the two sides would continue counter‑terrorism talks to avoid unnecessary clashes.

Downing Street has endorsed a Policy Exchange report that argues selling high‑value vacant social homes would raise about £4.5 bn a year, enough to build 80,000–170,000 new social homes and cut the waiting list by roughly 500,000, while still leaving some expensive units in place; the think tank claims 73 % of people support limiting council houses to below‑average values and that the scheme would be popular across society. Labour, however, says the proposal would drive low‑wage families out of affluent neighbourhoods, worsen the housing crisis, and create segregated communities, and criticises the coalition’s cuts to the £8 bn social‑housing programme. Critics from the National Housing Federation and Labour MP Karen Buck warn that the sell‑off would “cleanse” towns of hardworking residents and push the poorest into ghettos. Housing Minister Grant Shapps, who backs the sell‑off, cites radical reforms, £19.5 bn of public and private funding, and a target of up to 170,000 homes, while suggesting councils could use fixed‑term tenancies to prioritise those in greatest need.

Gareth Colfer‑Williams, 25, died at his Swansea home after a recent bout of measles, a disease that has now reached 942 cases in the city and caused 83 hospitalisations since the outbreak began in November. He had been discharged from Morriston Hospital for asthma, then developed a widespread rash and was seen by an out‑of‑hours GP on 17 April; the next day he was found dead. Public Health Wales confirmed a measles diagnosis but said further tests are needed to determine the exact cause of death, and an inquest will be opened and adjourned on Tuesday for additional investigations. The family, who were unaware of how he contracted the virus, noted that no close relatives, including his vaccinated three‑year‑old daughter, had the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, alleged to have occurred in 2001, and is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin’s Gateshead, unbeaten in nine National League matches, drew 1‑1 with Adam Lockwood’s Guiseley, who are unbeaten in five. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when a throw‑in from James Hurst set up Jake Lawlor’s header into an empty net, and Gateshead levelled in the second half when Wesley York curled a free‑kick from the edge of the box after a slip by Derek Asamoah. The game featured several substitutions and a few yellow cards but ended with both sides maintaining their unbeaten runs.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands to boost capacity, an alternative to a new stadium at Ashton Vale that has stalled over a town‑green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown said the club will start work after a shareholder meeting, following council approval in November. He added the club will sign a section 106 agreement soon, then wait six weeks for a judicial review; if no review occurs by March, redevelopment will begin in May.

Cuadrilla halted its fracking operations after a 1.5‑magnitude tremor—the second in two months—while it reviews data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume. The BGS noted a 1 April quake with a similar location and mechanism, and has been monitoring fracking as a precaution, citing that pressurised water injection can fracture rock and trigger earthquakes. Mark Miller, Cuadrilla’s chief executive, said the pause was to share information and consult authorities, expecting the analysis and consultation to take weeks. The UK Commons energy committee has urged ministers to support fracking, arguing that US‑style environmental concerns can be mitigated by regulation. The latest quake, felt by at least one person in Poulton‑le‑Fylde, was recorded at about 2 km depth and 1.2 miles from the Preese Hall drill site, with waveforms similar to the 2.3‑magnitude event on 1 April.

Angus Carpenter, a 62‑year‑old Liverpool busker who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one fraud charge after playing bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bag in April 2015, but was cleared of two other counts at Liverpool Crown Court. Sgt Chris Gaynor argued that Carpenter appeared to be collecting money for the charity, while Carpenter maintained he had previously piped for the campaign but was simply busking that day; the banner, designed with an eternal flame and the word “justice,” had been authorised by campaign chairman Kenneth Derbyshire, who insisted it was not to raise funds. Carpenter, a familiar face on Anfield match days, said the banner was a tribute to the victims, not a deception, and he is set to be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town secured a 3‑0 victory over Queens Park Rangers at Loftus Road, with goals from Luke Varney, Cole Skuse and Tom Lawrence, the latter finishing a long‑range shot that had been saved by QPR keeper Alex Smithies after a miscleared clearance. Rangers struggled offensively, with only a late header from Sandro off a Tjarron Cherry corner, and the win moved Ipswich up to 14th in the Championship while dropping QPR to 15th. Manager Mick McCarthy praised Varney and the team’s confidence, noting the win was a relief after a poor run, while QPR boss Ian Holloway lamented the second goal and the lack of mental toughness, vowing to improve. The match featured numerous shots saved, free‑kicks and fouls, but ultimately Ipswich’s clinical finishing and QPR’s defensive lapses sealed the result.

23‑year‑old Wells impressed in last season’s T20 Blast, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66, and praised the club’s direction, noting the elite performance environment created by the coaches that is motivating the players.

The Reds, sitting fifth in National Two South, won 29‑12 against third‑placed Chinnor for a second straight victory, with coach Churcher highlighting the leadership of Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams and noting that the front row and front five made over 70 tackles—a key to success. Ahead of their next eight games, they will face seven teams below them in the table and the league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher admits the win was not a complete performance but emotionally strong, and stresses the need to build on it to avoid wasting the effort.

Police allege that 28‑year‑old Nazrul (Nazu), a Bangladeshi citizen, raped a 74‑year‑old nun and was arrested at a Kolkata railway station; the case has sparked nationwide outrage and street protests. It is the sixth arrest in the incident, with police identifying eight suspects, two still untraced, and five earlier accused naming Nazrul as the rapist. Deputy inspector general Dilip Kumar Adak said the arrest followed a tip that Nazu, who fled to Bangladesh after CCTV footage identified him, was returning to Kolkata by train. In May, Milon Sarkar was arrested as the gang leader behind the convent attack, though his exact role remains unclear. The attack on 14 March in Ranaghat saw money stolen from the convent school, the building ransacked, and the nun raped inside the convent.

The interactive video, presented by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explains why consumer purchasing habits change, citing the arrival of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports as key factors that altered what items were sold and popular in the UK. It also examines how ownership and rankings of major UK brands are shifting, with interactive elements illustrating these trends. The video is best viewed in full screen, and non‑interactive versions of the content are available via links to topics such as China’s ownership, freezing food tips, the BBC Good Food annual survey of the top 20 UK consumer brands, and information about the Museum of Brands.

Two separate scams were reported: on 15 September a 71‑year‑old woman from Sandyhills was deceived by a caller posing as a BT employee, and a week later a woman in Stranraer lost money after a caller claiming to be BT technical support remotely accessed her computer to steal cash. PC Siobhan Pellett warned that such fraudsters can easily gain computer access and that the amounts taken are substantial, urging people to be extremely cautious with cold calls, never give banking details over the phone, and reminding that legitimate banks, building societies and reputable businesses never request such information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one‑year contract to coach the third‑placed Championship side Featherstone after leaving the Swinton Lions, where he was replaced by former assistant Stuart Littler.  The Scotland assistant coach will take charge of Featherstone’s final league match against Toulouse ahead of the Super 8 Qualifiers, and chairman Mark Campbell praised him as a “fantastic coach” who performed remarkably under difficult circumstances at Swinton.  Duffy’s 16‑year playing career included stints with Leigh, Widnes and Salford.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and a coastguard search‑and‑rescue helicopter, were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. Crewman Chris Page reported that the rider, lying unconscious on wet sand, suffered head injuries and was very cold. The rider was treated on site before being air‑lifted to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from more than 160 countries agreed to allocate a radio frequency for satellite‑based flight tracking, a move aimed at fixing the gaps in the current ground‑radar system that left 70 % of airspace unmonitored and was exposed by the 2014 disappearance of MH370, which carried 239 people and is believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean. The new system will let satellites receive automatic dependent surveillance‑broadcast (ADS‑B) signals that aircraft already send to each other and to ground stations, enabling real‑time tracking worldwide, as noted by ITU officials. The ITU’s rapid response was praised by Secretary‑General Houlin Zhao, and the International Civil Aviation Organization has set a November 2016 deadline for new guidelines requiring aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who vanished at age five, has been identified as the long‑missing child and is now 18, living with his father Bobby Hernandez in Cleveland. Bobby, 53, was arrested and is being held at Cuyahoga County Jail on a $250,000 bail after the FBI received a tip on October 30 linking the teenager to the disappearance; the FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirmed his identity. The mother has been notified of his recovery. Bobby is also charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver’s licence in 2012, and authorities had suspected him as a possible culprit at the time of Julian’s disappearance, which the missing persons database records as occurring in August 2002 when he allegedly fled after taking his son to pre‑school.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site after a blaze on 2 March that disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and revoked its environmental permit, effective 7 August, while the company must still remove all waste. The firm, run by Asset and Land Group, was described as broadly compliant with fire‑safety law, though it could not be contacted for comment. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the premises nine times in the past year, and in February raised concerns with the EA about potential impacts on residents, transport and the environment; the EA’s enforcement action followed joint site visits. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro‑Kremlin party A Just Russia has tabled two bills tied to the Ukraine crisis: one would let Russia annex territory from a disintegrating neighbour if a referendum or local leaders’ plea is made, citing Crimea’s separatist sentiment and the precedent of Moscow’s control over Abkhazia and South Ossetia; the other would fast‑track Russian passports for Ukrainians, eliminating taxes, residence and financial proof requirements and allowing citizenship in two months instead of a year, with the aim of supporting Russian‑speaking Ukrainians. The proposals were announced in Sevastopol by party leader Sergei Mironov, and several Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea to endorse them.

McLaren, a storied F1 team with 182 wins, 12 drivers’ titles and 8 constructors’ titles, has fallen from its former dominance since a 2013 chassis collapse, though the car has improved and the main issue now lies with the Honda power‑unit. Historically the team’s golden era began in the 1980s with Senna and Prost’s 1988 sweep, continued through the 1990s with Hakkinen and Mercedes, and saw a brief resurgence in 2007 when Alonso and Hamilton were tied for the drivers’ title but were stripped of the constructors’ championship after a Ferrari data scandal and fined $100 m. Further controversies included the 2009 “lie‑gate” involving Hamilton and Dave Ryan. Ron Dennis, who took over after Marlboro’s intervention, steered the team through its early dominance, the Honda and Mercedes partnerships, and returned to leadership after the 2013 slump, insisting that success will return. Alonso re‑joined in 2015 hoping the renewed Honda partnership would restore championship prospects, and Dennis remains optimistic that the current car and future Honda engines will enable McLaren to challenge Mercedes and reclaim titles.

Thomas Baker, 44, was found severely wounded at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool’s Old Swan on 27 January after being shot in the head and chest; he later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men—two 29‑year‑olds and one 32‑year‑old—have been arrested and are in police custody for questioning. Police say Baker had left Phoenix Gym near the market shortly before the shooting while getting into his car, and suspects had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. Detectives are still searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene at speed, traveling along Balmoral, Molyneux and Queens Roads, and are urging people who were captured on CCTV near the market to come forward with any information.

The passage describes how Christian groups are embracing digital media to celebrate Christmas, from Everyday Church Online’s global virtual services and Star‑Wars‑themed sermons to the free fantasy game Guardians of Ancora, which includes Bible‑themed quests about Jesus’ birth. It highlights viral nativity videos such as Viral.de’s “Digital Story of Nativity” and the Churches Advertising Network’s “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle,” noting their reach and challenges like cinema screening bans. It also covers Next Manga’s “Manga Messiah,” a multilingual manga retelling of the nativity aimed at refugees, and comments on the broader use of social media platforms by churches to share gospel messages in short, engaging formats.

The eight‑day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to acquire 250 ha of common land, with backers such as Blaenau Gwent council offering about 320 ha of replacement land. Experts have given conflicting views on whether the new circuit would harm habitats and plant life; Natural Resources Wales says it cannot confirm the replacement land is of equal value but does not oppose the development, while developers’ ecology report claims a net biodiversity gain from nearby habitat enhancement, a point contested by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will issue a recommendation after the inquiry, which Welsh government ministers will then consider before making a final decision.

Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April to condemn a Novaya Gazeta report that they said insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, calling for “retribution” against the alleged instigators and warning of reprisals against journalists; the paper’s 1 April story claimed that over 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of homosexuality, with at least three killed, and that detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun, a claim confirmed by the Russian LGBT Network but denied by Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov, who called the allegations “lies.” The resolution adopted by the clerics, confirmed by Mufti Salah‑haji Mezhiev, warned that Allah would punish those who slandered the Chechen nation and its clerics. Novaya Gazeta’s editor Dmitry Muratov wrote to the mufti that the paper would continue investigating human‑rights abuses and urged dialogue, noting that Chechens have been linked to the murders of former reporters Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova and the 2015 killing of opposition figure Boris Nemtsov, though details remain unclear. The LGBT Network is helping persecuted individuals flee Chechnya and accuses Russian authorities of ignoring abuses, threatening to bring a case to the International Criminal Court if prosecutions fail.
