Investing Solutions, a for‑profit letting agent founded by Samir Patel in 2002, has been receiving housing benefit payments for the past two years by placing single homeless men over 35 in private properties, often charging benefit for each tenant rather than the property itself, which inflates payouts and yields large profits (e.g., £2,114 claimed for two tenants against a £1,150 landlord rent, giving an annual gross profit of £11,568 on one property). The charity Fresh Start Housing, established by Patel in 2010 and based in the same storage‑unit building, sources clients from London homeless charities and refers them to both Investing Solutions and private landlords, claiming it is an independent charity with its own trustees. Despite no illegal activity, critics—including a homeless group and the charity Crisis—label the partnership a “new low,” citing poor housing conditions (e.g., Nigel McCann’s unsanitary accommodations) and the agency’s focus on profit over people. Nearly half of the benefit money paid to Investing Solutions over two years came from Wandsworth Council (£2.1 m), which maintains a private‑sector housing team, while Fresh Start reports having housed 788 homeless people overall and 222 in the last year, though it cannot disclose how many were placed with Investing Solutions. The Department for Communities and Local Government stresses that local authorities must safeguard taxpayers’ money through rigorous inspections and investigations.

Great Britain’s EuroBasket qualifying warm‑up ended in a 71‑60 loss to the Netherlands, after GB had led most of the first three quarters. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13, with Gordon’s three consecutive threes in the third quarter briefly restoring GB’s advantage. The Dutch, powered by an 18‑point surge from Worthy De Jong, took the lead early in the third and then opened the fourth with a 10‑point run to stay ahead, holding on despite a late GB comeback. Coach Joe Prunty praised Gordon’s performance, noted the need for “completing on every play” in the upcoming qualifiers, and highlighted that the game was a final warm‑up before cutting the roster for the six‑game qualifying programme.

Conor McGregor, the former UFC lightweight champion, filed a last‑minute waiver with the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to fight Floyd Mayweather, prompting the NAC to schedule a public debate on August 16 over the use of 8‑oz gloves at 154 lb, a deviation from the standard 10‑oz requirement; Mayweather had announced on Instagram that he would wear 8‑oz Grant gloves, while McGregor, who has used 4‑oz gloves in the UFC, welcomed the post and noted his “brittle hands.” NAC executive Bob Bennett, who had never seen 8‑oz gloves at that weight before, said the decision would rest on health and safety and that the commission would consider the fighters’ agreement, citing a “litany of information” on McGregor—including his past performance against Nate Diaz and input from trainer Virgil Hunter—to justify approval; Bennett also advised hiring Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez, who later oversaw an “out‑of‑control” sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi, after which the former two‑weight world champion left the camp in anger over the images.

Sunday Post reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who have spent decades on Fleet Street, are among the last journalists to work there as the paper’s London office closes. Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism since the 1702 Daily Courant, housed nearly every national and provincial paper within a half‑mile radius and was famed for its bustling newsrooms, printing presses, and pubs. Smith, a 43‑year‑old feature writer, recalls the street’s historic address, the exclusionary El Vino wine bar, and his disbelief at tour guides claiming Fleet Street had lost its journalists, while Sherriff, a 54‑year‑old former chief reporter, describes the smoky, typewriter‑filled newsroom of his early days and the shift to sandwich bars today. After their redundancy, Smith is turning freelance and Sherriff is writing memoirs. Former editors Robin Esser and Liz Hodgkinson reflect on Fleet Street’s dominance—where 85 % of public information flowed before television and social media—and its decline after Rupert Murdoch’s 1986 move to Wapping, the 1988 exodus of national papers, and the repurposing of former newspaper buildings. The closure marks the end of an era, with Smith noting his place in history as the street’s final chapter closes.

J.K. Rowling’s recent tweets reveal her frustration with abusive comments on Twitter, noting that her “personal line” has been crossed and that she feels the need to stand up to bullies, especially after being called a traitor for her political views. She has faced criticism for donating £1 million to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and for a similar donation to the Labour Party in 2008. Rowling has blocked abusive users she believes supported the SNP, while also acknowledging that she has engaged positively with many SNP supporters who share her political views. She joked about bringing marshmallows after a suggestion that her books be burned, and the SNP’s recent victory in Scotland, winning 56 of 59 seats, has made it the third‑largest party in the UK.

The University of Edinburgh’s Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime, tracking 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998, found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crimes as better‑off peers, and that poverty raises the risk of violence for both boys and girls; boys are three times more likely than girls to commit violent acts, while girls from poorer households are twice as likely as affluent girls to be involved in violent crime, even after controlling for truancy, substance abuse and parental supervision. A history of police trouble is the strongest predictor of a youth not being in education, employment or training by age 18, and poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Household poverty also increases offending likelihood, with extreme poverty linked to both victimisation and perpetration. Parallel research by AQMeN shows that the recent decline in Scotland’s crime rates has not reached the most deprived communities, where high crime correlates with chronic health problems and unemployment, underscoring that crime remains concentrated among the poor. The Scottish government claims crime is at a 41‑year low and is investing £296 m to address welfare cuts, while critics question whether inequality is being adequately tackled.

Mr Haugh, 25, was stabbed to death in a laneway of the Marian Estate in Kilkee early Sunday; the attack involved Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, who was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August, while two other men arrested in connection with the killing were released without charge pending further files for the Director of Public Prosecutions. At Ennis District Court, Det. Sgt. Padraig Frawley reported that Walsh and two others entered the estate after 01:00, searched for Haugh, and a fight erupted with weapons—including knives and golf clubs—used; Haugh suffered a stab wound to the back, was taken to Limerick University Hospital where he died at 06:00, and police recovered a blood‑stained knife blade and handle at the scene. The judge noted heightened tension in Kilkee following the incident.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted a false claim that former UDR soldier Tom Elliott had harassed and shot people, prompting a High Court hearing where the tweet was deleted within an hour and an apology was ordered. The court noted Elliott’s clear Ministry of Defence record and that he was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and DUP MLA Arlene Foster. Mr Elliott, now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, said he was vindicated but disappointed the matter took 19 months to resolve. Mr Justice Stevens reserved judgment on compensation, while the Stormont insurance firm declined to cover Flanagan’s costs, a decision the MLA is contesting in a separate action.

Hawick Knitwear, a 19th‑century firm now run by managing director Benny Hartop, employs over 230 staff and has raised its weekly output from about 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters to meet strong demand for both its newly launched Hawick Knitwear‑branded range (introduced in January) and its established private‑label business. Sales have outperformed expectations, prompting the expansion, and the company supplies customers across Europe—Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain—as well as the USA, Canada, Mexico and Japan. Hartop attributes the production boost to a surge in orders from home and abroad, expresses confidence in continued success, and credits the dedicated staff for the firm’s positive outlook.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December when she was struck by Brian Wright’s VW Golf, which failed to stop at a red light. Wright, 55, admitted hitting her but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, citing that he was blinded by the setting sun. He apologized to the court, describing how he had “turned her world upside down,” and the judge paused the case for five minutes to allow him to compose himself. Blackburn, a 20‑year‑old lollipop lady and mother of three, was escorting a woman and her six‑year‑old daughter across the road when the incident occurred; she is now in residential care. Prosecutor Sally Mealing‑McLeod noted that traffic in the opposite direction had stopped, but Wright did not, and the trial continues.

The exercise, dubbed “Dynamic Mongoose,” was staged as a response to the growing threat posed by Russian submarines that have intensified patrols in the North Atlantic, exposing a significant gap in Britain’s own defences. German U‑boat U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf and a crew of 28, was tasked with stealthily attacking the USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker, with detection limited to a brief periscope sighting. Rear Admiral Brad Williamson of the Vicksburg prepared a flotilla of ten warships, including HMS Portland, to hunt the unseen enemy, while anti‑submarine warfare officer Colin Ryan noted the difficulty of locating a submerged submarine. The exercise highlighted Russia’s expanding submarine fleet—around 60 vessels, including a newly launched “quietest” sub—and its advanced stealth capabilities, which can evade detection for months. NATO’s response incorporated helicopters, underwater unmanned drones (Harpo and Groucho) for persistent surveillance, and a French Atlantique maritime patrol aircraft, underscoring the critical role of long‑range patrols that Britain currently lacks. Peter Roberts of RUSI warned that the absence of UK maritime patrol aircraft leaves the nation vulnerable to Russian subs tracking its nuclear deterrent, a weakness that the upcoming defence review must address.

United Nations officials now warn that the violence in South Sudan could amount to genocide or ethnic cleansing, as the conflict that began in Juba in July has spread to the southern Equatoria states, forcing 340,000 people to flee to Uganda—more than any other country this year and exceeding the 200,000 who left Syria in 2016, with an average of 2,500 new refugees daily. Testimonies from refugees such as Nelson Ladu Thomas, who crossed the unofficial Busia border with family and later with a brother’s wife and children, describe killings, rape, and ethnic targeting of Dinka, Nuer, and Equatorians, while Otima Amos recounts a harrowing, days‑long trek with 16 others, mostly children, to escape the violence. Uganda has responded rapidly, allocating land and shelters within 36 hours and supporting agriculture, yet the influx has strained resources, with Bidi Bidi expanding to a 250‑square‑kilometre settlement of nearly a million refugees, half of whom are children; UNHCR’s Nasir Abel Fernandes urges international pressure on South Sudanese leaders to halt the massacres, noting challenges such as water supply and the need for schools, as exemplified by the resilience of refugee children like 16‑year‑old Patricia Mercy who performs poetry about the war’s trauma.

McKenzie, 38, will face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super‑middleweight title. The former Norwich and Peterborough footballer turned professional in 2013 after leaving the sport, and he now holds an 8‑win, 1‑draw record from nine bouts. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three‑time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital project, funded as part of the coalition’s £330 m NHS investment, will replace the 1813‑built, cramped facility with a new 30‑bed hospital featuring a midwifery‑led maternity unit, minor injury unit, X‑ray and mobile scanner space. The £33 m cost will be shared by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, with the aim of completion by autumn 2014 on Bowers Lane land pending planning permission. Matron Sue Taylor and GP Dr Donal Hynes highlighted the need for modern, patient‑friendly facilities, noting that three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have already been replaced in the past five years and that similar upgrades are underway at Musgrove Park Hospital.

A man was fatally shot outside a house on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, near Sheffield’s city centre, while he was in or near a black Mercedes he was driving; he was found with a chest gunshot wound, taken to Northern General Hospital, and died. Residents said he was a family member who was attending a family celebration when the attack occurred, and many neighbours rushed out to help after hearing the shot. The incident follows a string of recent shootings in Sheffield, including a 25‑year‑old seriously injured in Shiregreen, an elderly couple shot through a living‑room window in Southey Green (believed to be mistaken identity), and earlier January incidents in High Green.

Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut and Anonymous International are three independent virtual warrior groups that have taken part in the cyber‑warfare surrounding the Ukraine conflict. Led by Kiev‑based programmer Yevhen Dokukin, the Cyber Troops claim to have hacked Russian interior ministry servers, used DDoS attacks to cripple separatist websites, hijacked CCTV and printers to broadcast pro‑Ukrainian messages, and supplied data to Ukraine’s security services—though officials deny that the information is used to direct artillery fire. Cyber Berkut, an anti‑Western outfit that adopts the name of the riot police used in 2014, has targeted Ukrainian government sites during high‑profile visits (e.g., Biden’s 2021 trip), posted inflammatory messages, claimed to have obtained U.S. military assistance documents, disrupted electronic voting, leaked defence ministry data, and blocked the president’s website. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, publishes leaked Kremlin documents and Russian domestic material, including emails involving former FSB colonel Igor Girkin, and its site is currently blocked in Russia. All three groups routinely hijack CCTV cameras, electronic billboards, network printers, and use DDoS attacks, while making official documents and private communications public and blocking websites.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears by the farewell speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, who both announced they would stand down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond reiterated his long‑held belief that Scotland is “diverse, not divided”, praised the Scotland Bill and the transfer of powers, and reflected on the need for Holyrood to assume greater responsibility, ending with a heartfelt goodbye. McNeil warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny, while Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie humorously noted she would miss dealing with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is launching a review of the quality of life and care for older people in residential care, calling on pensioners, their families and friends to share their experiences. The evidence gathered will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies, with Rochira emphasising both the benefits of high‑quality care and the harms of poor care, and noting increasing complaints about variations across Wales. Her team will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment, and will consult care providers, social care staff and public bodies to give older people a voice in shaping change. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft welcomed the review’s aims but criticised the absence of a provider expert on the advisory panel, arguing that this omission misses an opportunity for partnership and sector engagement.

Harbro Group of Turriff, Aberdeenshire, reported a pre‑tax profit rise of £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, even though turnover fell by £1 million to just over £100 million; international sales in Europe and new markets grew. The company produces and supplies livestock feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland that sell rural‑community goods such as fireside supplies, country clothing and footwear. In its Companies House filing, Harbro noted that the agricultural outlook remains uncertain, the past 12–18 months have been challenging, but the industry is robust and the board believes the group will be well positioned to handle the still‑unsettled impacts of Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, while a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and are seeking to question 55‑year‑old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), warning the public not to approach him. Detective Chief Inspector Martin Brunning said the investigation is in its early stages and urged anyone with information to contact police or Crimestoppers, while officers increased patrols to reassure residents.

David Lipton, the IMF’s second‑in‑command, warned in Washington that the IMF’s latest assessment shows a weakening global economic baseline and a delicate juncture, following weaker‑than‑expected Chinese trade data that saw exports drop a quarter from a year earlier. He said the IMF will likely downgrade its current 3.4 % global growth forecast when it releases new predictions in April, a bleak outlook that will impact businesses and industries that have bet on China’s growth story.

At a council scrutiny meeting, leader Dave Stewart announced that crossings at Cowes would be free until 2 July to acknowledge the problems with the new chain ferry and to gather feedback, and he said the council had ordered an auditor review after a “frustrating and disappointing start.”  Since its launch on 14 May the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and caused car damage during loading and unloading.  Local shopkeeper Angie Booth warned that businesses are suffering almost six months of lost trade and asked whether they would be compensated like the damaged cars.  Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation was up for discussion, noted the ferry is a prototype with teething problems (electrical faults now fixed), and that the council had authorised ramp extensions to prevent vehicles scraping concrete, while seamanship‑related groundings had been resolved.

A multi‑vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday killed a 32‑year‑old man at the scene. Police arrested a 33‑year‑old Waterlooville resident on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while the investigation proceeded.

Matching Models in London, an international temp agency that markets itself as a provider of “beautiful and talented people,” has faced backlash for job ads that specify physical traits, such as a personal assistant with a “classic look, brown long hair and B‑C cup” and a “sexy female driver” for a Porsche Cayenne, offering £40,000‑£50,000 a year. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned the ads as “appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women,” with chief executive Rebecca Hilsenrath threatening to demand clarification of the agency’s hiring practices, while Fawcett Society CEO Sam Smethers warned the approach likely breaches equality legislation. Agency founder Nathalie Jansen defended the focus on appearance, citing client requests for specific looks (e.g., a Dior‑styled “Jackie O” outfit or a blonde, blue‑eyed Greek woman for an Indian businessman) and noting that the firm has placed 5,000 people worldwide for clients such as MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca‑Cola, Renault Formula 1 and Harrods. Employment lawyer James Lynas described the ads as clearly unlawful, arguing that terms like “beautiful and attractive” effectively discriminate against older women and could expose the agency to unlimited compensation claims under the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of age, sex, disability, race, religion, and other protected characteristics.

A shooting at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore left 18‑year‑old Gautami dead after gunman Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, barged into her room and fired a pistol. He also shot fellow student Sirisha, who sustained severe injuries but is believed to be out of danger. Mahesh was arrested following a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. Gun crime in Indian schools is rare; the motive remains unclear. The incident is noted alongside India’s strict firearms laws and a 2007 case where a 14‑year‑old schoolboy was killed by classmates.

Glaad’s “Where We Are on TV” study examined shows airing from June 2016 to May 2017, finding 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender representation rising from seven to 16. However, the report highlighted that more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, citing Poussey Washington and Bea Smith as examples. It also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to series such as *Empire*, *Luke Cage*, and *How to Get Away with Murder*. The study focused on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already airing or confirmed for casting, and Glaad president Sarah Kate Ellis praised the progress while noting that numbers only tell part of the story.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would step down after a police investigation uncovered that about £10.25 million of a public loan he arranged as former council leader for Northampton Town FC’s Sixfields stadium rebuild had vanished; the loan is now under scrutiny for alleged financial irregularities, and the stand remains half‑built. Despite previously saying he would seek re‑election, a majority of his local party executive voted to deselect him, prompting Mackintosh to declare it the right time for a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37‑year‑old police officer, fired a rifle into a car leaving a house party in Balch Springs, Dallas, in April, killing 15‑year‑old Jordan Edwards; Oliver was fired a few days later for policy violations and is currently free on bail, facing a murder charge that could bring 5 to 99 years in prison and would make him the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. The incident occurred while officers responded to reports of underage drinking, heard what they thought were gunshots, and Oliver fired into a vehicle full of teenagers as it drove away—footage later disproving an earlier claim that the car had reversed aggressively. Oliver is also charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official against the other four teenagers in the car, including two of Edwards’ brothers. The Dallas County District Attorney, Faith Johnson, stated that justice is proceeding effectively, while Edwards’ lawyer, Lee Merritt, noted the rarity of a cop conviction in Texas, emphasizing caution.

President‑elect Trump has said Mrs. Trump and son Barron will relocate to Washington shortly after school ends, a move that has sparked social‑media debate over the First Lady’s residency and the impact on the child’s schooling, though some praise it as responsible parenting. Historically, only Martha Washington and Anna Harrison have not lived in the White House during their husbands’ presidencies, and past First Ladies have varied in their residence and public engagement—from Frances Folsom Cleveland’s seasonal stay to the Obama daughters’ early move to avoid mid‑term school changes. The First Lady’s role is largely ceremonial yet increasingly public, with figures such as Lou Henry Hoover, Eleanor Roosevelt, Nancy Reagan, and Melania Trump (who plans to focus on cyber‑bullying) shaping the position. When a president’s wife is absent, daughters or other relatives have stepped in, as with Martha Jefferson Randolph, Angelica van Buren, and Chelsea Clinton, illustrating that the White House can adapt to family needs while maintaining its symbolic duties.

The man died in Inverness on 27 October. Police Scotland said it was fully engaging with the investigation and awaiting findings. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service to investigate the initial police response to a call from the 72‑year‑old man, who was later found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness, and will submit a report to the COPFS.

A yellow wind warning was issued, warning of gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h) especially to the west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction expected to increase the impact. Travel on roads and at sea was likely to be disrupted, affecting Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight gusts knocked down a tree in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing a main route, and the council said Telford Road would remain closed most of Monday for clean‑up work.

The Giants began the game with a short‑handed goal from player‑coach Derrick Walser, but the Panthers answered with a goal from Jeff Dimmen to level the score. In the second period, Mike Forney netted a power‑play breakaway to put the Giants ahead 2‑1, only for Andy Bohmback to equalise. The Giants then extended their lead with goals from Mike Radja, from an acute angle, and James Desmarais, making it 4‑2, before Nottingham’s David Ling scored to bring the score closer. The two teams will face each other again Saturday night in the second match of their double‑header, with Nottingham topping the league at 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers at 27 and Belfast at 25.

World champion Lewis Hamilton began the Chinese Grand Prix from the back after a broken front wing on lap one, requiring five pit stops and leaving him 36 points behind the leaders with 18 races remaining. Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first‑lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who fought back to fifth behind Red Bull drivers Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo. Raikkonen’s late‑race tyre strategy (softs versus Mercedes’ mediums) helped him overtake Hamilton, while Hamilton’s damaged car lost significant aerodynamic performance, limiting his ability to close the gap to teammate Nico Rosberg, who took the lead after a punctured Ricciardo and a safety‑car restart. The race was marred by multiple first‑lap incidents, including a safety car on lap four, and heated post‑race exchanges between Vettel and Kvyat over the collision. Despite Hamilton’s confidence that he could erode Rosberg’s points lead, the combination of early damage, tyre choices, and the need for numerous stops left him struggling to keep pace with the Ferraris and to prevent Rosberg from securing the championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, becoming the first prominent German footballer to do so and sparking widespread support from teammates, clubs, and football officials such as Lukas Podolski, Arne Friedrich, Theo Zwanziger, Reinhard Rauball, and Bayern Munich, as well as international figures like Gary Lineker and John Amaechi; the announcement is seen as a watershed moment in a sport that has struggled with homophobia, following past controversies such as Philipp Lahm’s 2011 remarks discouraging gay players from coming out and the earlier coming out of second‑tier player Marcus Urban, and has been praised by political leaders including Angela Merkel’s spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck, who hope it will encourage greater openness and reduce intolerance in German football.

Sidwell, 34, has played 32 Championship matches this season, helping Brighton & Hove Albion secure promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years, and he is now seeking a new contract as his current deal expires. He expressed confidence that the club can remain in the top flight and wants to stay for the next season. Brighton’s recent win over Wigan confirmed their promotion, and with a four‑point lead over Newcastle they aim to clinch the league title in the final two games. Sidwell previously joined Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015‑16, signed a one‑year deal in June 2016, and has Premier League experience with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke; he believes he has exceeded expectations and deserves another chance at the highest level, hoping a new deal can be negotiated before summer.

Blackpool and Colchester United settled on a 1‑1 draw at Bloomfield Road, with Blackpool taking the lead in the 12th minute when Nathan Delfouneso’s chip set up Jamille Matt’s close‑range finish, and Colchester equalised just before half‑time when Kurtis Guthrie headed in from a corner after a scramble in the box; Blackpool’s goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made several key saves, including one to deny Matthew Briggs and another to stop George Elokobi, while Colchester’s George Elokobi also had a close‑range effort saved; a late chance for Blackpool saw Tom Aldred miss a header from a corner, and the match ended with Colchester reduced to 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister; substitutions included Eddie Nolan for Jim McAlister, Denny Johnstone for Kurtis Guthrie, and Kane Vincent‑Young for Richard Brindley, and the game was reported by the Press Association.

The 29‑year‑old made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season, which ended with their relegation from League One. Reid, who has previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston, may debut for the U’s in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first‑round match against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester began the season with a 3‑1 defeat at Accrington, and readers are directed to a dedicated page for the latest football transfers.

PC Keith Palmer’s murder outside Parliament spurred the UK Police Memorial Trust to seek £1.5 million for a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, which will list the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. Sir Hugh Orde emphasised the need for a national tribute that honours police service and offers families a place for personal remembrance, while Home Secretary Amber Rudd pledged £1 million of the £4 million required, and the memorial—featuring a brass screen with leaf‑shaped cut‑outs for families—was slated for completion by 2019.

Manchester United stay 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League after a 1‑0 win at Sunderland, with eight games left. Ferguson praised the club’s 25 wins from 30 matches and highlighted the 50‑point haul in the last 18 games, noting the upcoming derby against Manchester City will be played with a 15‑point advantage. He said the focus is simply to win the next match and that United aim to surpass Chelsea’s 95‑point 2005 record. Ferguson will adjust the squad for the FA Cup quarter‑final replay at Chelsea after injuries to Rafael, Anderson and a knock to De Gea, and will not start returning England players Rooney, Welbeck and Cleverley, instead planning to field Giggs, Hernandez and others such as Ferdinand. The team credited its win to solid defending and courage, despite a strong first‑half performance from Sunderland.

Mr Schmidt told the BBC that Google had only done what UK law required, noting the company paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011 and would simply comply if the government changed the tax rules; he stressed that taxes are not optional and that any increase or decrease would be a political decision. Meanwhile Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, has called for a new committee to scrutinise the tax arrangements of major firms, potentially hearing evidence in secret to prevent confidentiality shields. Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland and has been criticised for minimising its UK tax bill, is part of a broader debate that has seen EU leaders agree to an automatic information‑exchange system to curb tax avoidance. The Google chairman has argued that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity and risk occur rather than where products are consumed, and has urged a constructive debate on international tax reform to create a clearer, simpler system in which companies that follow the law are supported by the politicians who set the rules.

NHS Improvement is pushing the NHS to cut its £3.6 bn agency staff bill, targeting a £1 bn reduction by the end of the financial year after a cap introduced in October has already saved £600 m; the cap limits hospitals, mental‑health trusts and ambulance services to paying no more than 55 % above normal shift rates for all staff except senior managers, aiming to lower costs and dependence on agencies. While progress is “promising,” trusts are still 10 % short of targets and it is unclear whether other pay components have risen; the regulator’s figures exclude NHS “bank” staff and overtime. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of agency spending and track the top 20 highest‑earning agency staff per trust, amid concerns that some are earning far above capped rates—examples include surgeons quoted £130 hr versus a £76 cap and junior doctors quoted £70 hr versus a £35 cap. Chief executive Jim Mackey warned that the NHS simply cannot afford such expensive agency spending and that more action is required.

Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger, now reflects the economic downturn, yet local traders such as Matt O’Brien—who runs a family men’s clothing shop that has rebounded by adding childrenswear and dress‑hire services—see a slow recovery. Fianna Fáil criticises the Fine Gael‑Labour coalition for mismanaging the midlands, arguing that a €500 million water‑meter investment should instead fund broadband, while TD Robert Troy blames the IDA for failing to attract foreign investment. The government counters with the planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, projected to employ about 1,000 people and costing €200 million, though it still requires planning permission; Fine Gael TD James Bannon remains optimistic about the project’s potential to draw visitors to the region’s scenic waterways and infrastructure. Despite the Centre Parcs announcement not threatening the government’s election prospects, traders like O’Brien contend that further measures—such as free street parking—are needed to fully revive local business, signalling that the midlands are beginning to recover but still require additional support.

The competition, which concludes on 29 May at the same stadium, features eight teams that play each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play‑offs; BBC Sport provides live scores, fixtures and results. Leading run‑scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267) and De Villiers (249), while Warner and De Villiers share the most sixes (12 each) and Kohli has eight; the highest individual scores are De Kock’s 108, Warner’s 90* and Gambhir’s 90*. The leading wicket‑takers are McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8) and Rahman (7). Four current or former England internationals participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils) and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The fixture list runs from 25 April to 22 May with daily matches, followed by the play‑off stages—Qualifier 1 on 24 May, Eliminator on 25 May, Qualifier 2 on 27 May and the Final on 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reports that the number of plastic carrier bags has risen by 200 million since 2013, many of which cannot be recycled and end up in landfills and rivers, harming the environment. To curb this, England will introduce a 5p charge on plastic bags from October, a measure that has already reduced bag usage in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland where similar charges exist, and campaigners hope the new fee will lower the amount of bags discarded and benefit the environment.

Wind damage and high gusts across Wales on Friday caused a roof to be ripped off in Rhosgadfan, power cuts for hundreds of homes, train delays and speed restrictions on major bridges, and the cancellation of six Irish Ferries fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, with passengers transferred to cruise ferries. Arriva Trains Wales warned of possible delays on services between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead, while the National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge were lifted later that evening, but a blustery forecast led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip, now scheduled for Tuesday, 27 December.

Jordan expressed excitement about a new film, saying he wanted to “put a different spin on it” but did not reveal his role; the project will reunite him with his Creed director Ryan Coogler and feature Lupita Nyong’o—Oscar‑winning actress from 12 Years a Slave—and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in last year’s Fantastic Four reboot, while Nyong’o also portrayed the CGI character Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, and the Black Panther film is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The 1875‑founded theatre at Alexandra Palace, long unused but still holding its original decor and stage machinery, is slated to reopen in 2018 as part of a £26.6 m east‑wing restoration that will also refurbish BBC studios at the palace’s eastern end and convert the glazed east court into a public exhibition space. The project, aimed at turning the palace into a new cultural destination, is funded by a £18.8 m contribution from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8 m from Haringey Council, and a £1 m pledge from the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust to be raised by summer 2017, with the theatre intended to host theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy and live music.

Former Manchester City midfielder James Milner, now 30, earned 61 senior caps for England since his 2009 debut, was part of squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016; he has expressed support for Sam Allardyce and the team’s future, while holding the record for most England U21 caps (46 since 2004) and scoring his sole senior international goal in a 5‑0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith’s house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was engulfed in flames when her son David woke her, and the family escaped while the house was destroyed and their pets perished. David, who was FaceTiming his father, was the only one awake and saw the fire spread rapidly from the kitchen’s wood stove, where he had burned rubbish—a common practice that sparked the blaze. The fire alarm failed to sound, and the family fled in pajamas. The community has rallied, donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David, and Mrs. Smith credits her son’s quick action as the sole reason for their survival, expressing pride and gratitude for his heroism.

An energy‑drinks company has reportedly been weighing a £200 million bid for West Ham United. The club’s owners, Sullivan and Gold, acquired a majority stake in 2010 for £105 million and now hold over 85 % of the club. Since the team moved to the London Stadium in August, West Ham has attracted interest from Qatari and Chinese investors, though Sullivan has said a minority stake could be sold to reduce debt while the ownership is intended to be passed to their children.

Jillian Bell opened the ceremony in Los Angeles, noting it was “definitely not the Oscars,” as the event featured fan‑voted categories such as best kiss and best shirtless performance (Efron won again) while also promoting summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars took best movie, with Shailene Woodley earning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss with Ansel Elgort, and she dedicated her speech to author John Green. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, paying tribute to Chris Kyle; Channing Tatum took best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep received best villain for Into the Woods. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne, while Kevin Hart accepted a comedic genius award with his children, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award with Avengers co‑stars presenting. The show previewed upcoming releases such as the Pitch Perfect sequel, Judd Apatow’s Trainwreck and Marvel’s Ultron, and encouraged viewers to follow BBCNewsbeat on Twitter, Instagram and YouTube.

Smith, a 21‑year‑old Scotland Under‑21 international, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season; he debuted for Aberdeen in 2012, has made 89 appearances and netted four times for the club. Aberdeen manager Jack Ross praised the move, calling Smith a brilliant, mature acquisition who will add an attacking option, and noted that St Mirren, the Championship bottom side, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council said the warmer weather now allows its Jetpatcher machines to work on road holes, with a target of filling 145 potholes each day over the next four months. In addition, extra staff will be deployed to repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and to clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework during a shutdown; the exposure was less than 1 % of the level required to be reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). Rigging supervisor Steve Innes, who later claimed the workers were not given proper PPE and were told the radiation was harmless, said the incident caused cancer fears and ongoing medical tests, and that EnQuest had failed in its duty of care. EnQuest confirmed the exposure, stated it had advised the HSE, and said it had taken additional precautionary steps; Wood Group said it had down‑manned the platform, conducted medical assessments, and supported a joint investigation. The Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers, while the HSE noted the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR and no separate investigation had been carried out.

The Asian Civilisation Museum purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 (£420,000) from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007, but the dealer’s manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece. The allegations surfaced during a 2012 court case over antiquity trafficking, and the sculpture is believed to have been taken from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. After discussions between Singapore’s National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which formally requested its return in May, the museum acknowledged the manager Aaron Freedman’s confession of dealing in looted objects and possession of 150 stolen items, though it noted no conclusive proof of theft. The sculpture was one of 30 items acquired from the dealer, none of which were considered stolen, and the ASI was allowed to inspect them; the museum plans to pursue legal action for compensation.

A magnitude‑4.8 earthquake struck 15.5 km deep 35 km north of Lucca at 15:48 local time, with its epicentre in Garfagnana; it was felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena, shaking top floors of tall office blocks in Milan and causing phone lines to go down and power cuts in Garfagnana, prompting school evacuations and damage checks. No immediate injuries or damage were reported, though aftershocks were felt over a wide area. The event follows a history of seismic activity in the region, including last May’s twin quakes that killed more than 20 people and a magnitude‑6 shock that caused significant damage, and comes amid Italy’s ongoing recovery from the 2009 L’Aquila disaster, for which six scientists and an ex‑official were later convicted of manslaughter for giving false reassurances about earthquake risk.

On 8 September 2016 (updated 15:33 BST) a fruit was still attached to its plant and not yet ripe; Austin Grant, a 62‑year‑old grandfather from Sheffield who had doubted South Yorkshire’s climate, now sees results and was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has pushed the launch of its open‑world adventure to 24 March, citing a few extra weeks of testing and polish after the original 27 January release date, and has announced that the eagerly‑awaited online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC version. Screenshots from the PC build show Los Santos and Blaine County in 1080p at 60 fps with support for up to 4K and triple‑monitor setups, and minimum system requirements have been published. The passage also notes that Grand Theft Auto V, released on 17 September 2013, became the fastest‑selling entertainment product ever, earning $1 bn in just three days.

A 76‑year‑old artist who had previously been shortlisted and longlisted for the John Moores Painting Prize won £25,000 for his work Squint (19) at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery; the piece, about 7 ft tall, depicts a medieval leper squint and is part of a series of paintings he has been working on, some larger. Judge Ansel Krut praised the work as “quite extraordinary” and “a little bit like a tone poem,” noting its subtle, minimal language and emotional impact, while the artist said the prize money would fund high‑quality materials for future work. The John Moores Prize, founded in 1957, is one of Britain’s oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig and patron Sir Peter Blake, who won the junior title in 1961.

The daily Yeni Safak reported that its office and the nearby Yeni Akit building were attacked by four masked assailants, with windows shattered and bullet casings found at both sites; firefighters quickly extinguished a blaze at the Safak building, and police cordoned the area while hunting the attackers. No casualties were reported. Both papers support the ruling AK Party, and the attacks occurred almost simultaneously early Thursday, with the Akit offices located 20 km (12 mi) away. No group has claimed responsibility, and the incident follows a September protest in which pro‑government demonstrators attacked Hurriyet’s offices over alleged misquoting of President Erdogan.

A 24‑year‑old former Burton player, who had been on loan at Crawley and scored three goals in 23 games, is moving on a free transfer from the Stags to Marcus Bignot’s Mariners, becoming Bignot’s first signing and officially joining the club on 1 January.

Wenger, whose contract with Arsenal runs until summer, has been linked to the England head‑coach role that Southgate recently took over, with Wenger praising Southgate’s experience and observation skills while noting that proving competence is key to securing the job. Southgate, 46, is set to face Scotland in a World Cup qualifier on 11 November and Spain in a friendly four days later, hoping to convince the FA to appoint him permanently. Wenger also confirmed that 21‑year‑old defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract, despite speculation of moves to Barcelona or Manchester City, and that midfielder Aaron Ramsey, 25, will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in Arsenal’s opening Premier League loss to Liverpool.

A local man working for Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday, prompting Lincolnshire Police to launch a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, with the company fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that a new charter arrangement will end the long‑running dispute over seafarers’ pay on the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, where the RMT union claimed crew were earning less than £4 an hour. The change will bring the contracted services back to operator Serco Northlink from next month; the vessels had been operated by Seatruck under a Serco contract, and Seatruck had argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to its largely non‑UK crew. Serco had offered to bridge and backdate the pay gap, but Seatruck declined. Yousaf said the new arrangements, subject to final financial and regulatory details, will take effect early next month and guarantee all crew will receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, which won the six‑year £243 m Northern Isles contract in 2012, runs three ferries and two cargo boats on a heavily subsidised route to the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after a fight at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, of Apple Close, intervened in an argument between Dickie and his mother, Samantha, and later pleaded guilty to common assault. The trial revealed that Mitchell and his mother had lied to police about the incident, first claiming Dickie had pushed Mrs Mitchell and she had pushed him back, then later saying Mitchell had tried to separate the couple, causing a “tragic accident.” Mitchell and Samantha will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, who died in London at 66 after a brief aggressive battle with cancer, was a prolific songwriter best known for writing Michael Jackson’s “Off The Wall,” “Rock With You,” “Burn This Disco Out,” “Thriller,” “Baby Be Mine,” and “The Lady in My Life,” as well as Heatwave’s “Boogie Nights,” “Always & Forever,” and “Groove Line.” Nicknamed “The Invisible Man” for his low profile, he grew up in Cleethorpes, was influenced by his father’s radio, worked in a frozen‑food factory before joining Heatwave, and later caught Quincy Jones’s attention, leading to his work on Jackson’s breakthrough albums and the best‑selling Thriller. His songs were recorded by Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and others; he earned a 1990 Grammy for “Birdland” and Oscar nominations in 1986 for The Color Purple soundtrack. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, Gilles Peterson, and others, while Warner/Chappell requested privacy for his family.

Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street‑Perrott, together with colleagues from Exeter, Reading, São Paulo and Belém, uncovered more than 450 large geometrical “geoglyphs” in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, that may be around 2,000 years old. The earthworks, hidden beneath bamboo‑dominated rainforest until recent deforestation, appear to have served sporadic ritual purposes rather than as villages or defensive sites, as suggested by the scant artefacts and layout. Loader’s soil analyses—phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes—indicate the geoglyphs were built amid taller vegetation, likely invisible above the canopy, challenging assumptions about their visibility and function. The study also overturns the idea of a pristine Amazon, showing a 6,000‑year history of human‑assembled plant diversity, especially economically valuable trees such as palms, implying ancient agroforestry practices that may still influence Acre’s current biodiversity.

The 21‑year‑old Australian advanced to the second round by defeating world No. 29 Denis Querrey 6‑4, 6‑4 in 53 minutes. Meanwhile, Australian star Nick Kyrgios, who is ranked a career‑high 12th and is closing in on the top 10 after winning the Japan Open, admitted he was tired and bored during the match, blaming travel and poor sleep from the Qi Zhong Stadium in Shanghai for his subdued performance. Kyrgios also recalled being fined $1,500 (£984) at last year’s Shanghai Masters for a foul‑mouthed outburst in which he called the event a “circus.”

The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before deciding whether to expand the HPV vaccination programme, which currently protects girls aged 12‑13 against cervical cancer and has already reached 85 % coverage since its 2008 rollout. Charities such as Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru and Cardiff University’s HPV research team are urging the government to roll out the jab to boys, citing a rise in head and neck cancers—particularly among younger, non‑smoking men with an average age of 55—and the fact that HPV accounts for 5 % of the global cancer burden. Dr Mererid Evans and Jon Antoniazzi have highlighted these demographic shifts and called for a progressive public‑health response to stem the increasing cancer rates.

Jak Trueman, a 15‑year‑old from West Calder, suffered from a rare gamma‑delta T‑cell lymphoma and documented his battle on a Facebook page called “Jak’s Journey,” which amassed over 28,000 likes and highlighted his positive outlook, love of Rangers FC, and meetings with former Ibrox stars and other football personalities; after being diagnosed in August, he spent months in the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh and Yorkhill Hospital in Glasgow, received a Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy at a prom held in his honour—where he attended for ten minutes before leaving ill—was visited by players from Celtic, Hibs, Hearts, Edinburgh Rugby and the cast of *Wicked*, and enjoyed moments such as playing tuba, visiting classmates, a romantic dinner with girlfriend Hannah Boyd, a supercar and quad‑bike outing, and a party attended by Neil Alexander and Nacho Novo; on 23 January doctors confirmed the cancer had spread and no further treatment would be pursued, prompting Jak to write about fighting pain and urging donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, while his mother Allison announced his death on Facebook, and a charity football match at Livingston FC’s Energy Assets Arena was scheduled to raise further funds.

Egypt secured a 1‑0 victory over Uganda in a Group D match, with Abdallah El Said scoring in the 89th minute after a reverse pass from Mohamed Salah; Uganda’s earlier goal by Joseph Ochaya was ruled offside. The win keeps Egypt at the top of the group and sets up a Wednesday clash with Ghana, while Uganda are eliminated from their first tournament since 1978. Ghana had already qualified for the quarter‑finals with a 1‑0 win over Mali, and Uganda will face Mali next, with Mali needing a win and Ghana needing a two‑goal margin over Egypt for the remaining spot. The match was played on a deteriorating pitch in Port‑Gentil, and Egypt’s goalkeeper Essam El Hadary made a notable clearing header early on.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land on the former Glenburn Sports College and the unused Westbank campus of Skelmersdale College for a new railway station, following a Network Rail comparative study of these sites and one near Concourse shopping centre; the council, which owns Glenburn, plans to provide Skelmersdale with two direct trains to Liverpool per hour in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, citing the site’s size, good highway access and connectivity as suitable for future expansion, and will now begin acquiring the land—an effort that could bring the town, designated a new town in 1961 and one of the largest in the north west without its own station, its first railway service since the original station closed to passengers in 1956.
During a Saturday morning search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house and arrested a man in his late 40s.

Police in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, report that a 28‑year‑old woman was found on a pavement with serious injuries, underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic after being dragged by the neck through several streets; her ex‑partner, a 38‑year‑old from nearby Bad Muender, has turned himself in and is now in custody. Both the victim and suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin, and prosecutors say the motive is still unclear while the police have secured the area and are calling for witnesses.

The Cass Business School, Warwick and Wisconsin study of 4,600 Australian workers found that women ask for pay rises as often as men but are 25 % less likely to receive one, disproving the “reticent female” theory and showing no evidence that women hesitate because of fear of upsetting bosses or gender stereotypes. By comparing full‑time and part‑time workers separately, the researchers ruled out pay‑gap effects and controlled for employer size, industry, parent status and qualifications. The data came from the 2013‑14 Australian workplace relations survey, the only systematic record of pay‑rise requests. Andrew Oswald noted the surprise at the findings, suggesting possible discrimination and that men may hide failed requests while women are more open. Age analysis revealed that under‑40 men and women ask for and get raises at the same rate, indicating a shift in negotiating behaviour, a point highlighted by Dr Amanda Goodall who sees young women’s improving negotiation success as a positive trend.

Oxford City Council has spent money on ground investigations for new burial sites but has found none suitable, leaving only the Wolvercote and Botley cemeteries with remaining space, which are expected to fill by 2018 and 2021 respectively. The council, still exploring options, acknowledges that all council-owned sites considered have been discounted due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants, and that after the two cemeteries close only family plot reopenings, reserved plot use, and ashes interment will be possible; the last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

HebCelt, the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19‑22 July, will feature an augmented‑reality app that lets visitors tap signs and posters to access videos, band interviews, ticket purchases and other online content on phones and tablets. The lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean, and director Caroline Maclennan says the AR feature will enhance on‑site enjoyment while also letting people worldwide experience the festival’s atmosphere in real time.

A 10‑year‑old Irish‑bred gelding collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day, with the British Horseracing Authority attributing the death to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage and noting the horse had no significant underlying health issues. Veterinary chief Tony Welsh said such episodes are rare across all sport horse disciplines and that the BHA is committed to understanding and preventing them. The race saw Thistlecrack, the King George winner, briefly catch the Trevor Hemmings‑owned gelding, Many Clouds, who ultimately prevailed; Many Clouds had a history of post‑race ataxia and overheating but had shown no symptoms on the day of the race. Despite past concerns about overheating, the report concluded the death was due to a rare haemorrhage rather than any pre‑existing condition.

A 15‑year‑old girl was accused of being raped by a 34‑year‑old defendant, Davina (formerly David Ayrton), whom she met in a Portsmouth garage in 2004; Davina denied the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March, but Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody—likely at a male prison in Winchester—citing risks to her safety and potential failure to attend court. The court noted that Davina has learning difficulties, had attempted suicide the previous summer, and had changed her name in 2012; during the trial she discussed her sexuality but denied any physical changes or medication. The alleged assault occurred while two other teenagers slept in the garage, with the victim recalling the event after drinking a small amount of alcohol; in 2014 Davina reportedly told a care‑home worker in Fordingbridge about the attack. The judge described the case as unusual and difficult.

The Serbs were defeated 6‑4 6‑4 by Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a loss that followed Novak Djokovic’s singles exit to Argentine Juan Martin del Potro; Djokovic, the world No. 1, had earlier suffered a surprise third‑round defeat at Wimbledon to American Sam Querrey, but later returned to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics, and the BBC Sport newsletter invites readers to subscribe for news, features and video.

The Carrbridge chainsaw carving competition in the Cairngorms will host over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US, who may only use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes, with all other tools banned. Last year’s champion, Pete Bowsher of Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27‑year‑old rugby player, has been sidelined since a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm‑up against Italy but is now close to returning, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations that starts in February. He is in a pre‑season phase, hoping to push back his debut by a couple of weeks, and will take each week as it comes. Webb, capped 16 times for Wales, has renewed his dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region where he debuted in 2007 rather than accept offers elsewhere, saying he wants to position himself best for national selection. Wales will open the Six Nations against Ireland in Dublin on 7 February.

On Tuesday morning, U.S. border agents stopped two men carrying backpacks five miles east of Sumas, Washington, and discovered they were attempting to smuggle 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco; one man fired a weapon and fled while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested, and Canadian police later detained Nathan Hall, whose backpack also contained a California driver’s licence with the name William Nickerson but Hall’s photo. Investigators also arrested Kali Henifin, who had planned to pick up the smugglers, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who allegedly was to be paid $11,000 to transport the drugs; all three defendants now face conspiracy, possession and distribution charges. The wooded area near the border is a known smuggling route, and U.S. prosecutors say such cases form a large part of their practice.

The NSPCC’s Childline reported that it counselled more than 4,500 children in the past year, up from about 2,400 in 2011‑12, while the true number of children suffering online abuse is believed to be far higher. Children as young as seven have told the service they are tormented, abused and scared to go to school, with online trolls causing misery and humiliation for thousands. Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen warned that bullying, especially cyber‑bullying, can follow children home and worsen if left unchecked, urging adults, parents, teachers and schools to intervene and take the problem seriously. The report was released at the start of Anti‑Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools and other organisations to combat the issue; a young caller’s testimony illustrates the emotional toll, and advice for dealing with bullying is also offered.

The Israeli government, prompted by Prime Minister Netanyahu’s office, has reacted strongly to a UN Security Council resolution that calls for an end to settlement construction, which the U.S. chose to abstain from vetoing. Netanyahu, angered by claims that the White House helped draft the resolution, summoned ambassadors from the U.S. and 14 other countries that voted for it, recalled Israel’s ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine’s prime minister. The resolution, which declares settlements illegal under international law and a major obstacle to a two‑state solution, was rejected by Israel, which is particularly upset about condemnation of building in East Jerusalem. Meanwhile, the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on 492 new homes in Ramat Shlomo and Ramot at the prime minister’s request to avoid straining U.S. relations before Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the conflict. Kerry is expected to outline a vision for ending the conflict and address Israeli critiques of the Obama administration, while Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as paving the way for a January 15 conference in France aimed at establishing a mechanism and timetable to end the occupation.

Prince William paid tribute to Queen Elizabeth II in a BBC interview on the eve of her 90th birthday, calling her a guiding example of a good monarch, while a set of stamps featuring the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince George was released to mark the occasion. The Queen’s celebrations included a visit to Windsor’s Royal Mail office on the 500th anniversary of the postal service, a ceremony at Alexandra Gardens to open a new bandstand and meet pupils, and a plaque unveiling on the Queen’s Walkway; Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn publicly wished her a happy birthday. William discussed his approach to duty, the criticism he has faced, and his desire to balance public life with family, noting his father and grandmother’s support. Additional festivities featured the lighting of a beacon across the UK and a lunch with U.S. President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama, while the republican group Republic condemned the BBC’s coverage as excessive.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2‑0 in an EFL Cup tie, with Diafra Sakho opening the scoring from a Sam Byram pass and Andre Ayew adding a second from a low cross; Cheltenham, who made seven changes after recent Premier League defeats, had several chances—including a volley from Harry Pell and a header from Jordon Forster—but failed to score, and the result ended the League Two side’s cup run.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died after a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to spot him while turning his VW Transporter right, causing a fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years; prosecutors noted the victim’s family saw no value in jail, accepting the momentary lapse, while his defence lawyer said Werner was remorseful and offered no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27‑year‑old from Southall, London, who fought in Syria under the alias Abu Daigham al‑Britani and was a member of the Islamic State‑affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed, is facing a possible life sentence for his role in the conflict; he was known for posting slick propaganda videos and gruesome images, including a photo of him holding a head, and was monitored by MI5. After leaving the UK in January, he returned in June with the help of his cousin Tahir Bhatti, faking his own death in an online obituary and attempting to re‑enter Britain unnoticed, but was intercepted at Dover and prosecuted at the Old Bailey. While on remand he was held in Belmarsh’s high‑risk terrorism unit; Khawaja admitted four offences, Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender, and an additional charge of soliciting murder remains on file.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as the club finished eighth, but he declined a contract offer and has signed with Barnsley as their third acquisition for next season, ahead of their League One play‑off final at Wembley; caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and ability to challenge defenders, and the club’s website directs readers to a dedicated page for the latest football transfers.

Detergent bottles began washing up on Poldhu Cove in Cornwall on Sunday, prompting National Trust volunteers to clear them as they pose a wildlife risk; witnesses report some bottles have leaked despite being sealed. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes that while the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of Vanish detergent near Land’s End in May, there is no definitive evidence that the bottles found on the coast came from that container, only circumstantial links. Other nearby coves such as Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove and Marazion have also been affected, raising concerns from the Cornwall Wildlife Trust about sensitive marine life. The National Trust, Cornwall Council, and partners including Natural England are monitoring the beaches, advising the public to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to attempt recovery.

An incident on the A9 north of Berriedale, Caithness, around 14:00 caused a crash that left several people with minor injuries, leading to the road’s closure and the implementation of diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, while Police Scotland announced that inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, a 28‑year‑old French centre‑back who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, made 83 appearances for the club and contributed 14 games last season as the Wanderers finished second in League One and earned promotion; manager Phil Parkinson praised his late‑season impact, and Dervite has now signed a new contract alongside David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan following Bolton’s promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being ready to “concede everything,” prompting Baroness Smith to claim the opposition was giving people “false hope.” The two parties had previously cooperated to defeat the government on EU‑citizen rights and a Brexit deal, but that partnership collapsed when MPs rejected the amendments—Lib Dems insisted on them while Labour deferred to the Commons. A Labour source in the Lords described the Lib Dems’ actions as grandstanding aimed at campaign leaflets, calling it unforgivable to create false hope for worried voters. In turn, Lib Dem Europe spokesperson Baroness Ludford accused Labour of “waving through” government plans and aligning with Conservatives on a hard Brexit. Despite past alliances on issues such as higher education and housing, Ludford expressed optimism about future collaboration, while the Labour source warned of residual tensions and that leaderships would keep things business‑like.

Defence is a low‑priority issue in the current election, with polls showing it barely in the top ten concerns behind the economy, NHS and immigration, and parties’ manifestos offering little detail; politicians are “on the defensive” on the topic. The UK has cut its armed forces—army from 102,000 to 82,000, navy to 19 warships, RAF to eight front‑line squadrons—creating capability gaps such as the loss of maritime patrol aircraft and reliance on NATO for submarine detection. Defence spending has slipped from fourth to sixth globally, with the 2 % GDP target largely absent; projections suggest spending will fall to 1.7 % (possibly 1.5 %) by decade’s end, requiring an extra £25 bn to stay above 2 %. The US may view the UK less favourably if it fails this benchmark, and future governments are likely to cut the MoD’s £34 bn budget further, with Conservatives promising no army size cuts but a 1 % annual equipment budget increase and a Trident replacement costing at least £20 bn, while Labour and Lib Dems propose different nuclear deterrent arrangements and the SNP/Greens would scrap it. The next Strategic Defence Review will need to address these issues, and the planned two new aircraft carriers risk becoming “hollow” forces due to crew shortages and scaled‑down F‑35 plans, making it harder for Britain to live up to its rhetoric of punching above its weight.

Barcelona paid £48.6 m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34 m, and the total cost of the player—including signing‑on fees, wages, agents’ fees and a recent tax payment—has risen to £106.8 m; the club has denied any tax crime, issuing a complimentary declaration of €13,550,830.56 while maintaining that the original payment complied with fiscal obligations, but a Spanish judge has found enough evidence to keep investigations into the transfer open. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation and is also under investigation. Neymar has scored seven league goals in 18 appearances and three Champions League goals in seven matches.

Michael Luciw, a 27‑year‑old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed as a passenger in a van that was struck by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died, on the motorway near Kegworth, Leicestershire, at 02:00 GMT on 12 October. Luciw’s family, who describe him as generous, kind‑hearted and a lover of practical jokes, are calling for regular driving tests for retirees, echoing Age UK’s view that older people should be allowed to drive as long as possible but must be supported to do so safely. The crash was witnessed by Luciw’s colleague Andy Harrington, who was driving a Ford Transit, swerved to avoid the collision, sustained serious injuries, and urged that retired drivers undergo medical examinations. In the UK, drivers over 70 must renew their licence every three years via a self‑assessment form that does not include a medical or driving test; the DVLA says it has no plans to restrict licensing on age alone, citing evidence that older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents, while Age UK stresses the importance of maintaining older drivers’ independence and safety.

Women in Scotland have raised safety concerns about transvaginal mesh implants used for incontinence, citing painful complications that have led to more than 20,000 procedures and over 400 legal actions; the independent review’s final report, which critics say was watered‑down, concluded that the procedures should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse, urged a range of treatment options, informed consent, and mandatory adverse‑event reporting, and will be examined by Professor Alison Britton for lessons learned. Despite calls for an outright ban, the health secretary said only the UK Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency could prohibit the implants, and Ms Robison confirmed the recommendations would still be implemented. Chairwoman Tracey Gillies apologized for failing to unite the review panel, noting the task was “almost mission impossible,” while former members Olive McIlroy, Elaine Holmes and a consultant resigned in protest over the report’s content and alleged omissions.

Muir, 23, broke Lizzie McColgan’s 25‑year‑old 5 km indoor record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14 min 49.12 s, a performance that British Athletics has said will be ratified. McColgan welcomed the achievement but had earlier questioned whether the race met UK Athletics’ criteria, noting it was a mixed 3 km race with only Muir running the full 5 km and raising concerns about drug‑testing requirements; however, the governing body confirmed no doping control is required for a British record set at an event without such testing. McColgan praised Muir’s potential, noting her 1,500 m best of 3:55 and suggesting she could lower her 5 km time to around 14:30, and recalled her own record‑breaking race where she lapped Paula Radcliffe. Muir has also broken her own British 1,500 m record at the Diamond League in Paris and reached the Olympic final in Rio 2016.

Jung won the Olympic show‑jumping event aboard Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou who fell ill in July, while France’s Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton earned bronze; Great Britain’s William Fox‑Pitt finished 12th after a flawless final show‑jumping round but a poor cross‑country performance that dropped him from first after dressage to 21st, and Ireland’s Jonty Evans placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray beat Matteo Fognini 6‑2 4‑6 6‑1 7‑5 after 2 h 39 min, clinching match point at 20:57 BST; Fognini had five set‑points but Murray rallied, winning five straight games to reach the last 16 for the 11th time and will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round. The match was tense, with fading light and a roof‑related potential change, and included a penalty for Fognini’s obscenity and an ankle injury that hampered him. Meanwhile, fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week with a 6‑4 6‑1 win over Maria Sakkari.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, and police later found patrons still inside; receipts confirmed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST, leading a judge to order the bar’s closure for three months. Colleen O’Neill (43) of Kevin Lynch Park was charged with two counts of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours, while James Thomas (44) faced one count; both were fined £3,000 and £1,000 respectively. The defence solicitor noted that licensing laws were not strictly adhered to and the premises had been poorly run into the morning, prompting the judge to remark on Ms O’Neill’s appalling record and his inability to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt concluded his manifesto launch with the line “Domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” and urged voters to support the Ulster Unionists and any candidate who will act rightly for their community. He praised Danny Kennedy for distancing himself from earlier remarks, saying it was reassuring that Kennedy was listening, and denied any regret or mistake, insisting he would not withdraw a word. Nesbitt said he would prefer the SDLP over Sinn Féin if the nationalist party entered Stormont Castle, and reported strong support in heavily unionist areas after door‑knocking. His manifesto, titled “Real Partnership,” calls for tackling waiting lists, boosting PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, protecting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off because of Brexit, while a “Cleaning Up Stormont” section frames the election as a referendum on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and corruption, hoping this message outweighs controversy over his comments about transferring to the SDLP.
