Justice Minister Claire Sugden will table a motion in the Northern Ireland Assembly to align the region with England and Wales’ “Turing’s Law,” which provides automatic posthumous pardons and allows living men convicted of now‑abolished sexual offences to apply for pardons. The motion, backed by executive agreement, aims to grant equal treatment for gay and bisexual men and is expected to be considered soon, offering a quicker resolution than a full assembly bill.

Laura Muir, 23, from Kinross ran 4:19.12 in the 1500m, finishing second to Kenyan Faith Kipyegon and erasing Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60, placing her second on the British all‑time list behind Zola Budd’s 4:17.57. She now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and said she was pleased to set the new record. Muir aims to qualify for the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham (24‑26 June). She began the season with an 800m win in Montbéliard, France, and will next race a 1500m in Stockholm, balancing training with her fourth year of veterinary studies.
The passage indicates that a selection of photographs is available, depicting 26 beaches that have been ranked as Scotland’s “most excellent” in terms of water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill former Russian intelligence officer Alexei Litvinenko, but that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the 2006 poisoning, citing the fatal polonium‑210 dose Litvinenko ingested in tea during a meeting with the two men and his subsequent death after nearly three weeks in hospital; Horwell noted that the evidence points to state involvement, though not necessarily to President Vladimir Putin or a direct order, and highlighted Litvinenko’s 2000 defection, accusations of FSB corruption and political murders, and his attacks on Putin as possible motives. He warned that the public risk from polonium exposure remains unknown, that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death, and that the suspects left a trail of polonium with no credible explanation; while the Metropolitan Police wanted them tried for murder, extradition attempts failed and they remain in Russia, with former Soviet officer Kovtun criticized for not testifying, and the inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Smith, 26, has been named captain of Australia’s one‑day side and will also lead the Twenty20 team while Aaron Finch is injured, with 28‑year‑old David Warner appointed vice‑captain; the decision follows veteran Clarke’s retirement after the Ashes loss at Trent Bridge, and selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s extraordinary talent and Warner’s maturity, noting Smith’s 32 Tests, 2,952 runs at 54.66, and confirming that Smith and Warner will guide the team in the limited‑overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval on 20 August.

Mr Farron, who won the Liberal Democrat leadership over Norman Lamb, has repeatedly avoided answering whether he thinks homosexual sex is a sin, instead stating that “we are all sinners.” He has declared himself “passionate about LGBT‑plus rights” and said defending equal marriage and extending marital rights to transgender people would be “at the top of my agenda.” On Channel 4 News he explained that he voted against the 2007 Equality Bill because the party tabled an amendment out of concern for “protection of individual liberties,” a concern he did not elaborate on, but he affirmed his support for equal access under the law for all people regardless of sexuality.

French‑based Sanofi shut its Fawdon drug‑manufacturing plant in 2015, cutting 450 jobs, but Accord Healthcare has taken over the site to resume pharmaceutical production, hoping to employ many former Sanofi staff. Accord’s spokesman said the investment would have an “extremely positive” impact, and Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes praised the move as a boost to the region’s science and healthcare reputation, noting Accord’s global reach and the highly skilled jobs it will create; the company develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 products to roughly 60 countries.

Richard Ellis will leave the council on Friday when his contract ends, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are exiting under a voluntary redundancy and early‑retirement scheme; the departures, noted by SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn as evidence of the council’s difficulty retaining senior staff, are expected to be followed by more exits. Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Monaghan heads the chief executive’s office, and Sutherland leads human resources and customer services, all of whom were thanked by chief executive Angela Scott for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants, claiming affiliation with Islamic State, breached the Sardar Daud hospital in Kabul by detonating explosives at the gate and then opening fire on staff and patients, wounding more than 50 people; commandos landed on the roof and killed all four attackers after several hours of fighting. The attack, which began at 09:00 local time, was condemned by President Ashraf Ghani as a violation of human values and by Afghan deputy leader Abdullah Abdullah, while the Taliban denied involvement. The assault marks a shift for IS, which has previously targeted Shia gatherings and the Supreme Court, now adopting tactics similar to the Taliban by breaching gates and engaging security forces directly in the capital. Analysts suggest IS has gained resources and training, raising concerns of further attacks, though the government claims it has removed IS bases in the east but not in mountainous areas. The incident follows a series of IS‑claimed attacks in 2015‑2016, including a 2016 Kabul rally bombing, Ashura attacks, a mosque bombing, and a Supreme Court assault, while the Taliban has also carried out recent suicide attacks in Kabul.

Martin, an English rider, crashed at this year’s TT and his Fireblade bike suffered mechanical issues. He told MCN he was quitting road racing, but clarified on Facebook that he hasn’t abandoned racing entirely, only that he has no plans to race on Hondas this year. He missed the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a “bloody disaster,” noting he was essentially a test rider and that after further testing at Cadwell the bike was deemed uncompetitive, leading the team to withdraw him from the event without informing him. He says there is no unfinished business and he intends to focus on classics and oddball races.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 of the 28 governor seats announced from Saturday’s elections, marking the most severe defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999 and following the PDP’s loss of the presidential poll last month. Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating incumbent Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP’s decline is evident in the loss of key northern states such as Katsina, Kaduna and Adamawa, while it retained only Rivers State; it won eight governorships mainly in the southeast, with Taraba still pending and Imo’s result inconclusive due to a high number of spoilt ballots. Elections were not held in seven states. The APC’s gains have turned the PDP into a regional party, with the APC winning most northern states and Lagos, but failing to capture any of Nigeria’s five oil‑producing states, raising concerns about oil revenue amid militant threats. Violence at polling stations—66 incidents, mainly in Rivers and other southern states—was higher than in the presidential poll, though overall the elections were relatively peaceful. The APC’s control of Lagos for the first time since 1999 and the PDP’s need for introspection and rebuilding under new leadership are highlighted as key implications.

Mighty, a U.S. environmental lobby, accuses Singapore‑based palm‑oil trader Olam and its majority shareholder Temasek of overlooking unsustainable palm‑oil practices that fuel haze in Southeast Asia, citing a “secretive market” for rogue suppliers and a lack of transparency in sourcing; Olam, which buys 99 % of its palm oil from third‑party suppliers and represents less than 1 % of the global market, denies the claims, pledges a zero‑burn policy, and has only released 14 supplier names, while Temasek rejects the allegations, stresses its support for no‑burn policies, and says it does not direct Olam’s operations. The report also highlights Indonesia’s failure to curb slash‑and‑burn fires that clear land for palm‑oil, pulp and paper plantations, and notes similar concerns in Gabon where Olam’s joint ventures are alleged to clear rainforests for monoculture plantations, though Olam insists its partnerships are responsible and transparent. The broader palm‑oil industry, projected to be worth $88 bn by 2022, faces criticism for deforestation, illegal labor practices, and environmental harm, with NGOs and executives at odds over accountability and the feasibility of policing third‑party suppliers.

On 27 August 2016, a restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law permitted dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they stayed outdoors, and a clip shows the offerings described as a “right dog’s dinner.”

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful because of a knee injury, having only appeared from the bench in his last two matches; Derby County striker David Nugent, who missed Monday’s draw with Huddersfield due to a groin problem, may return; midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping to be recalled after scoring a late equaliser from the bench against the Terriers.

Pakistan’s telecom regulator announced that the YouTube ban is no longer needed because Google has launched a Pakistan‑specific version of the platform, prompting ISPs to open access and the PTCL to welcome the change; however, YouTube denies that authorities can unilaterally filter content, noting that removal of videos is governed by its community guidelines and that government requests will be recorded in its Transparency Report. Young Pakistanis largely support the lifting of the ban, while activists call for greater transparency of the deal between Google and the government. The ban, imposed by Pakistan’s Supreme Court in 2012 after the controversial “Innocence of Muslims” video sparked deadly protests, was lifted following the introduction of a local YouTube service that allows the PTA to request blocking of offending material through an online process, with Google promising to restrict such content after review. Google also recently launched local versions of YouTube in Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss‑Italian head of FIFA’s Ad‑Hoc Electoral Committee, has been accused of a conflict of interest because he shares nationality with one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino.  Scala previously stepped aside in 2015 when Swiss Sepp Blatter was a candidate, and FIFA’s regulations (Article 7.4) say any committee member with a conflict must be replaced.  Liberian FA boss Musa Bility has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing the need for fairness in the upcoming election that will replace long‑standing president Blatter in 18 days.  Bility, who had wanted to run himself but was denied eligibility, has pledged his vote for Prince Ali and urged other African members to do the same.  The five candidates—Prince Ali of Jordan, Gianni Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman of Bahrain and Tokyo Sexwale of South Africa—will be voted on by FIFA’s 209 members in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56) were killed in a paint‑spraying area at Harford Attachments on Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday; their bodies were removed the following afternoon. A forensic search of the bucket‑making site has progressed, with Detective Chief Inspector Paul Durham reporting significant progress in inquiries and witness statements. Evidence points to a flashover explosion caused by a build‑up of toxic fumes ignited, producing a fire‑ball effect, and Health and Safety Executive inspectors and electrical safety experts are collecting further evidence.

Tunisia was threatened with expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after a dispute over a contentious penalty in a 2015 quarter‑final, but the federation issued an apology to CAF and the ban was lifted, allowing the team to compete; Morocco’s participation was initially barred but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and cut a CAF fine from $1 million to $50 000 after Morocco had been stripped of the 2015 hosts’ slot amid Ebola fears, with Equatorial Guinea stepping in to stage the finals; both North African federations have since reconciled with CAF—Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa praised the minimal impact of the break, while Tunisian vice‑president Maher Snoussi said the dispute was closed after a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou—and the 2017 draw places Tunisia against Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A and Morocco against Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé in Group F, with Tunisia eyeing a record thirteenth straight finals appearance.

Mass fracas in the 95th minute of Chelsea’s 3‑1 win at the Etihad saw Manchester City’s Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho sent off, while Chelsea’s Cesc Fabregas faced no further action; City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for the incident. Aguero, 28, received a four‑match ban for his second violent‑conduct dismissal this season after a high late challenge on David Luiz, and Fernandinho was handed a three‑match ban for clashing with Fabregas in the ensuing scuffle. Both clubs must respond to the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Castell‑nedd, inspired by Denmark’s improved cancer‑diagnosis system, aims to speed early detection for patients who show vague symptoms but no clear signs of cancer. Family doctors will be able to refer such patients directly to new diagnostic clinics—first at Morgannwg General Hospital in Llantrisant and later at Castell‑nedd Port Talbot—so that tests can be carried out within a week, with an expectation of seeing about six patients per week on the same day. Currently only 35 % of symptomatic patients in the Cwm Taf area receive a diagnosis, and the pilot seeks to raise this by reducing the time to referral and treatment. If the six‑month trial proves successful, other health boards in the region are expected to roll out the service. Dr Gareth Davies and GP Gareth Jordan both endorse the initiative, noting that quicker, single‑location referrals could markedly improve early cancer diagnosis.

England’s second Test at Old Trafford finished with a decisive 589‑8 declared and 173‑1 declared, giving England a 2‑0 series win with a day to spare and their second‑biggest run‑margin victory over Pakistan. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was man of the match after scoring 254 and an unbeaten 71, taking four catches and a wicket, while Alastair Cook added 105 and 76*; Root’s innings was hailed as his best Test performance. Pakistan were bowled out for 234 on a pitch that offered little assistance, with only Misbah‑ul‑Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests, and captain Misbah lamented a loss of confidence and poor shot selection. England’s batting quality, discipline and bowling were praised by former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott, who said the team was “too strong” for Pakistan, and Pakistan will play a two‑day game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland is the head coach of the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley named as interim coach in his back‑room staff. Forwards coach Gareth McBryde is taking on head‑coach duties for the third time, having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013, and he welcomes the opportunity to guide the Lions again. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde, with chief executive Martyn Phillips saying the full management team will likely be confirmed next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies, who sits on the Lions’ selection panel, stresses that the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit Welsh rugby, offering a chance to develop coaching talent in a new environment and that the New Zealand tour will be a mentally stimulating test for all involved.

Hull City’s 2‑1 win over Southampton at the KCOM Stadium began with a sixth‑minute penalty for the Saints, but after Abel Hernandez and Will Keane were injured in the first half, the hosts turned the game around when Robert Snodgrass, brought on for Keane, scored from a Sam Clucas cross and later assisted Michael Dawson’s goal, while David Marshall made crucial saves; Hull’s victory, their first league win since 20 August and the end of a six‑game losing streak, left them still in the bottom three before the international break, and both managers praised their players’ character and highlighted the need for concentration after a recent European outing.

A crash on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa at about 14:15 BST killed a local motorcyclist, while the tractor driver was unharmed; Lincolnshire Police have not released further details and are asking witnesses to come forward, and the road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, claiming he wanted to “put an end to the agony” before early June elections, a move condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev and EU officials; Zaev, who has been releasing recordings since February 2015 that accuse ministers of vote‑rigging, murder cover‑ups, wiretapping 20,000 people, corruption and misuse of funds, urged protests that drew several hundred people outside the prosecutor’s office, while EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn warned the action threatened Macedonia’s EU membership ambitions and was not in line with the rule of law, and the government denies the accusations and accuses Zaev of destabilising the country.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea’s Saturday match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley’s dismissal, while the club aims to appoint a new boss quickly, with former Derby manager Paul Clement as the preferred choice. Managerial instability has left the team feeling it has lost its “Swansea Way” since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure, and Curtis, a former player who witnessed the club’s rise from near‑bankruptcy and near‑relegation in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, laments that key players have left without adequate replacements. Despite these concerns, Curtis believes the current squad can survive in the top flight, reminding new signings of the club’s storied past—highlighted in the documentary *Jack to a King*—and stressing that staying up is vital for both the club and the wider community.

In a 3‑2 National League defeat, Leyton Orient (the Daggers) fell to Dagenham & Redbridge after a 2‑0 lead was overturned by Armand Gnanduillet’s winner, consigning Dagenham to relegation and leaving Orient two points adrift of the play‑off places. The match highlighted Dagenham’s struggles – the club’s worst goal difference in League Two, 20 more conceded this season than the previous year, and a 40‑year‑old striker Jamie Cureton’s nine goals compared with 20 in 2014‑15 – while manager John Still, in his third spell, vowed to push for promotion next season. Orient’s interim boss Andy Hessenthaler, who took over after Kevin Nolan’s dismissal, lamented the loss of two managers and stressed the need to win games to reach the play‑offs, noting the team had conceded two sloppy goals. Still criticised his side’s lack of organisation and discipline, saying that without those the outcome is inevitable.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain, will return to the club as a youth coach in February, his first role since retiring, a move praised by Jürgen Klopp as “wonderful news.” Gerrard, who debuted in 1998, left Liverpool in 2015 for LA Galaxy, won multiple domestic and European trophies, and ended a 19‑year playing career in November. He had been linked with a managerial position at MK Dons but declined it as “too soon,” and is now pursuing a UEFA A coaching licence, the qualification needed to manage in the Premier League.

McManus opened the scoring with a close‑range goal at the quarter‑hour mark, and Ross Forbes’ deflected strike soon doubled the hosts’ advantage. Kyle McAusland’s shot gave Alloa a consolation goal before half‑time, but another McManus finish and a late goal from Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable win for the hosts.

Ofsted has uncovered children being taught in squalid conditions at three Birmingham sites that have now closed, and those running illegal schools face up to 51 weeks in jail; ministers are consulting on tighter regulation for places teaching more than 6‑8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector, said inspectors were shocked by the conditions and that 18 unregulated schools—mostly in Muslim communities in the Midlands—have been visited, with owners under investigation; he warned the cases were likely only the “tip of the iceberg” and that children risk abuse or radicalisation. Schools teaching over 20 hours a week must register, yet some “flexi schools” may be exploiting home‑education rights to operate illegally. Wilshaw criticised slow, confusing action from officials, and the government has funded six inspectors to probe illegal schools, promising the crackdown will apply to all religious groups. The education secretary has ordered Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases, noting that consent is required to bring charges, and the consultation on further regulation runs until mid‑January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is part of a wave of new distillery projects that would bring the Scottish Borders its first whisky distillery in nearly 200 years. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the venture’s small‑scale, cowshed‑sized still and its focus on local botanicals to showcase the region’s terroir, while Born in the Borders’ John Henderson praises the gin’s alignment with the site’s existing brewery and its commitment to local sourcing. The gin’s name honours Lilliard, a 16th‑century heroine of the nearby Battle of Ancrum Moor, reflecting both the landscape and the strong female leadership behind the operation.

Harry Whitlam was killed in August 2013 when Gary Green, 51, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm near Leeds; Green was found to have been more than twice the legal alcohol limit, having drunk the equivalent of 13 pints before bed, and was later jailed 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure safety, prosecuted under health and safety law rather than road traffic law because the incident occurred on private land. Pam Whitlam, Harry’s mother who worked at the farm’s café, said the family was “changed forever” and expressed hope that Harry’s life could be remembered beyond the single day he lived, while HSE inspectors described the incident as “extremely tragic” and Green’s behaviour as “reckless.”

Luis Suarez, the 27‑year‑old Uruguay striker, can now train with Barcelona and play in friendly matches after a Cas ruling that, while still barring him from competitive “organised” games, allows all football‑related activities; he must complete the remaining eight games of his nine‑match ban in international competition, with a likely competitive debut against Real Madrid on 26 October. The club will present him publicly on Monday at Camp Nou, and he will be available for Uruguay’s friendlies against Japan, South Korea and Saudi Arabia. Suarez’s lawyers argued FIFA’s four‑month ban for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini was excessive; Cas confirmed the sanctions but deemed a total ban on football activity disproportionate, though it did not reduce the ban’s length. FIFPro expressed disappointment at the lack of reduction, and Suarez can also attend matches and promotional events. The appeal was deemed a success by his legal team, who claimed FIFA misapplied its rules, and Suarez has previously faced suspensions for biting PSV’s Otman Bakkal, Chelsea’s Branislav Ivanovic, and for racial abuse of Manchester United’s Patrice Evra.

On 18 March 2014 Richard Blake‑Smith and his partner Anna won a 380‑metre “carry” race, beating Lithuanian Vytautas Kirkliauskas who carried his wife, Neringa. They had trained a week on a nearby athletics track, faced tough competition—especially from the Lithuanians—and navigated hurdles over haystacks, a steep slope and water pistols. The event allowed mixed pairings (men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman). Blake‑Smith and Anna will now represent their country at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond warned that DVLA job roles would change when paper car tax discs are abolished in October 2014, but reassured employees that any reductions would be handled through redeployment rather than redundancies. In a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, Hammond explained that the new electronic system will allow monthly direct‑debit payments, likely reducing refunds and altering job duties, and that staff would be retrained for new processes. Hedges welcomed the assurances, noting the benefits of direct debit and the absence of a physical disc, while acknowledging a slight loss of job opportunities but trusting the minister’s commitment to redeploy workers.

Hungarian minister Péter Szijjártó told Reuters that the EU should not meddle in domestic matters and that Poland would veto any EU sanctions that could strip Hungary of its voting rights. He rejected calls to backtrack on three controversial laws—tight asylum‑seeker controls, new NGO restrictions, and a higher‑education law that could force the closure of the Central European University founded by George Soros—saying they are national competence. The EU has objected to these measures, noting that Hungary is housing asylum seekers in shipping containers and that the education law threatens a top‑ranked university, while draft NGO legislation could label organisations as “foreign‑backed.” Human‑rights groups and the EU’s executive commission have warned that action will be taken if no positive changes occur, amid widespread protests in Hungary.

The upcoming live‑action adaptation of “Beauty and the Beast” will star a lead actress as Mrs. Potts, a role originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury, with Kevin Kline playing Maurice, Belle’s father. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens will portray the Beast, and Luke Evans will take on the role of Gaston, with Josh Gad joining as LeFou. The film is directed by Bill Condon, will begin shooting at Shepperton Studios in May, and is scheduled for U.S. theatrical release on 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a long‑time Sunday Times columnist known for his sharp wit and often controversial prose, was diagnosed with advanced cancer and died in the morning of the day his final column on coming to terms with the illness was set to appear. Tributes poured in from editors and peers—Martin Ivens, Tim Shipman, Stig Abell, John Witherow and Andrew Neil—who praised his fearless writing, intelligence and compassion, while Jay Rayner and Piers Morgan noted his polarising style. Gill’s career began in the 1980s with art reviews, then Tatler, before joining the Sunday Times in 1993; he had dyslexia but dictated his copy over the phone. His work sparked outrage on several occasions, from a 2009 baboon‑shooting story to slurs about the Welsh, Rhyl, Norfolk, the Isle of Man, Clare Balding and an incident at Gordon Ramsay’s restaurant. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, he studied at St Christopher School, Central Saint Martins and the Slade School of Fine Art. He was married twice—first to author Cressida Connolly, then to Home Secretary Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children—before divorcing and later engaging to Nicola Formby, his 23‑year partner, with whom he had twins; he was also known for referring to her as “The Blonde” in restaurant reviews.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator when he was struck on the head with a bottle and kicked in the face; he spent about ten days in a coma with serious brain injury. He was wearing a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol that predates Hitler, and he displayed a book of traditional swastika patterns to clarify that it is not a hate symbol. The Russian embassy said it was investigating the incident and called local press reports “distorted,” noting confusion over the date, number of participants and circumstances, while the suspect—identified as a Russian diplomatic officer—has not been arrested; police said the injury was not serious and that the suspect would be investigated under Mongolian law regardless of diplomatic status.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday at 03:30 BST on the northern runway to protest the airport’s expansion plans; they were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security‑restricted area of the aerodrome and will appear in court on 19 August, while the Metropolitan Police said it would review airport security.

Glamorgan won the match, largely thanks to Nick Selman’s 101 off 144 balls, his second first‑class century after a poor run of form, and the regular wicket‑taking of seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles in cloudy conditions. Selman’s innings followed an early dismissal on eight and was a welcome return to form after a string of low scores, while Aneurin Donald added a quick 36 off 30. Gloucestershire struggled to keep up, with their bowlers dominating the day and the innings ending in a close, even‑balanced finish; Glamorgan earned a consolation bonus point from Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten. The game was led by Michael Hogan for Glamorgan, as Jacques Rudolph was absent with a neck problem, and both Selman and Taylor commented on the conditions and their performances.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after online chats with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court, admitting he planned to file a false police report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary and then shoot them; the threats were made twice at night while he was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry remanded Hughes in custody pending sentencing, noting a prior 2009 firearm conviction, and his legal team said he had no intention to kill himself or police. Police were concerned because Hughes was on bail for firearms offences, which he was later cleared of. The Hope Line offers confidential support and counselling to people in difficulty.

Surrey posted 255‑7, powered by a 130‑run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes, each scoring 90. Yorkshire, chasing, were reduced to 8‑2 and ultimately fell short, all out for 236. A nine‑ball spell from Stuart Meaker, taking three wickets (Bairstow, Ballance, Leaning), and Matthew Waite’s 3‑48, which included a dropped catch of Davies, were decisive. Tim Bresnan top‑sc

A 56‑ft (17.1‑m) converted trawler was located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack when its crew radioed the coastguards at 07:00 BST; the Holyhead coastguards reported that the vessel’s pump could not cope with the water ingress, so an RNLI lifeboat crew installed a pump and towed the trawler to Holyhead.

Muir, a 24‑year‑old Scottish middle‑distance runner, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast because her veterinary medicine exams run until May, making the April event impossible to attend. She finished fourth in the 1500 m and sixth in the 5000 m at the World Athletics Championships, clocking a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07, and says she will return to university next week after a brief break. Muir remains optimistic about future competitions, noting she could still target the World Indoor Championships in March and possibly several more Olympics, while expressing pride in her recent performances and a desire to run in Birmingham. The passage also notes Hellen Obiri’s 5000 m gold win in London, with Sifan Hassan third.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are far from repeating last season’s title challenge, citing over‑achievement that has inflated expectations and a lack of quality forwards after Suarez’s sale and Sturridge’s injury; he criticises Rodgers’ transfer choices, noting that Balotelli, Lambert and Borini lack the work‑rate and scoring threat of the previous strike partnership, and that the team’s first‑half intensity and set‑piece potency have dropped sharply. Savage also highlights defensive frailties, the absence of a commanding goalkeeper or leader at the back, and the need for a solid midfield and full‑back partnership to counter Chelsea’s counter‑attacks. He predicts a difficult match against Mourinho’s side, with Liverpool unlikely to win, and stresses that Steven Gerrard’s future hinges on maintaining his physical fitness and mental resilience as he battles age‑related decline, though Savage believes he remains a key player for the club’s long‑term plans.

A £45 million campus will be built on Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock to house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre, and East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name it after the local writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock and was passionate about education. McIlvanney, an English teacher who turned to full‑time writing in 1975, gained fame with his first novel *Remedy Is None* and became known as the “Godfather of Tartan Noir” for works such as the Laidlaw trilogy, as well as for his poetry, journalism, broadcasting and contributions to Scottish political and sporting life; he died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near a swimming pool was evacuated from morning until early afternoon, with residents advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside; a 500‑metre exclusion zone was imposed around a British sea mine spotted on Monday, believed to date from the 1940s or 1950s, while experts worked to secure it. The mine’s deterioration made its explosive content uncertain, so it was moved to a safer location before further action, and a half‑mile exclusion zone at sea prevented small boats from sailing. Ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted, but the local commander, Ch Insp Elliot Brown, said the evacuation was precautionary and posed no immediate danger to the community, and Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the cordon and safe evacuation procedures.

UK Sport has cut funding for several Olympic sports ahead of Tokyo 2020, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby and cycling (now £25.98 m after a £4 m cut), and has removed all funding for badminton – the only Rio‑2016 medal‑winning sport to lose support – sparking criticism from Badminton England. The total budget for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports is £345 m, £2 m below the Rio allocation, and UK Sport has set medal targets of 51‑85 Olympic and 115‑162 Paralympic medals, compared with 67 and 147 at Rio. While judo received a modest increase, other team sports such as basketball, handball and volleyball have faced funding withdrawals in previous years, and UK Sport’s review has been criticised for neglecting team‑sport development. New sports for Tokyo – baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, Para‑taekwondo and Para‑badminton – have yet to receive confirmed investment, with £9 m of the £345 m still to be allocated; UK Sport will decide funding after further medal‑potential analysis.

Three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and Ocean View—will be demolished at East Cliff, Bournemouth, to make way for a six‑storey, four‑star hotel and two assisted‑living apartment blocks (a nine‑storey and a seven‑storey building with 122 apartments) on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive; the project, led by East Cliff Project LLP, received 246 supportive letters but was opposed by 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society, who argued the buildings still contributed to the area’s historic character, and by English Heritage, which warned the scale would cause “severe harm” to the conservation area; nevertheless, councillors voted 7‑3 in favour, citing tourism benefits, with Chair David Kelsey noting the old hotels were no longer functional and that the development would preserve tourism while improving housing for older residents.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, a Royal Gibraltar Regiment soldier from Carrickfergus, was found unconscious and later died after being punched and beaten outside a Brecon bar called The Cellar by 24‑year‑old Jake Valle Vallely, who had been on a seven‑hour drinking binge and boasted he was the “hardest man in Brecon”; CCTV captured the assault and Vallely’s subsequent removal of the body and escape, and he is set to be sentenced on 8 December. Boyd was on training at the infantry battle school when the attack occurred, and his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter after the jury learned he had left before the violence began. The incident was condemned by senior investigating officer Det Supt David Guiney as a “despicable act” that shocked Brecon, and a family tribute praised Boyd as an all‑rounder with a promising career cut short, lamenting the void left by Vallely’s murder.

Andrew Travers departed Barnet Council by mutual agreement after a polling error that caused voters to be turned away at all 155 stations because names were missing from the poll list; an independent investigation has been launched. Travers praised the council’s growth programme, while a spokesperson noted his valuable contribution during his three‑and‑a‑half years as chief executive. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily assume the role pending a permanent appointment. On election day, only three of the first 30 voters at one station were registered, prompting the council to apologise, offer emergency proxy votes, and face criticism over the fairness of the result. Travers blamed electoral registration lists, and the council’s review—set to finish by the end of May—will be presented to the General Functions Committee and will examine the suitability of arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum, with discussions underway to appoint the investigation’s lead.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2–1 in a match that saw Josh Gillies score a free‑kick to give the Tynesiders the lead, only for Wrexham to level before half‑time with a set‑piece from Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman then finished the game with a header from Craig Baxter’s cross, securing the win for Gateshead. Manager Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s second‑half improvement, while Wrexham’s Gary Mills lamented the team’s lack of second‑half focus and missed chances. The match featured numerous fouls, free‑kicks and corners, but the decisive moments were the two Gateshead goals.

On 1 October 2014, last updated at 19:45 BST, the Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assessed the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, ranking Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst, with Mozambique following Afghanistan as the second‑worst country; media playback is unsupported on your device.

OneWeb plans to launch a broadband satellite constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially exceeding 2,000, to provide global internet, especially to schools, using a high‑volume, low‑cost manufacturing model pioneered by Airbus. The new assembly lines in Toulouse and soon in Florida use automated trolley robots to produce three satellites per shift for under a million dollars each, a sharp departure from traditional gold‑plated, expensive builds. Airbus and OneWeb have secured $1.7 bn in equity and are negotiating loans to fund the largest rocket campaign yet, with more than 20 Soyuz launches planned to deploy 32–36 satellites per flight, aiming for roughly 300 on‑orbit by early 2021, 600 a year later, and 800 by mid‑decade. The UK‑registered OneWeb works closely with the UK Space Agency, emphasizing economic benefits and regulatory leadership, while also committing to debris mitigation by de‑orbiting satellites within two years and equipping them with recovery hardware. Airbus and OneWeb hope to extend their manufacturing lines to other customers, though bespoke satellites for specialized missions will still be needed.

Mr Swinney criticised the UK government’s recent spending review for putting “unprecedented pressure” on public expenditure north of the border, arguing that cuts imposed since 2010 and the review will leave Scotland’s discretionary budget 12.5 % lower in real terms by 2019‑20, with 4.2 % of that reduction occurring before then and more than £1 bn of cuts still to come; he warned that the chancellor’s austerity approach could have been avoided and that Scotland must now make tough choices, pledging to protect schools, hospitals and police while highlighting past gains such as more police, lower crime, better schools, tuition‑free university and a record health budget. The UK Scotland Office countered that the block grant will be almost £30 bn, giving Scottish ministers £390 m more next year (up to £750 m if underspend is included) and that the current oil price makes this a better deal than the constitutional alternative, urging the Scottish government to focus on new powers rather than grievance. Labour’s Jackie Baillie called for a long‑term budget and a real alternative to austerity, with different tax decisions from the Tories and the SNP.

People with severe disabilities and their carers often feel isolated because standard accessible toilets lack the space and equipment needed for those who require two carers or a hoist; campaigners therefore push for compulsory installation of “Changing Places” toilets—larger, fully equipped facilities—in larger public buildings. Lorna Fillingham has petitioned for mandatory guidelines and submitted evidence to Parliament, while experts like Mike LeSurf estimate over 250,000 people would benefit, and 893 such toilets already exist in the UK. Families such as Alison Beevers’ and Bethan Folen’s experience the psychological toll of inadequate facilities, yet some find temporary solutions through friends’ pop‑up Changing Places. The BS 8300:2009 building standard lists the specifications as a recommendation, not a requirement, leading architects like Vaila Morrison to argue that compulsory rules would clarify expectations; logistical and cost barriers hinder retrofits, so the focus is on new large complexes. Arsenal Football Club’s early adoption of a Changing Places toilet, guided by the Changing Places group, shows that with adaptation and collaboration, venues can meet diverse needs and receive positive public response.

Italian consumer organisations have lodged a formal complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald’s of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, and of preventing them from switching competitors through long contracts and above‑market lease rates, which they say reduces consumer choice and raises prices; McDonald’s counters that it shares risks and rewards with licencees and supports them, while the Service Employees International Union and other European unions back the complaint, arguing the company’s dominant position harms franchisees, consumers and workers; the Commission will study the submission and may investigate, noting that franchisees run 73 % of McDonald’s restaurants in Europe and generated $9.27 bn (£6.40 bn) in franchised revenue worldwide in 2014.

A social‑media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh has drawn worldwide attention to 13‑year‑old Joshua Martin of Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve during an intended appendix operation at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, where doctors discovered a large primary tumour and five smaller growths. The campaign began on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh’s father works, and has since gone viral, with the church’s senior pastor Gary Beattie noting 948 shares and over 79,000 views. A mystery donor paid for a billboard bearing the hashtag at Holywood playing fields, and classmates on Twitter have also rallied around Josh, showing that the support from strangers worldwide continues to grow.

The UK is restructuring its military estate in Wales, with the announced closure of Brecon Barracks—home to troops since 1805 and a historic site that has seen soldiers fight in every conflict since the early 19th century—prompting Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies to denounce the decision as “abhorrent,” launch a petition, and warn that the move could harm the town’s high‑unemployment rates and thriving military‑tourism industry, although he notes the 85 civilian and 90 military staff are not expected to lose jobs and nearby Sennybridge training grounds will remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon said the reorganisation will create a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, while Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire will close in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge will shut in 2025; Labour’s Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the ministry’s right to restructure but cautioned that base closures will create “gnawing uncertainty” for many livelihoods.

The Lords review warns that Britain may need to allow EU‑registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a broader deal, noting that fishing communities voted heavily to leave the EU and risk marginalisation in negotiations. While the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticised as a disaster for Britain, the industry sees Brexit as a chance to regain control of UK waters and become a leading fish‑exporter like Norway. The report highlights that UK fishing is a small part of GDP but must not be sidelined, and that most commercial stocks are shared with EU states, with the UK largely exporting fish to the EU and importing much for domestic consumption. Successful industry will need continued market access, potentially requiring trade‑offs such as EU demands for greater UK water access in exchange for zero‑tariff sales. The report recommends retaining many CFP elements, basing quotas on science, and maintaining international cooperation, warning that leaving the EU could split the CFP framework into four separate regimes. Despite concerns, industry leaders remain optimistic, citing recent EU quota increases for plaice, haddock, and prawns and the prospect of full control over the 200‑mile exclusive economic zone, while the government stresses that Brexit offers an opportunity to review fisheries management for fair access, sustainability, and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of NSA leaks that exposed the agency’s massive surveillance capabilities, including access to chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, social networking data, and millions of Verizon phone records detailing call duration, location, and numbers. The NSA’s Prism program allegedly provided backdoor access to the servers of nine major tech companies—Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube, and Apple—though the companies deny involvement and the exact workings of Prism remain unclear. While NSA officials claim the eavesdropping keeps Americans safe, experts argue its reach may be limited, and privacy laws vary by country, with many companies’ policies allowing data sharing when legally required. Governments justify surveillance as essential for counter‑terrorism, with U.S. officials citing the Patriot and FISA Acts to access foreign cloud data, while the EU and UK express concern and uncertainty about GCHQ’s role. Privacy advocates warn that Prism enables widespread violation of individual privacy, and Snowden himself cited the intrusive nature of such monitoring as his motivation for leaking.

The venture, backed by Tesla, SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and AWS, is funded with $1 billion but will conduct research without financial obligations, aiming to advance digital intelligence for humanity’s benefit. OpenAI’s statement stresses that AI should be an extension of individual wills, broadly and safely distributed, and that only a small portion of the pledge will be spent in the coming years. While Musk and Stephen Hawking warn that AI could pose an existential threat, other experts argue the risk remains remote.

Ben Parkinson, a former L/Bdr who was seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, has recovered enough to carry the Olympic torch on 26 June, walking for nearly half an hour with an assistant and flanked by hundreds of supporters; his brain injury left him speech‑impaired but not his personality or sense of humour, and he now speaks unaided. He spends 12 hours a day in gym and rehab, walks with crutches, raises money for military charities, and serves as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. Since the torch run, his Facebook page has received thousands of friend requests—though limited to 5,000 per personal profile—along with 19,000 hits on a single update and a surge of e‑mail and mail asking to visit torch‑bearing sites; his mother Diane reports the support as phenomenal. Facebook advises that, as a public figure, he could create a page or use a subscription model to manage the influx of contacts. The torch will be carried by 8,000 people over an 8,000‑mile, 70‑day journey to the London Olympic opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011 the U.S. poverty rate held steady at 15 %—46.2 million people—after three years of rises, while real median household income fell 1.5 %. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021 (about £14,300). Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, increased 1.6 % that year, the first annual rise since 1993. The share of Americans without health insurance dropped to 15.7 % from 16.3 %. The preceding year, 2010, saw a record‑high poverty rate of 15.1 %.

The 25‑year‑old cricketer, who joined Lancashire (the Red Rose) from Somerset in 2013 on a contract running to 2019, is a short‑format specialist known for scoring England’s three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46‑ball ton against Pakistan. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised his talent, noting his key role in Lancashire’s T20 Blast final win at Edgbaston and his positive influence in the dressing room. While also playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL, Buttler is set to return to Lancashire for the Friday T20 Blast home match against Durham.

Decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham and Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bidders having until 23 January to register interest; no preservation proposals have been submitted, and those who did register are finalising bids with viewings scheduled for late February and March, though a final decision will not come until spring. The Disposal Services Authority, handling the sale, aims to award at least one frigate to a UK recycler to gauge domestic capacity, while MP Penny Mordaunt stresses the importance of giving UK recyclers a chance and expresses a preference for converting a ship into a reef or diving attraction to generate tourism income, though the Ministry of Defence will consider all options to secure the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22, originally an anti‑submarine platform that evolved into a versatile surface combatant with robust weapons and command facilities for a crew of about 280, has seen similar vessels like HMS Ark Royal sold for scrap (£3 m last year).

Since 1987 Fiji has endured repeated coups—first an indigenous Fijian takeover that briefly installed a constitution favoring Fijians, then a 2000 hostage crisis led by George Speight that held the Indian‑led government captive, and a 2006 military seizure—each deepening racial tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo‑Fijians and damaging the economy, especially tourism, and its international standing. These events led to Fiji’s 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth, but after agreeing to free elections in 2014 the country was readmitted and diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand were restored. The population, mainly on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, was once roughly split between the two groups, but by the mid‑2000s the indigenous Fijians hold a slight majority as many Indo‑Fijians fled; intermixing remains minimal and segregation is widespread, with only small Chinese and Rotuman minorities. Fiji’s economy, heavily reliant on sugar and tourism, also includes mining of gold, silver and limestone, a robust services sector and some light manufacturing, yet persistent trade and budget deficits keep it among the world’s largest per‑capita aid recipients.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad told the BBC that Syria is “doing its best” to meet the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, though it missed Wednesday’s deadline to hand over the entire stockpile; he said two shipments en route to Latakia were attacked, with the second intercepted by fire from “terrorist groups.” He condemned U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry’s criticism of barrel‑bomb attacks in Aleppo, citing reports that 246 people, including 73 children, were killed in the last five days and that 14 were killed in Masaken Hanano, while insisting the government never bombarded civilians and accusing the U.S. of supporting terrorists. The Syrian government denied that rebels seized Aleppo’s central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and rebel groups claim the Islamic Front freed hundreds of detainees and now controls the prison, which holds at least 3,000 inmates in dire conditions. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, of which only 30 tonnes (4 %) have left the country; the U.S. and Russia urge completion of the transfer to the coast by 1 March and destruction by end‑June, while the OPCW notes security concerns have slowed the process, and Mekdad reiterates Syria’s commitment to its obligations under the OPCW and UN Security Council.

Mukherjee’s *The Lives Of Others* is the 5/2 favourite to win the 46th Booker Prize, the first year the award is open to all English‑language authors regardless of nationality; the winner will be announced at London’s Guildhall. The shortlist features British writer Howard Jacobson (nominated for *J*), Ali Smith (*How To Be Both*), American Joshua Ferris (*To Rise Again at a Decent Hour*), American Karen Joy Fowler (*We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves*), and Australian Richard Flanagan (*The Narrow Road to the Deep North*). Jacobson’s *J* is seen as the strongest book, though some fear a repeat win, while Fowler’s novel is the best‑seller with over 55,000 copies sold. Sales spiked after the shortlist announcement, with Mukherjee’s book rising from 97 to 507 copies sold. Professor David Brauner criticised the list as weak and debated whether the prize should reward literary merit or readability. The judging panel, chaired by AC Grayling, includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven and Erica Wagner; shortlisted authors receive £2,500 and a bound edition. The ceremony, presented by the Duchess of Cornwall, will be broadcast on BBC News and BBC Arts.

PJS is appealing a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his name appearing in the media in England and Wales, with the Supreme Court now set to decide whether to grant an appeal and whether the ban should be allowed or dismissed; an interim injunction remains in force until the next hearing. The Court of Appeal had given PJS until 10:00 BST on Tuesday to apply to the Supreme Court and ordered no publication that could disclose his identity before 13:00 BST on Wednesday. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish allegations of PJS’s extramarital affairs, which he claims violate his privacy; a Monday judgment confirmed that PJS had occasional sexual encounters with AB starting in 2009, a three‑way with AB’s partner CD in 2011, and that the story was already circulating online and on Twitter. A High Court judge initially refused an injunction, but PJS’s appeal won a ruling that prevented his identification in England and Wales; News Group Newspapers requested the ban be lifted, arguing the story had been published elsewhere, but the Court of Appeal ruled that a permanent injunction was unlikely because the allegations were now so widespread that confidentiality had probably been lost.

Fosse Park, which opened in 1989 and was purchased in August for £345.5 million, is now the focus of redevelopment plans aimed at improving parking, traffic congestion and the appearance of its units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White said the new owners have met with the council to resolve potential planning issues and view the site as a gateway into the city that could offer a better view, noting the current prevalence of shed backs. Crown Estates investment director Paul Clarke added that the priority is to tackle parking and congestion, refresh the tired common areas, and enhance facilities so the location can reach its full potential.

The live‑action remake of *Beauty and the Beast* has become the centre of a controversy in Malaysia after a “gay moment” was discovered in the film. Although the movie was slated for a Thursday release, Disney announced a delay for a “review” of its content, while the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) has approved the film with a minor edit to the gay scene and granted it a P13 parental‑guidance classification. Homosexual activity is illegal in the Muslim‑majority country, yet the tourism minister dismissed a ban as “ridiculous.” The LPF chairman clarified that approval only concerns content, not screening dates or locations, and local cinema chains are offering refunds to advance ticket holders. Director Bill Condon has spoken about the scene involving LeFou’s conflicted feelings for Gaston, and the decision to review the film has drawn criticism from netizens who called the move “stupid and laughable.”

Landlords in Southampton who let to more than three unrelated tenants must obtain an HMO licence, yet many avoid the £1,000 fee despite a potential £20,000 fine, with the council estimating 1,500 unlicensed HMOs; Shelter adviser Nadeem Khan reports tenants fear eviction and poor conditions, citing a shortage of affordable homes and receiving five to six calls daily; nationally, mandatory licensing applies to houses three storeys or taller with five or more unrelated occupants, while in Southampton the licences cover areas such as Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1, 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett (Designation 2, 2015); the council notes most landlords cooperate but a small minority resist, and it has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are trying to avoid a second election, with Martin offering to facilitate a minority government but refusing to back a full programme. A key dispute is over water charges, with Fianna Fáil demanding their immediate removal while Fine Gael sees a role for them; a commission on the future of Irish Water is being considered. After the election, Fine Gael held 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and Labour 7, leaving no party with a majority and TDs still unable to elect a Taoiseach.

The Sorrento, bound for Valencia, caught fire on a car deck about 27 km from Mallorca and quickly lost control; passengers were evacuated into lifeboats and rescued by nearby vessels, including the ferry Puglia, with all evacuees heading to Palma de Mallorca where they were expected to arrive in a few hours. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and were air‑lifted to hospital; psychologists were dispatched to the port for counselling. The Balearic Islands port authority warned that the Sorrento might sink, and the ship had sent distress signals at 13:50 local time; initially the captain did not think evacuation was needed, but the fire’s intensity forced a full abandonment.

The Electoral Commission warned that 38 MPs had flagged people, including students, who claimed to have voted twice, a criminal offence, and urged better linking of the 381 separate council‑run electoral registers to spot duplicates. Labour’s Cat Smith cautioned against making it harder for young voters to register, noting that the 8 June election saw a record 46.8 million registered (up 500 000 from 2015) and a 68.7 % turnout, the highest since 1997, driven by a surge of 2.9 million applications after the snap poll call and before the 22 May deadline. Many constituencies, especially those with large student populations, saw electorates rise over 10 %. However, the lack of a shared database between the online registration service and local registers means duplicate applications are common—estimated at 30–70 % in some areas—causing administrative and financial strain. The watchdog called for clearer registration guidance, a verification function used in Australia, New Zealand and Ireland, and for people registered in two seats to pre‑select which one they will vote in. While some dual registration is lawful for local elections, voting twice in a general election remains an offence punishable by an unlimited fine, and the report urged police to investigate suspected cases.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40‑year‑old former Nebraska star who played for the Rams, Dolphins and 49ers, was found dead by suicide early Wednesday while serving a 30‑plus‑year prison sentence. After a career plagued by on‑and‑off‑field trouble, he had been convicted of assault for driving into a group of teenagers and for assaulting a former girlfriend, and was accused of killing his former cellmate. A judge on Tuesday determined there was enough evidence to charge him with the murder of Damion Soward, 37, though the circumstances of his death remain unclear. Tom Osborne, Phillips’ former Nebraska coach, described him as intelligent with good qualities but plagued by anger and demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classed as a soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at a Chester ceremony celebrating the Mercian Regiment’s eight‑year anniversary, an honour presented by Brigadier Andrew Williams for “good behaviour”; he is the 30th mascot ram in a line that traces back to the Indian Mutiny of the mid‑19th century, with the original Private Derby acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and later adopted as the Mercian Regiment’s mascot when it formed in 2007. Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014, holds an army number, receives payment for his rations, and takes holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate, while also having switched on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool’s 4‑3 Europa League victory over Borussia Dortmund at Anfield, sealed by Dejan Lovren’s injury‑time header, was a dramatic showcase of Klopp’s “turn doubters into believers” philosophy, echoing the 2005 Istanbul triumph; the match featured early Dortmund goals from Mkhitaryan and Aubameyang, a 2‑0 deficit for Liverpool, and a comeback highlighted by Origi, Coutinho, Sakho and Lovren, while the stadium’s electric atmosphere—complete with a Hillsborough minute, a prolonged “You’ll Never Walk Alone” and a clash of club colours—underscored the emotional stakes, and the win positions Liverpool in the Europa League semi‑finals and keeps the Champions League return in sight, even as Klopp notes defensive frailties that will be addressed in the summer.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, where UK minister Mr Davis announced that the government would keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland informed and proposed monthly meetings to create a two‑way information flow, allowing devolved administrations to voice their views as the UK prepares talks with Brussels and implements the decision to leave the EU. He described the meeting as constructive and said the UK would work positively with the devolved governments. In contrast, Mr Russell demanded greater transparency, noting that more than four months after the referendum the UK had not clarified its strategic intentions, especially regarding whether it would remain in the single market or customs union—a decision he said is essential for Scotland’s economic prosperity. He also warned that the UK’s High Court ruling on Article 50 could be overturned on appeal to the Supreme Court, a move the Scottish government intends to oppose, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe expected to be heard in the case.

Veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr examines Daisy, one of 13 cloned sheep on the University of Nottingham’s Sutton Bonington farm, including four clones (Debbie, Denise, Diane, Daisy) derived from the same adult ewe that produced Dolly, the first cloned mammal. These clones are being rigorously tested for signs of age‑related disease—particularly osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes—through joint manipulation, X‑rays, and full‑body fMRI scans, as researchers like Prof Kevin Sinclair investigate whether the cloning process transfers “age‑memory” that could cause premature aging. Dolly herself died at 6½ years from a virus‑induced lung lesion and osteoarthritis, raising questions about whether such conditions are more common in clones. The ongoing study, which will publish results next week, finds the nine‑to‑ten‑year‑old clones appear healthy, but the findings could shape the future of cloning science.

Trainer John Gosden’s unbeaten 4‑7 favourite won after walking the course, beating runner‑up Vintage Folly by a length and three‑quarters and will head to Chantilly rather than the Epsom Oaks, where his stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders; Tasleet (14‑1) won the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas, with Jim Crowley’s mount winning comfortably ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas; Shutter Speed, who finished third behind Enable at Newbury, secured a fifth Musidora win for Gosden and jockey Michael Dettori, who praised her class on soft ground and noted she will target France’s Oaks over a mile‑and‑a‑quarter while Gosden relies on Enable and Coronet for the longer Epsom Oaks; Gosden remains concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday’s Dante Stakes, planning to walk the course again before deciding on a Derby trial, and the 16‑day gap between the Dante and the Derby may mean Cracksman is not entered in the demanding Dante.

The pound slipped against the dollar and euro, briefly recovered mid‑afternoon, then fell again, ending 0.2 % lower at $1.4226, 0.6 % lower at €1.2605 and 1 % weaker against the yen; the volatility index spiked to 2008‑era levels as investors reacted to falling Remain‑vote probabilities and global economic worries. With ten days to the referendum, polls and Betfair odds now favor Leave, prompting analysts to warn that the pound could swing further and volatility could rise; hedge funds are shorting sterling and markets are on “Brexit alert.” Asian stocks fell (Nikkei 3.5 %, Hong Kong 2.5 %) and the FTSE 100 slipped 1.1 % to 6,044.9, Lloyds Banking Group dropping 4.2 %. Nigel Farage claimed sterling has been strengthening since March and that a weaker pound benefits exporters, a view supported by a narrowed UK trade deficit in April driven by a jump in exports.

The Iron sit sixth in the National League, just one point and one place shy of the play‑off spots. Cowley reflected on a recent match against Barrow, noting the difficulty of conceding early after a long journey, while Barrow extended their unbeaten run to nine games and Braintree’s losing streak grew to three. Despite the challenges, Cowley praised the team’s progress as “remarkable,” emphasizing that as a part‑time side the current campaign is their toughest yet, but they intend to embrace and enjoy the challenge and see where it leads.

The passage explains that from April 2015, planning decisions in Northern Ireland will shift from the Planning Service to local councils, giving elected politicians direct control over most development approvals and potentially democratising the process. Proponents like Michael Corr see this as an opportunity for councils to shape community and development plans, while critics warn of a risk of discrimination and favoritism reminiscent of the 1960s civil‑rights era, citing Friends of the Earth’s concerns about transparency, close ties between developers and parties, and the need for strict conduct codes. The debate also touches on political donations, with some politicians fearing donor security issues and others arguing that the £7,500 declaration limit is largely irrelevant, leaving the decision to the Northern Ireland Secretary to regulate disclosure.

A one‑year‑old cat named Teenie was shot twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, requiring amputation of the leg, but survived after being found injured by owner Sarah Nisbett in NiddryView, Winchburgh on 14 March and taken to the Scottish SPCA. The owner says the pellet was powerful enough to pierce the leg and that Teenie is now relearning to walk, while she worries about the safety of children in the housing estate. The incident has prompted the Scottish SPCA to call for the urgent implementation of an air‑gun licensing scheme, echoing a 2023 government consultation that saw 87 % of respondents oppose the plan, describing it as “draconian.” The SPCA urges anyone with information to contact them and stresses that licensing would help trace irresponsible air‑gun use.

The Tablets for Schools‑commissioned study of 671 schools found no clear evidence that tablet use improves academic attainment, though head teachers report positive effects such as motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement; tablets are now used in 68 % of primary and 69 % of secondary schools, with 9 % of schools providing one per pupil, and usage is highest in academies, with a projected rise from 430 000 to 900 000 devices between 2014 and 2016 and 45 % of non‑using schools likely to adopt them soon. A separate National Literacy Trust and Pearson study noted touch‑screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read, with poorer households more likely to read on screens than print. Tablet use has become part of everyday life, with a quarter of secondary pupils in fully equipped schools describing themselves as internet “addicts” and two‑thirds taking devices to bed for social media or videos; Ofcom reports about 70 % of 5‑15‑year‑olds have a tablet at home. Simon Mason of Honywood Community School champions tablets, arguing they empower students, reflect the digital reality of their lives and future work, and are preferable to laptops for their portability and immediacy.

The Museum of Liverpool’s “Growing Up in the City” exhibition displays 25 evocative photographs that trace the lives of children in the city from the 1880s to the 1990s, offering both nostalgic snapshots and a social history of Liverpool’s streets. Highlights include an 1887 portrait of the Rollo children at a fancy‑dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle, and a circa‑1900 image of a nervous young maid working for a well‑to‑do family. Curator Kay Jones sifted through hundreds of images from the National Museums Liverpool collection to select those that best illustrate the joys and hardships of childhood, including the reality of child labour. The exhibition runs at the museum until 25 September.

Centre‑back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his Barrow contract to join a National League rival, a move that could see him face his former club on 18 February; the ex‑Aldershot and Exeter player, who has also played in Italy, is expected to feature in the upcoming match. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams and has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, with his transfer pending international clearance. Nicholson praised Myles for his stature, voice and leadership despite limited appearances, and described Ruairi as a hungry, raw young talent. The Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The new Bolivian law, approved by Congress and signed by Vice‑President Alvaro Garcia Linera while President Evo Morales was abroad, allows 12‑year‑olds to work with parental consent and imposes a 30‑year prison sentence for child homicide, reflecting the country’s need to address extreme poverty and child labor. Over 500,000 children already work in informal jobs such as shoe cleaning, street vending, mining and agriculture, and the socialist government hopes the legislation will curb such exploitation. While the law aligns with Bolivia’s realities, it diverges from international norms that prohibit child labor under 15 (though a 14‑year minimum is permitted for developing nations), prompting the ILO to review whether the new law breaches global regulations.

A 50‑year‑old actress, O'Donnell, experienced a “widow maker” heart attack after noticing sudden nausea, chest ache, and feverish symptoms while helping a woman in her Nyack village home; she searched online for women’s heart attack signs, took aspirin, and the next day saw a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a 99 % blocked artery. She wrote about the episode on her blog, including a poem titled “my heart attack,” and warned readers to recognize symptoms and call 911, noting she had not done so herself. O'Donnell, known for roles in *Drop Dead Diva*, *Will and Grace*, and *Nip/Tuck*, also hosted *The Rosie Show* on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide‑Wellington, a 16‑year‑old from Harrow, was invited to a party on Belvedere Way, Kenton, where a fight with youths denied entry occurred. He was later stabbed in an alleyway around 00:30 GMT and died about an hour later. Police said he was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. A 21‑year‑old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two other youths aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on the same charge and bailed until mid‑December; a 14‑year‑old is being held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon. Det. Chief Insp. Chris Jones is seeking witnesses who were near the alleyway.

Denmark has restructured cancer diagnosis by introducing a three‑route system to address long waiting times and poor survival statistics revealed over 15 years ago, especially for cases with vague or non‑obvious symptoms; the routes include fast‑track pathways for alarm symptoms with strict time targets, diagnosis centres that quickly test patients whose GP cannot diagnose, and “yes‑no” centres for minor symptoms that rarely indicate cancer but can still uncover serious disease; a study of 30,000 cases found over 25 % fell into the ambiguous group, and the new model has not overloaded the system but improved organisation and survival rates, prompting Wales to consider similar reforms and earning praise from Dr Tom Crosby for breaking down barriers between GPs and specialists.

The UK government’s decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) has led to Powys Council winning a competitive bid to take over its estate‑agent regulatory role, receiving £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest agents and to enforce breaches of the Estate Agents Act. Complaints will still be directed to local authority trading standards, which will prosecute offenders but refer cases to Powys when the Act is breached. James Munro, who will head the new Powys team, hopes the role will demonstrate the council’s capacity for future contracts and external work, and he discussed the responsibilities on Radio Wales’ Good Morning Wales with Peter Johnson.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to expand the 1.3‑million‑strong workforce after advisers noted that additional tasks could be handled with more training, a view supported by a Nuffield Trust review that highlighted nurses stepping in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. Unions, however, warned that this should not become a quick fix for chronic shortages, citing documented gaps in junior doctor rotas and GP workloads. The Trust’s report, which identified pilot projects and stressed the shift toward managing long‑term conditions rather than curative care, argued that doctors make up only about one in ten staff and that more support staff are needed, but that sufficient funding must be allocated. Report author Candace Imison saw “huge opportunities” for improving patient care and staff roles, while NHS Employers chief Danny Mortimer said the challenge is to implement the recommendations. Dr Mark Porter of the BMA cautioned that expanding the support workforce should not compromise quality doctor training, and Unison’s Christina McAnea noted that funding constraints often leave training courses unaffordable, warning that a support workforce should not be seen as a cheap, short‑term solution.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath at 03:00 GMT after a crash, lifting the A36 closure at 14:00 GMT; the incident caused rush‑hour delays for commuters and bus services. Investigations are underway. First bus operator said some services had returned to normal but full restoration would take a few hours, with managing director James Freeman expressing hope for full service by the evening commute and thanking the public and staff for their support.

NRW has estimated that the proposed £1.3 bn Swansea tidal lagoon would cause 21 % of salmon and 25 % of sea trout to die each year, a figure TLP disputes as lacking a clear scientific basis and claims the regulator withheld its methodology; TLP’s own modelling suggests a worst‑case impact of only 2 % of all fish species. The lagoon is being promoted as a test bed for larger, cost‑effective projects along the coast, while UK ministers review its viability and Wales’ Environment Secretary remains supportive but seeks clarity on the UK government’s stance. NRW maintains that its estimates are based on the best available evidence, extensive data sharing with the developer, and independent expert assessment.

Northern Ireland’s DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new industry‑led agri‑food marketing body, to be developed by the Agri‑Food Strategy Board (AFSB), citing the sector’s importance of nearly 100,000 jobs and its potential for export‑led growth. Foster likened the body to Scotland’s successful Food and Drink model, emphasizing its role in providing strategic leadership for both government and private marketing activities. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the initiative as a positive step for the sector but noted that it could affect the work of other organisations, including her department, and expressed a desire to discuss the plans with the AFSB.
