On Saturday afternoon the Woodland Trust invited the public to plant thousands of native trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley as part of a four‑year, UK‑wide initiative to plant “millions” of trees in memory of those who died in WW1, with the pledge “We will stand for those who fell.” The Brackfield project aims to plant 40,000 trees to honour the estimated 40,000 Irish people who lost their lives, and will feature wildflower carpets and poppies to create a wildlife‑friendly, reflective space; volunteers are supplied with saplings and advised to wear sturdy footwear, and the site—about seven miles from Derry on the Glenshane Road—has limited parking. The director, Patrick Cregg, urged as many people as possible to join, noting the trees will stand for generations as a living tribute to Irish soldiers, families and loved ones.

Hilary won Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the start of Harrogate’s annual crime writing festival, with Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham, a judge, calling the book “an emotionally exhausting and powerful story” and noting it was “so finely written and tightly written.” The award ceremony also honoured US author Sara Paretsky with an outstanding contribution award for her 23‑year career as the creator of detective VI Warshawski, a pioneering female private investigator whose character was portrayed by Kathleen Turner in a 1991 film and adapted for BBC Radio 4; Paretsky’s work, which changed perceptions of female crime writers, led her to found Sisters In Crime. Festival chair Ann Cleeves praised the strong shortlist, highlighting Hilary’s thriller *Someone Else’s Skin*—a domestic‑violence and honour‑crime narrative featuring Detective Inspector Marnie Rome—as atmospheric, well‑plotted, and tightly written.

Santner, 24, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, prompting director Steve Rhodes to lament the loss of Mitch, whose injury last summer had been a major setback for the county’s qualification hopes; Santner, a left‑arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Tests in 2015, plans to rejoin the team after the June ICC Trophy in England and hopes to make up for lost time with both bat and ball, while in August Worcestershire secured Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed in 2008 when a speeding car struck him on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev while he tried to hail a taxi; the coroner at Exeter County Hall, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded an unlawful‑killing verdict, citing overwhelming circumstantial evidence that the death was deliberate. Pring’s wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), 19 years his junior, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove and was later found to have sold his Range Rover, liquidated flat contents, moved funds from his bank account, and claimed the first £200,000 of his estate, while computer records revealed an affair with a Ukrainian man. Family members and close friend Peter Clifford asserted that the couple’s online‑met, quickly married relationship and Ziuzina’s false teacher claim (she was actually a lap dancer) pointed to a staged hit‑and‑run to inherit his wealth. Ukrainian police initially closed the case but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry; Det Con Jonathan Watts reported the vehicle had no lights, was speeding at 75 mph, and witnesses described the killing as deliberate. Despite attempts, Ziuzina did not attend the inquest and has made only limited statements to Ukrainian authorities, leaving the case still active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns of Litherland, Merseyside, says her son Charlie, who has been ill since age three and suffered a third relapse in April, urgently needs a second T‑Cell therapy at Seattle Children’s Hospital after a failed transplant in the UK. The family received an email confirming that an anonymous donor has paid for the treatment, leaving them “ecstatic” and “overwhelmed.” With financial clearance secured, the treatment is set to begin as soon as possible, with the exact date expected next week.

Third‑party software was used to steal intimate photos from iCloud, prompting Apple to add a two‑step verification step that requires a four‑digit code sent to a trusted phone or via Find My iPhone after a user logs in from a new device; if the code is not entered, access is denied and purchases are blocked, though a 14‑character recovery key can restore access if the trusted device is lost. Previously, this two‑step protection did not apply to iCloud backups, allowing attackers to download backups with Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker, a tool whose Moscow‑based owner, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged that Apple’s changes now prevent his program from listing devices or backups and that Apple now notifies users when a backup starts. Katalov still worries about the recovery key’s memorability and security, while security expert Alan Woodward argues that two‑factor authentication should be the default for Apple, Microsoft, and Google. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage two‑factor authentication and stronger passwords, and Tim Cook has said the company has a responsibility to raise user awareness beyond engineering solutions.

Dan Groves said the finer details of a potential deal that could see former reality‑TV star Wright acquire a 20% stake in Billericay Town are still pending, while The Sun reports Wright will become a club director. The club sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points shy of the play‑off places, and has recently been taken over by multi‑millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has pledged to invest £10,000 a week. Wright, a 30‑year‑old who finished runner‑up on *I’m A Celebrity* in 2011 and has played for non‑league sides such as Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds, joins a squad that also signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence on the treatment of workers at Sports Direct after a BBC investigation into the Derbyshire warehouse’s practices. A letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, chair of the BIS select committee, gives Ashley until 21 March to respond and notes that the committee will review low‑paid workers and minimum wage enforcement. The committee has offered several dates for a public meeting at the company’s Shirebrook base, but Ashley has not accepted any; if he fails to agree, the committee may pursue further action, including a contempt complaint in the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not yet commented, though it has pledged to review worker rights under Ashley’s oversight, who also owns Newcastle United Football Club.

The unfinished report “Putin. War,” completed by colleagues of the murdered opposition politician and led by Ilya Yashin, compiles media‑reported facts from the 2014 Crimea annexation and the eastern Ukraine conflict to argue that President Vladimir Putin is waging war for his own ends; it cites evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in Donetsk and Luhansk, that volunteers admit they were directed by Russian generals, and that Russian spending on the war is about 53 bn roubles (≈$1 bn). Yashin notes that volunteers can earn $2,000–$3,000 a month, while a veteran claims they enlist for pay. The dossier, which documents unit names, numbers and weapon photos, was begun by Boris Nemtsov after learning relatives of dead Russian soldiers had not received promised compensation; those relatives have remained silent since his assassination. Yashin says the opposition will seek donations to expand the initial 2,000‑copy print run, but publishers fear backlash and the public’s appetite for the facts remains uncertain. The report accuses Putin of masterminding the war to boost his popularity, a claim that mirrors earlier Nemtsov works that, despite critical acclaim, failed to spark mass protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34‑year‑old from Wath‑upon‑Dearne, Rotherham, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday; a post‑mortem determined he died from head injuries. A 41‑year‑old man and a 23‑year‑old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones complained that he had not seen the Article 50 letter before its publication, arguing that devolved administrations were excluded from its drafting and treated with disrespect, while Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that the Prime Minister had visited Wales multiple times and that the UK government was acting in the interests of the whole country, including Wales. Mrs May’s letter mentioned Wales and promised a consultation on which powers should remain in Westminster versus devolved to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, with an expectation of increased decision‑making for the devolved administrations. Questions remain about which specific powers—such as farming or economic aid—would be devolved and whether accompanying funding would follow, with Jones fearing a lack of money after 2020 and Labour pledging to keep EU‑level regional aid. Some Whitehall officials view EU spending in Wales as an argument for transferring powers to Westminster, though this seems politically unlikely; a forthcoming white paper on the Great Repeal Bill may clarify the process, but the exact powers to be devolved remain unclear.

On Friday night in Newry’s Nursery Drive and Parkhead area, an incident left two cars damaged as police were attacked while carrying out duties; Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed being appalled by the mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the community, and a PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post noted the assault and urged parents to be aware of where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was ousted last year after employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds; a San Francisco court filing from the board states he will not return, and his lawyer Keith Fink claims the statements are false, alleging the company invaded Charney’s privacy and tried to extort him. The filing also documents illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, which the board says were in response to Charney’s defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. Company papers assert that Charney repeatedly violated its sexual‑harassment and anti‑discrimination policy, and the board warns that hiring him would pose too great a risk to the company and shareholders. Earlier this month, American Apparel obtained a restraining order preventing Charney from making negative press statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app will stream Britain’s home game against Greece at the Copper Box, a rematch of the 92‑64 loss in Patras earlier this month, with three Greek players absent giving GB a chance for revenge. Guard Teddy Okereafor, a Stratford native, praised the venue and said the match is “the level we need to be playing at” to prepare for EuroBasket 2017, noting that several players will debut in London. The game, scheduled for 17:30‑19:30 BST, is Britain’s only home fixture before the tournament, which kicks off in September with a qualifying group in Istanbul; after the match, Coach Joe Prunty’s squad will head to a four‑team warm‑up tournament in Poland.

The narrator recounts their experience covering Apple’s first iPhone launch, including a brief interview with marketing chief Phil Schiller who allowed them to preview the device for a BBC news segment, which drew criticism for giving the product undue prominence. They defended the coverage by noting the iPhone’s potential to change everyday life, likening it to the Model T Ford’s impact, and later reflected that the comparison was justified as smartphones have indeed transformed society. The author contrasts early digital SLR photography of Steve Jobs with a 2017 iPhone photo, illustrating how the iPhone revolutionized mobile photography and sharing. They acknowledge that phones already existed before 2007 but credit Jobs with creating an attractive interface that broadened phone use beyond calls and texts, and conclude by noting that companies like Amazon and Google are now advancing AI-driven products, while the iPhone’s launch in January 2007 marked the beginning of the mobile‑connected era.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, tests have confirmed that a toxic substance—identified as antifreeze—has been ingested by all the cats near Victor Avenue, leading to the deaths of several animals, including a seven‑month‑old cat named Meereen who died after showing symptoms of poisoning. The RSPCA is unsure whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and has warned residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially antifreeze, to prevent further incidents.

Greece’s streets are calm despite Syriza’s willingness to adopt further austerity and liberalisation measures demanded by creditors, even as Athens airport anticipates 25 million visitors this year, up from 21 million, reflecting a surge in tourism. The lack of protests over announced VAT hikes, pension cuts, farm‑subsidy reductions, privatisations and opening of professions to competition is attributed to an impending disclosure of how much Alexis Tsipras has conceded to secure an €86 bn credit line in the country’s third bailout. The government’s shift to “TINA” (there is no alternative) after July’s bank closures and economic collapse has left Greece under both fiscal and monetary austerity, with banks unable to lend and businesses hesitant to borrow, threatening a post‑Christmas slump. Tsipras remains popular but faces pressure to deliver a path to recovery; many argue creditors should ease Greece’s debt burden by a third to a half, and that Brussels—especially Berlin—must avoid triumphalism and consider debt forgiveness to make the new bailout sustainable.

Ross Kemp will return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for a brief stint in Barbara’s final episodes, a storyline that reunites the Mitchell brothers with their mother, who will die from cancer after a surprise return to Albert Square. Kemp, who originally played Grant from 1990‑1999 and again in 2005‑2006, said he could not refuse the role and is eager to bring the family together for a “classic” episode. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell‑Collins highlighted the opportunity to showcase the iconic brothers facing the loss of their mother, underscoring Grant’s status as an EastEnders legend.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24‑year‑old Alice Ruggles in October, a crime that was confirmed when two Northumbria Police officers knocked on her parents’ door; Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles immediately recognised Dhillon as the perpetrator. At the Newcastle Crown Court trial it emerged that Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice and had stalked her, while Hills expressed deep guilt for reassuring her daughter that the police would protect her and for dismissing her daughter Emma’s concerns that Dhillon might kill her. The Ruggles family established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking dangers and to honour Alice’s vibrant, cheeky personality. Dhillon denied the murder charge but was convicted and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

EDF’s board approved an £18 bn investment in the Hinkley Point C nuclear plant, with contracts slated for Friday, but Business Secretary Greg Clark said the government would “consider carefully” before backing the project, prompting EDF chief Vincent de Rivaz to cancel a site visit. Critics highlight environmental damage, rising costs and the fact that a third of the funding comes from Chinese investors, raising concerns about foreign control. The government’s sudden review, launched hours after the board vote, has stalled the post‑Brexit investment push and sparked debate over possible policy shifts. Industry voices such as Tom Greatrex and Claire Jacobson urge a swift decision to avoid supply risks and higher costs, while Greenpeace warns the plant offers poor value and calls for more renewable investment. Hinkley Point C is expected to supply 7 % of UK electricity; EDF frames it as a joint French‑British asset that will boost employment, yet the company’s financial strain—requiring a €4 bn share issue and recent board resignations—remains a concern. The project’s history includes a 2006 government proposal, 2013 construction approval, a 2013 price guarantee, a 2015 investment deal with China’s CGN, and a 2016 board approval followed by a UK government postponement until autumn.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales now requires the applicant to list the name of any person their spouse has committed adultery with, a change that family lawyers warn adds conflict and complexity; the Ministry of Justice stresses there is no obligation to name a third party, yet the form’s wording may pressure users to do so. Lawyers Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin note that most people ignore the small print and that naming a co‑respondent makes them part of the case, obligating them to receive paperwork and potentially delaying proceedings if they do not respond. In 2015, of just over 100,000 divorces granted, 12,148 were for adultery and 46,815 for unreasonable behaviour, and while 80 % of Hamblin’s clients want the new partner involved, judges view such moves unfavourably, seeing them as a bad light on the petitioner. The form still requires proof that the marriage has broken down, with the new wording clarifying that naming a third party is optional but relevant to the proceedings.

Ministers are criticised for prioritising environmental goals over timber production, even as Britain remains the world’s third‑largest wood importer and Welsh commercial forestry—worth over £450 m a year—faces a loss of 16,000 ha since 2001 that must be replanted. Half of Wales’s woodland is managed by Natural Resources Wales and the rest by private firms, yet the industry clashes with environmental policy that favours native broadleaf species and public access, while conservationists argue commercial forests harm wildlife. Transporting timber through rural areas also creates local conflicts. The Welsh government seeks a balance, promoting schemes such as Glastir and the Woodlands for Wales strategy to enhance landscapes, deliver community benefits, support industry and improve the environment. Confor’s Martin Bishop notes the current system is bureaucratic, with only 90 ha planted last year against a target of 20,000 ha, and argues that a robust timber market could double or treble mill production if supply were adequate.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge; emergency crews arrived at Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40 and transported him to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Russian Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to surviving Arctic Convoy veterans, including 91‑year‑old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, after the UK Foreign Office lifted its earlier ban on foreign medals for actions more than five years old; the ceremony, held in 2013 with President Vladimir Putin presenting the first medals, followed the Russian Embassy’s 2012 intent to honour the convoys that supplied the Soviet Union during World II, a perilous route that claimed 120 vessels and thousands of Allied seamen and was deemed by Winston Churchill the “worst journey on earth”; the UK had created its own Arctic Star in 2012 to recognise the veterans, but campaigners argued they should also receive the Russian accolade, which the Russian Embassy and Minister‑Councillor Alexander Kramarenko described as a material expression of wartime alliance and gratitude.

HM Inspectorate of Probation reported that many offenders are delayed in starting community payback work and are often let off if they fail to attend, citing an example where an offender completed only 16 hours in 17 months; the Ministry of Justice said it is acting on the report’s 15 recommendations. Community payback can require 40‑300 hours for offences such as shoplifting, theft, drug offences or criminal damage, and in 2014 some 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work such as garden maintenance, decorating or litter‑picking. Inspectors examined 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, noting organisational difficulties in getting offenders—many with drink or drug problems—to work on time, and that sanctions could lead to prison while non‑attendance meant the sentence was unenforced. While some high‑quality work and skill gains were praised, the report criticised the perception of unpaid work as mere punishment and urged community rehabilitation companies to reduce turn‑aways and tailor objectives to offenders’ circumstances, with the chief inspector calling for urgent remedial action; the Ministry of Justice pledged to implement the recommendations to improve rehabilitation and ensure offenders attend on time.

The paper’s front‑page headline branded the comedian a “hypocrite” for campaigning for economic and political revolution while living in a luxury London home, a criticism that has been leveled at him repeatedly. Viewers of his vlogs see his spacious, airy residence, and when a Channel 4 reporter asked him about his rent during a visit to Downing Street, Brand called the journalist “snide” and walked off. Newsbeat reached out to confirm whether he would sue The Sun and Rupert Murdoch, but he did not respond, instead tweeting about the Sun’s accusations under the hashtag #TheSunLogic. In past interviews he has acknowledged the charge, noting that his wealth and fame do not absolve him of the need for personal and systemic change, that sharing wealth alone is insufficient, and that he sees inequality as a real problem that must be addressed.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist turned entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome project by turning it into a competitive race, earning both acclaim for speeding the mapping and criticism for his disregard of scientific conventions such as open data; after the human genome’s publication he shifted focus to creating the first synthetic organism, Synthia, which he announced in *Science*. Born in 1946, Venter’s early life surfing and service as an orderly in Vietnam instilled a sense of urgency that drove his research career, leading him from NIH work in the 1980s to founding the Institute for Genomic Research in 1992 and, in 1995, publishing the first complete genome of *Haemophilus influenzae*. In 1998 he launched Celera Genomics to finish the human genome in three years, a goal achieved in 2001 alongside the public effort. With the wealth and independence gained, he founded the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006 to pursue synthetic biology and also embarked on a marine genomic treasure hunt aboard his yacht Sorcerer II, sequencing diverse ocean microbes; he envisions synthetic microbes sparking an industrial revolution that could reduce oil dependence and mitigate climate change.

Researchers found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried foods at school that they had not tried at home, and half of parents reported that their children asked for school‑served foods to be cooked at home. A survey of about 1,000 parents (628 of whom had children who ate school lunches) revealed that the most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were least popular. The study, commissioned by England’s School Food Trust after a Mumsnet survey suggested parents gave packed lunches because children were fussy, highlighted that school meals can encourage children to try new foods and increase dietary variety, and noted that school meals must meet strict nutritional guidelines. Roughly 40 % of primary school children in England now eat school lunches—slightly more than in secondary schools—and about 46 % of Scottish children do so. The online survey was conducted between 26 February and 5 March among parents of children aged 4‑17.

Morata, 23, is a Spanish striker who played for Spain at Euro 2016 and joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, with a buy‑back option for Real worth up to €30 million. He had previously been linked to Arsenal and Chelsea, scored three goals for Spain in France, netted 27 goals in two years for Juventus, and helped the club win two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia trophies. Morata appeared in back‑to‑back Champions League finals, coming on as a substitute in Real’s 2014 win and scoring in Juventus’ 3‑1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. Standing 6 ft 3 in, he rose through Real’s ranks, debuted for the first team at 18, and scored 10 La Liga goals. Find all the latest football transfers on our dedicated page.

Wilson, 30, rejoined Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013, adding 51 appearances in his second spell after having spent four seasons at the club before moving to Celtic; he has also played for Preston North End and Notts County, but was released in May and is currently without a team.

Tesco, the world’s third‑largest retailer, is exiting its loss‑making U.S. chain Fresh & Easy, transferring 4,000 of the 5,000 employees to a new business and closing the remaining 50 stores. The deal includes an £80 million loan to the new venture, with Tesco paying £150 million to dispose of the brand—part of which may be repaid—and retaining an option to buy a stake if the business turns profitable. Fresh & Easy, which opened in 2007 and operates 200 stores in California, Nevada and Arizona, has never been profitable. The new owners will be Yucaipa, a Los Angeles‑based private‑equity firm run by billionaire Ron Burkle, and the transaction comes as Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years.

Media playback is not supported on this device. The passage recounts an athlete who initially faced racial abuse, overcame it, briefly considered representing France, and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, while also mentioning a special guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s the Mont Blanc region and surrounding French Alps glaciers covered about 375 sq km, but by the late 2000s this had fallen to roughly 275 sq km, a 26 % loss over 40 years. A new inventory led by Marie Gardent of the University of Savoie, presented at the AGU Fall Meeting, mapped roughly 600 glaciers across the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves and Mont Blanc massifs, using satellite imagery, aerial photos and manual verification to correct for debris cover and shadows. The study confirms earlier findings that retreat is uneven, with the southern sectors (e.g., Belledonne almost gone, Ecrins retreat >3× Mont Blanc) losing more ice than the northern Alps, where higher elevation, more precipitation and cloud cover slow the loss; La Mer de Glace now covers just over 30 sq km versus 31.5 sq km in the 1960s/70s. Similar accelerating mass loss has been reported by Swiss researchers, underscoring ongoing monitoring efforts across the Alpine region.

Scotland’s women have won all five qualifiers and face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, a win that would almost guarantee a spot in next summer’s finals in the Netherlands; Emma Evans, a 24‑year‑old Bayern Munich forward, stresses the emotional stakes after past play‑off defeats and notes that the group’s top seed, Iceland, is unbeaten, making the match decisive for group leadership. Evans, one of 12 of the 20‑player squad playing abroad (five in England, four in Sweden, two in the US), highlights the advantage of competing in top leagues like Germany’s Frauen‑Bundesliga, where she won the Bundesliga with Bayern and gained experience alongside men’s stars, arguing that such exposure strengthens the national side as it approaches its first major finals.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish‑born blogger who runs the Wings Over Scotland site and is a vocal Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England after a woman in south London filed a complaint alleging two years of online harassment. The woman, in her 30s, claimed the harassment had taken place over that period, and the Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegation. Campbell, who was released on bail pending further inquiries until mid‑September, says the accusations stem from tweets that are not threatening and accuses the media of creating “innuendo” to fuel speculation, while noting that all the tweets in question remain publicly visible. He has also announced on Twitter that he will be posting less frequently due to reasons “totally outwith my control.”

PETA wants Skegness’s iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot replaced with a more animal‑friendly image, proposing a fish with the slogan “Skegness – A Happy Plaice.” The mayor, Carl Macey, welcomes suggestions but doubts the mascot will be removed, noting that the original 1908 poster, commissioned by the Great Northern Railway for 12 guineas and featuring the slogan “Skegness is so bracing,” has become synonymous with the resort and is beloved by adults and children alike. Dawn Carr of PETA argues that the Jolly Fisherman evokes images of fish cruelty and that the town should rebrand itself as a progressive holiday destination that does not celebrate the mutilation and killing of sea animals. Macey maintains that the mascot has never been portrayed as cruel, and while the proposal will be presented to the council, he says the town will not pursue changes if the council does not approve.

Scotland dominated a rugby match against Georgia, taking an early lead with a try from Vasil Lobzhanidze and then piling on five more through Tommy Seymour, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg, Hamish Watson and a second Hogg try, while Georgia managed only a penalty and a late try. Scotland controlled 91 % of possession, used counter‑attacks and a strong scrum to force a penalty try, and finished with a 38‑11 victory. Coach Vern Cotter praised the team’s pragmatic play and the performance of captain Greig Laidlaw, while Georgia struggled with their scrum and discipline, earning a yellow card for Moray Low and a sin‑bin for Kote Mikautadze. The match featured key players such as Hogg, Seymour, Watson, Laidlaw, and Georgia’s Lobzhanidze, Aptsiauri and Mikautadze.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38‑12, taking a 14‑6 half‑time lead through tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge, with Paddy Flynn scoring early in the second half. Ah Van, Lloyd White (two) and Joe Mellor added further points to make it 38‑12, while Castleford’s three tries in four minutes—Larne Patrick, Luke Gale and Flynn’s hat‑trick—came late but were not enough to overturn the deficit. The Vikings’ win had seemed secure after Mellor’s early break, but Castleford’s defence faltered, allowing Patrick to score after signing a three‑year deal from Huddersfield. Widnes’ victory moved them above Wakefield into seventh place, leaving Castleford in sixth, one point ahead of the Vikings.

Fawzi al‑Odah, a 37‑year‑old Kuwaiti who had been held at the U.S. detention facility in Cuba since 2002 after a Pakistani arrest on alleged al‑Qaeda and Taliban ties, was released following a U.S. review panel’s finding that he posed no continuing significant threat; he had challenged U.S. detention in the Supreme Court and denied the charges. He boarded a Kuwaiti government plane on Wednesday, with his lawyer expressing excitement rather than bitterness. The release, approved by Guantanamo’s Periodic Review Board in July, requires him to spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait, a condition set by the Kuwaiti government, which had pressed for the release of all its nationals. His departure, the first since the May exchange of five Taliban detainees for U.S. Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, reduces the U.S. base’s population to 148. The facility, opened in January 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, has been slated for closure by President Barack Obama.

PPAP (“Pen‑Pineapple‑Apple‑Pen”) is a one‑minute, catchy tune performed by the animal‑print‑clad DJ Piko‑Taro, a fictional persona portrayed by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The song’s simple, silly lyrics (“I have a pen… Apple‑pen… Pineapple‑pen…”) and accompanying dance made it a viral video, first posted on Piko‑Taro’s YouTube channel and then widely shared on Facebook, where the original clip has over 4 million views and a 9GAG‑hosted version has surpassed 44 million. Fans have commented on its addictive hook, the performer’s flamboyant wardrobe (some likening him to the anime character Borsalino), and the irritation it can cause, while the track has spawned hundreds of covers and tributes—including heavy‑metal versions and a Thai star’s rendition—yet it has received limited coverage from mainstream Japanese media and has not trended on Japanese social platforms, despite being dubbed the next Psy and aimed at becoming a global phenomenon.

Thousands gathered for the early‑morning Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people marching in a parade before a wreath‑laying at the Cenotaph, while a parallel service was held at Westminster Abbey; the event, which began in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey ceremony a year after the Gallipoli landings, has since become a key moment for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honour their countrymen’s sacrifices. At the dawn service, Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the crowds, laid a wreath, and reflected on the bravery and heroism of the Anzac troops, while the ceremony featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of New Zealand, Australia and the United Kingdom, and highlighted the eight‑month, blood‑stained Gallipoli campaign that was an Allied attempt to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, 30, has re‑signed with St Mirren for a second spell in July and may debut in the Championship against Alloa, where the club sits eighth, seven points clear of the bottom. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has mostly appeared as a substitute this term, but says he is fit, has been playing U20s and training hard to be ready. With two Scotland caps and one goal in 2008, Clarkson has nearly 400 senior club appearances, having played for Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers. He stresses that every match matters, hoping wins will boost confidence and help St Mirren climb the table.

The turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, sparking concerns that the new owners might abandon the existing workers’ pension scheme; however, Unite regional officer Steve Harley reported that negotiations yielded guarantees that all current agreements would be honoured, noting that the Bernard Matthews final‑salary pension scheme closed in 2004 and members now have an unaffected alternative scheme. Boparan’s private office confirmed the continuation of the current pension arrangements, and Harley’s meeting with Boparan at the Great Witchingham headquarters highlighted the owner’s intention to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and by expanding chicken processing to utilise spare capacity.

The council’s scrutiny meeting addressed the chain ferry’s launch on 14 May, which has suffered breakdowns, groundings, and a suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, causing vehicle damage and business losses. Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings at Cowes until 2 July to gather feedback and ordered an auditor review. Transport councillor Ian Ward noted the ferry is a prototype with expected teething problems, citing resolved electrical faults, seamanship groundings, and the council’s approval of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle scraping, while compensation for local businesses remains under discussion.

The Lords review warns that Britain may need to allow EU‑registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a broader deal, a concern amplified by the fact that fishing regions voted heavily to leave the EU and that the industry, which contributes only about 0.5 % of GDP and employs 12,000 fishers, risks marginalisation in Brexit negotiations. The report notes that the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been seen as disastrous for Britain, yet many fishers view Brexit as an opportunity to regain control of UK waters and become a leading fish‑exporter like Norway, though continued market access to the EU will likely require concessions such as allowing EU vessels greater access to UK waters. It recommends retaining many CFP elements post‑Brexit, basing quotas on scientific advice, and maintaining international cooperation, while warning that the UK could end up with four separate fisheries regimes if the CFP framework collapses. Despite these risks, industry leaders and the government see potential gains: recent EU quota agreements for plaice, haddock and prawns are viewed positively, and the Scottish Fishermen’s Federation CEO heralds full control of the 200‑mile exclusive economic zone as a chance for fairer shares and sustainable management, with the government emphasising the need for maximum trade freedom and a review of fisheries management to ensure fair access, sustainable stocks and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney, a 69‑year‑old teacher, admitted to taking or allowing the download of erotic images of young boys between April 2004 and February 2014, leading to a community payback order and placement on the sex offenders register. A February hearing at Dumfries Sheriff Court described the images as depicting partially dressed boys in erotic poses without sexual activity. The General Teaching Council Scotland panel found his conduct “fundamentally incompatible” with teaching, noting a long‑term pattern of behaviour, lack of remedial action, and a strong likelihood of recurrence, and consequently declared him unfit to teach, removed him from the professional register, and barred him from re‑registering for two years.

A fire on 2 March at the Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited site on Duncan Street caused train service reductions and travel delays, prompting firefighters to spend several days on site. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company’s waste‑acceptance licence and, after joint inspections with Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS), decided to revoke its environmental permit effective 7 August, though the firm—run by Asset and Land Group—was described as broadly compliant with fire‑safety law. The company has until 7 August to appeal, must still remove all waste, and the fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad told the BBC that Syria is trying to meet the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, but the country missed Wednesday’s deadline to hand over the entire stockpile; he said two shipments en route from Damascus to Latakia were attacked, with the second intercepted by fire from “terrorist groups.” He criticized U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry’s condemnation of barrel‑bomb attacks in Aleppo, citing reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights that 246 people, including 73 children, were killed in the last five days, and from the Aleppo Media Centre that 14 were killed in Masaken Hanano. Mekdad denied that the government bombed civilians, accused the U.S. of supporting terrorists, and insisted Syria was defending its people. Meanwhile, the Observatory reports that the Islamic Front coalition freed hundreds of detainees from Aleppo’s central prison, which the state media says was thwarted, while rebels claim control of the 3,000‑strong prison held in horrific conditions. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, of which only 30 tonnes (4 %) have left the country; the U.S. and Russia urge Syria to complete the transfer to the coast by 1 March and destroy all weapons by the end of June, a process slowed by security concerns and overseen by the OPCW, with Mekdad affirming Syria’s commitment to its obligations.

England secured a series‑winning victory at Old Trafford, leveling the four‑match series with a day to spare after a dominant performance that saw them score 589‑8 declared and 173‑1 declared, the largest run margin over Pakistan. Joe Root, promoted to number three, earned man‑of‑the‑match honors with 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, while also taking four catches and a wicket; captain Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76 not out. England’s bowlers dismantled Pakistan, who were bowled out for 234 on Monday, and the pitch offered little assistance, leading former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott to praise England’s batting, discipline and bowling. Misbah‑ul‑Haq lamented Pakistan’s lack of confidence and poor shot selection, noting only he and Asad Shafiq passed 50 in the first two Tests, and the team will play a two‑day game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is launching a review of the quality of life and care for older people in residential care, inviting pensioners, their friends and families to share their experiences so that recommendations can be made to care providers and public bodies. She will assess physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment, drawing on her extensive visits across Wales and growing public concern over uneven standards. Rochira aims to give older people and their families a voice to hold service providers accountable and drive improvements. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft welcomed the review’s goals but criticised the absence of a care‑home expert on the advisory panel, arguing that this omission limits partnership and sector engagement.

Former Dundee United midfielder Paul Sheerin, 39, has been player‑manager of Arbroath (the Red Lichties) since 2010 and was appointed to replace Neil Cooper as Aberdeen’s manager at Pittodrie; he led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division in 2011, but the club were relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013‑14. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser said Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process, noting that “Despite wishing to retain Paul’s services, Arbroath chairman John Christison was good to deal with and completely appreciated Paul’s desire to come back to Aberdeen.” Sheerin’s playing career included stints with several Scottish clubs and a spell with Sweden’s Östersunds, and he earned a Scotland U21 cap in the mid‑1990s.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea City in Saturday’s match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley’s dismissal, while the club is eager to appoint a new permanent boss—ex‑Derby manager Paul Clement is the preferred choice. Curtis, a former player who spent his career at the club, laments that Swansea have lost their “Swansea Way” since Michael Laudrup’s departure in 2014, citing frequent managerial changes, the loss of key players and a failure to adequately replace them. He stresses that the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League, reminding new signings of the club’s remarkable rise from near‑bankruptcy in 2003 to promotion in 2011 and the importance of maintaining that status for the club and the wider area. The club’s past success under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers and Laudrup is highlighted, and Curtis notes that the Championship has grown stronger, making promotion more difficult even for clubs like Norwich, Burnley and Newcastle.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist turned entrepreneur, famously accelerated the human genome project by turning it into a competitive race, earning both acclaim and criticism for his aggressive, privately funded approach; after publishing the human genome, he shifted focus to creating the first synthetic organism, Synthia, which appeared in *Science* in 2006, and has since led the J. Craig Venter Institute in pioneering synthetic biology. Born in 1946, Venter’s early life in Southern California and service as a naval orderly in Vietnam instilled a sense of urgency that drove his rapid adoption of automated sequencing technology in 1987 and his breakthrough strategy of targeting RNA to speed gene discovery, a move that shocked peers like James Watson and prompted his departure from the NIH in 1992 to establish the Institute for Genomic Research. In 1995 he released the first complete genome of *Haemophilus influenzae*, and in 1998 founded Celera Genomics to finish the human genome in three years, a venture that, despite controversy over data access, secured him substantial wealth and independence. Venter also launched the oceanic “genetic treasure hunt” aboard his yacht Sorcerer II to sequence marine microbes, aiming to deepen understanding of gene evolution and to harness synthetic microbes for industrial applications that could reduce oil dependence and mitigate carbon emissions.

The Sutton Trust study, conducted by Boston Consulting Group, finds that England’s apprenticeship system lags behind other European countries, with fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual starts rated at level 3 (A‑level equivalent) and only 61,000 new starts for young people, compared with 570,000 in Germany where 90 % are level 3; only 20 % of English employers offer apprenticeships versus 51 % in Germany, and England’s system offers 18,000 qualifications versus Germany’s 330. Since 2010, more than half of apprenticeships have been below level 3, three‑quarters target workers over 25, and 11 young people compete for each spot. The report calls for a radical expansion to 300,000 new starts per year, mainly at level 3 or 4, limiting two‑year level 2 courses to 10 %, and stresses that apprenticeships are vital for social mobility. The Association of Colleges warns that creating 300,000 places would be a massive challenge given the current shortage for 16‑year‑olds, while the Department for Education says it is already reforming apprenticeships to raise standards, extend minimum duration, and improve English, maths and job relevance, with further plans to be published.

Briton Ellie Storey finished more than two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, and could secure a 17th title in Saturday’s road race, a win she called a massive relief as she targets further Paralympic success in Rio. Storey, Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian, has 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) from six Paralympics in cycling and swimming, won four golds at London 2012, and has 21 world titles across both sports. She began her career in swimming, earning six medals at the 1992 Games before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United, known as the Bulls, faced a crippling financial crisis after relegation from the Football League in 2012, with debts of roughly £225,000 and an additional £70,000 owed to HMRC, while average attendance fell from 3,270 to 1,758. Despite a £1 takeover bid from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust and negotiations with other bidders, the club was ultimately acquired by London businessman Tommy Agombar on 3 June, but failed to meet successive Conference payment deadlines (5, 6, 7, and 12 June) and was expelled on 10 June. The Conference reinstated Chester FC—formerly Chester City—to the Premier division, effectively taking the Bulls’ place, and Chester’s final‑day win at Aldershot and a Salisbury equaliser at Chester had initially kept the Bulls up. Key figures included former boss Martin Foyle, who later managed Southport and signed former Bulls keeper Dan Lloyd‑Weston, and Kingsley James, who moved to Bumpers Lane after Chester’s announcement.

Former Manchester City midfielder Michael Milner, now 30, earned 61 senior England caps since his 2009 debut, was part of squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but only logged three minutes at Euro 2016; he publicly wished success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters, and holds the record for most England U21 caps (46) since his 2004 debut, scoring his sole senior international goal in a 5‑0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a months‑long illness, with a private funeral and a later memorial service. A pioneering early‑music conductor, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led it for about 30 years across six continents, producing over 200 recordings—including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments—and a celebrated 1980 Handel Messiah with Emma Kirkby that BBC Music Magazine ranked among the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge under Rafael Puyana, Mary Potts, Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, and began his career as a keyboardist and musicologist with Sir Neville Marriner’s Academy of Saint Martin‑in‑the‑Fields, later becoming a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, taught at Harvard, held an honorary professorship at Cambridge and a professor‑at‑large position at Cornell, and was widely praised by colleagues such as Christopher Purvis, Richard Egarr, Emma Kirkby and David Thomas for his generosity, academic brilliance and role as a global ambassador for historically informed performance.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being protected, has been withdrawn from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping; his parents have been waiting for a place at a special school, but in September were told all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full with no timetable for availability. The boy’s mother, who gave up her job to care for him, says he feels isolated and misses being around people, and she worries that the over‑subscribed special‑needs system will similarly affect other families. An extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, giving hope that the boy may start there soon, while the Education Authority, citing privacy concerns, has declined to comment on the case but stated it is reviewing special‑school needs and working to place children closer to home, a process ongoing since 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is pursuing a takeover of the Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade as a rugby venue, while Newport County (the football club) holds a lease that gives them fixture priority at the ground until 2023; the club’s chairman, Will Godfrey, notes that County and the Newport Squash Club are protected under existing agreements and that the WRU’s plan to install an artificial pitch would violate Football League rules. A shareholder vote on the takeover is scheduled for early May, with the WRU’s proposal to be voted on 9 May. Newport County, under caretaker manager Mike Flynn, sits two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left, needing a win and a Hartlepool loss to survive, and the club’s chairman, Foxall, warned that relegation to the National League would be a devastating blow to the fans and the city, especially after the club’s 2013 promotion back to the Football League.

The narrator recounts being kidnapped at 15 by the Revolutionary United Front, forced into violent training and atrocities, escaping to Freetown where he was jailed and met preacher Richard Cole who helped him reorient toward education and national rebuilding; after Cole’s death in 2006, the narrator and others formed a clinic during the 2014 Ebola crisis, conducting education for over 10,000 people in local languages, providing food to 11,000 households, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives, while the country ultimately declared itself free of the virus that had killed nearly 4,000 people over 18 months, with death totals listed for Sierra Leone, Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria, Mali, and the US.

About 80,000 items from the Wedgwood collection—art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs—were threatened with auction to cover the pottery firm’s pension debt, but a public fundraising campaign launched in September reached its target in a month. Administrators Begbies Traynor confirmed the collection will stay on display at the Barlaston museum, and the Art Fund will donate it to the Victoria and Albert Museum before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The sale, approved by administrator Bob Young, was praised by Tristram Hunt MP and Alison Wedgwood, who noted the collection’s importance to Staffordshire and Britain’s cultural heritage, and avoided the risk of the items being dispersed worldwide.

Dan Groves said the finer details of a potential deal that would let former reality‑TV star Wright acquire 20 % of Billericay Town and become a club director remain undisclosed, while the club sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points shy of the play‑off places. Wright, who finished runner‑up on *I’m A Celebrity* in 2011 and has played for non‑league sides such as Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds, is linked to the move. Billericay, recently taken over by multi‑millionaire Glenn Tamplin—who has pledged to invest £10,000 a week—also signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, surprised observers by announcing a one‑year extension of his term beyond the originally planned 2018 exit, rather than staying until 2021 or stepping down immediately; he explained the decision was purely personal, citing his daughters’ upcoming exams and a desire to return to Canada, and that he wanted to avoid leaving amid the Brexit negotiations, while noting that Prime Minister Theresa May had encouraged an extension but that the choice was his; he stressed the move was not politically motivated and that he would step down once the Article 50 process was complete, allowing a new governor to chart Britain’s economic future.

The Healthy Me programme, created by Action Mental Health, is a pilot of interactive workshops for P6 and P7 pupils in five Northern Irish schools that teaches emotional wellbeing, coping strategies such as breathing exercises, and how to seek help, while also training teachers in supporting students’ mental health; chief executive David Babington says it aims to ease the stress of the transfer test and the primary‑to‑secondary transition, which has seen a slight rise in test takers to 14,681 this year, and is intended for wider rollout. Carrick Primary School’s pastoral co‑ordinator Helen Hamilton reports the programme has helped pupils and parents manage anxiety about moving to secondary school, noting the difficulty for new teachers to spot emotional issues. Chief inspector Noelle Buick highlights the broader need to strengthen resilience and embed preventative pastoral care across the curriculum to address the complex challenges young people face.

The former Fawley oil‑fired power station, which closed in 2013 after 40 years of operation and once supplied power to one million homes, is being redeveloped by Fawley Waterside into a £1 bn “merchant city” that will feature a petal‑shaped glass structure, marina, housing and restaurants, with fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth; the 198‑metre‑high chimney will remain as a signature landmark and become the tallest attraction south of London’s Shard, with planning permission expected later this year and construction potentially starting in 2018.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders for a brief stint as Grant Mitchell to film Barbara’s final episodes, a storyline that sees the long‑running character reappear after her 2010 exit to reveal her cancer has returned and that she will be killed off in spring. Kemp, who originally played Grant from 1990‑1999 and again in 2005‑2006, said he could not refuse the chance to bring the Mitchell family together for one last reunion with their mother, and he looks forward to filming what he expects to be classic episodes. The plot will feature the Mitchell brothers confronting the loss of their mother, with executive producer Dominic Treadwell‑Collins praising the opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best.

Spurs lost at Anfield after Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds, leaving the second‑placed side disappointed. Pochettino warned that a poor start makes it hard to fight for the Premier League title and criticised the team’s lack of desire, noting that Spurs have won only twice on the road since 24 September and just once in 17 away matches against top‑six clubs. He added that if Chelsea beat Burnley and go 12 points clear it would be a big problem for Spurs. Former player Danny Murphy echoed the criticism, saying Spurs’ defensive record is good but they were “all over the place” with a back‑four instead of their usual back‑three, and that the lack of pace and different mindset away from home must be improved quickly.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 of 28 governorships, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999 and confirming Buhari’s presidential victory over Goodluck Jonathan, who will be succeeded on 29 May. The PDP’s decline is evident in its loss of key northern states such as Katsina, Kaduna and Adamawa, while it retained only Rivers State and won eight governorships mainly in the southeast; Taraba remains undecided and Imo’s result is inconclusive. Seven states had no elections. The APC’s gains made it the dominant national party, though it failed to win any of Nigeria’s five oil‑producing states, raising concerns about oil revenue amid militant threats. Violence at polling stations rose to 66 incidents, mainly in Rivers and other southern areas, yet overall the elections were calmer than before, suggesting democratic maturation. The PDP, after 16 years in power, faces introspection and rebuilding amid defections, corruption allegations, and perceived failure to curb insurgency.

HebCelt, the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19‑22 July, will offer an augmented‑reality app that lets visitors tap signs and posters to access online videos, band interviews, ticket purchases and other festival information on phones and tablets. The lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Director Caroline Maclennan says the feature enhances on‑site enjoyment and lets people worldwide experience the festival’s atmosphere in real time, with updates available before and during the event.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated under clause 5.6 of the supplementary funding agreement, with the Park View Educational Trust possibly removed from running the schools; Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, have been warned that they could lose funding unless breaches are addressed. Education minister Lord Nash sent letters to the trusts’ chairmen, citing deep concerns over the schools’ management, discrimination, segregation of boys and girls, and a narrow faith‑based curriculum, and demanded corrective actions by 4 July. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw warned of a culture of fear and intimidation in Birmingham schools, while head teachers reported an organised campaign to impose a narrow Muslim ideology. The Park View report highlighted inadequate safeguarding and unvetted extremist speakers at Islamic‑themed assemblies. Saltley School, the only local authority school in special measures, is working with the council and DfE to install a temporary governing board and aims to improve its Ofsted rating. Parents across the schools have criticised the Ofsted findings as biased, with some calling for an open meeting with Education Secretary Michael Gove to discuss the evidence.

Nazanin Zaghari‑Ratcliffe, a 38‑year‑old British citizen, was sentenced in September to five years in Iranian prison on undisclosed charges of allegedly plotting to topple Tehran’s government; she has been held in solitary confinement since her arrest at Tehran Airport in April, and her two‑year‑old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran with grandparents after the government confiscated her passport. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, has criticized the UK for inaction, claims the appeal is being held secretly in Tehran, and says the family cannot attend the hearing; he believes his wife is being used as a bargaining chip in a diplomatic dispute and that the appeal’s outcome could quash, reduce, or increase the sentence. Ratcliffe reports that Nazanin had suicidal thoughts and a hunger strike while in jail, but has become more resilient after being moved out of solitary; he is trying to obtain a visa to visit her and their daughter, who has lost her English and is now fluent in Farsi. Amnesty International UK labels her a prisoner of conscience, and the Risk campaign manager hopes the appeal will secure her immediate release.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich.  The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court argued that the eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, failed to detect Vinnie’s swollen optic discs and did not refer him for further investigation, a lapse that led to fluid buildup in his brain, increased skull pressure and ultimately his death.  Jonathan Rees QC said the conduct was so far below the expected standard of a competent optometrist that it was “criminal,” and Ms Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter; the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman to have sex with a man he sourced from an adult website, filming the act, and of sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim’s sister on Christmas Day; he was also convicted of forcing the victim’s sister and father to view sexual images and of threatening or abusive behaviour on 25 December 2014. The court remitted the case to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing, noting Weatherhogg’s first‑offender status and a moderate risk of sexual re‑offending, while the judge emphasised that the sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence of such conduct. Weatherhogg had denied the charges, was placed on the sex offenders register, and his defence counsel described his remand ahead of sentencing as a dramatic shock.

In the first T20 at Greater Noida, Ireland were bowled out for 165‑5 after Stuart Thompson’s 56, Gary Wilson’s 41 not out and William Porterfield’s 39, but an early duck from Paul Stirling left them scrambling; Afghanistan chased the target comfortably, with Samiullah Shenwari’s 56 and Mohammad Shahzad’s 47, and an opening partnership of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai, finishing 171‑4 with two overs to spare. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2‑23, the only bowler to claim more than one wicket, while Ireland’s loss of paceman Boyd Rankin to a back problem in the T20s was a setback, though

Barcelona paid £48.6 m (€57 m) for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34 m, and the total cost of the player—including signing‑on fees, wages, agents’ fees and a recent tax payment—has risen to £106.8 m. The club has faced investigations after former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money; a Spanish judge found enough evidence to continue probing the transfer. Barcelona denies any tax crime, issued a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56, and maintains that the original tax payment complied with fiscal obligations, though it is unclear whether the case will be dropped. Neymar has scored seven league goals in 18 appearances and three Champions League goals in seven matches.

Bodies of 24‑year‑old David Miller and 23‑year‑old Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September; post‑mortems revealed Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Metropolitan Police detectives flew to Thailand to work with Thai authorities, who are holding two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the killings and are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape and robbery, facing the death penalty. The UK police have finished their investigation in Thailand, will return to compile a report and update the families, and the UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns over the investigation, including DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects. The Thai police claim DNA found on Witheridge matched the suspects.

Virtual reality is increasingly being used beyond entertainment, embedding itself in everyday contexts to enhance understanding and engagement. The BBC highlighted unexpected applications such as the National Autistic Society’s VR film that immerses viewers in the sensory overload of an autistic child, and Alzheimer’s Research UK’s “Walk Through Dementia” that shows the challenges of daily tasks for those with dementia. Real‑estate agents and retailers use VR for virtual property tours and Westfield’s fashion showcases, while Ikea launched a Steam‑based app that lets users explore and customize a fully furnished kitchen, even adding virtual meatballs to delight customers. In healthcare, surgeons like Dr Shafi Ahmed streamed a live virtual operation to thousands worldwide, and startups such as Medical Realities aim to democratise surgical training; VR has also helped soldiers with PTSD and arachnophobics overcome fears. Educational initiatives include Google Expeditions, which takes students on virtual field trips, and Evanescent Studios’ Mandarin‑learning app that lets learners converse with virtual Chinese speakers and visit landmarks; NetDragon is testing head‑tilt sensors to gauge student engagement. Despite these promising uses, schools face hardware and cost hurdles that must be addressed for VR to become a mainstream educational tool.

The Su‑24 jet’s black box was opened in Moscow, where investigators found missing flight data that could clarify the aircraft’s position when it was shot down; an analysis is due next week. The jet, part of a Russian contingent in Syria, was downed by Turkish F‑16s on 24 November, leading to a crisis between Russia and Turkey: Russia claims the aircraft was shot down within Syrian airspace, while Turkey says it ignored warnings to leave its airspace. Both crew members ejected, the pilot was killed by ground militants and the navigator rescued; a Russian marine sent to help was also killed and a helicopter destroyed on the ground. In response, Russia has imposed sanctions—including a ban on package holidays that could cost Turkey billions—and demands an apology from Turkey.

Scotland’s women have won all five of their qualifiers and are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, a win that would almost guarantee a place in next summer’s finals in the Netherlands.  Forward Lauren Evans, who has missed out on major tournaments after play‑off defeats in 2013 and 2019, stresses the emotional stakes and the desire to avoid heartbreak, noting that the best six of eight group runners‑up qualify automatically and Scotland are in pole position.  Iceland, ranked 20th and unbeaten after four wins, are top seeds and a tough opponent, but the Scots believe they can beat them, especially with the support of a big home crowd.  Evans is one of 12 squad members playing abroad—five in England, four in Sweden and two in the US—alongside BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little, and she credits the experience of playing in top leagues such as Germany’s Bundesliga (where she won the title with Bayern Munich) for raising the national team’s quality.  She highlights the competitive culture of foreign leagues and how it adds new dimensions to Scotland’s squad.

The Commission on Local Tax Reform, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, has concluded that there is no “magic bullet” to fix the council tax’s inherent problems, which have accumulated since its inception; Prof. Kenneth Gibb’s review of global local‑tax systems found that while property taxes are common and stable, they are confusing and perceived as unfair because they are not income‑linked, whereas local income taxes are seen as fairer but create revenue volatility and limit rate flexibility for authorities. Gibb warned that reform will inevitably be difficult and tied to past experiences, and the commission plans a public consultation across Scotland before publishing its autumn report, which the government says will explore fairer alternatives to the current system.

Third‑party software was used to steal intimate celebrity photos from iCloud, prompting Apple to add a two‑step verification that requires a four‑digit code sent to a trusted device after a new device logs in; if the code is not entered, access to iCloud and App Store purchases is blocked, though users can recover with a 14‑character recovery key if the trusted device is lost. Apple’s new safeguards prevent attackers using Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker from downloading backups, and the company now emails users when a backup starts. Experts debate the practicality of the recovery key and call for two‑factor authentication to be the default, while Apple plans to push users toward stronger passwords and two‑factor authentication, with Tim Cook emphasizing the need for greater user awareness.

UKIP, which won the May election, spent £2,956,737 (68p per vote for 4,376,635 votes), while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote), the Liberal Democrats £1,580,575 (1.45p per vote) and Labour £1,027,339 (26p per vote); the Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote) and the SNP £267,372, bringing the six highest‑spending parties’ total to £9,347,087. UKIP’s victory left the Lib Dems with only one of their 12 MEPs, Labour finished second, and the Greens came fourth; all parties except Labour spent more on the campaign than they did in 2009.

Centre‑back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his Barrow contract to join a National League rival, with a potential debut against his former club on 18 February; the ex‑Aldershot and Exeter player, who has also played in Italy, may feature soon. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams and has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, with his move pending international clearance. Nicholson praised Myles for his stature, voice and leadership qualities despite limited appearances, and highlighted Ruairi as a hungry, raw young talent. The Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10‑year‑old Irish‑bred gelding, collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day; veterinary staff treated him before he was pronounced dead, and the British Horseracing Authority confirmed a severe pulmonary haemorrhage as the cause. Acting chief veterinary officer Tony Welsh noted that such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues, and the sport is committed to understanding and preventing them. The horse had previously shown post‑race ataxia and had been treated for overheating after his Grand National success, but had no symptoms on the day of the race; he had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and trainer Oliver Sherwood called him the “horse of a lifetime.” The report concludes that the death was due to a rarely seen haemorrhage rather than a pre‑existing condition.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, former SNP leader Alex Salmond and Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie all bid farewell to Holyrood ahead of the 5 May election; Marwick herself wept again when Salmond delivered his valedictory address, in which he reiterated his belief that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse”, praised the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill, and urged the parliament to take greater responsibility for governing Scotland, while McNeil warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny, and Goldie lightened the mood by joking about missing Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “huge outbursts of faux indignation.”

The upcoming live‑action adaptation of *Beauty and the Beast* features Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou; Kevin Kline portrays Maurice, Belle’s father, while the housekeeper Mrs Potts—voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film—is played by the star in the new version. Bill Condon directs, with filming beginning at Shepperton Studios in May, and the film is slated for U.S. release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service will meet with victims’ relatives at 11:00 BST to explain its plans after 96 football fans were killed in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster. New inquests last year ruled the deaths unlawful, and in January the CPS received evidence on 23 suspects: 15 from Operation Resolve, which investigated the disaster’s causes during the Liverpool‑Nottingham Forest FA Cup semi‑final, and eight from an Independent Police Complaints Commission inquiry into the conduct of South Yorkshire and West Midlands police after the event. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall, chair of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, will be briefed by Sue Hemming, head of the CPS’s special crime and counter‑terrorism division, and Aspinall stresses the families’ long‑standing demand for accountability and their determination not to give up.

Chelmsford Prison has reported a surge in contraband incidents, with residents noting that packages have been hurled over the wall multiple times in recent weeks; a former inmate described the jail as “notorious” for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, and claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, though the Ministry of Justice found no evidence of drone activity. The Ministry said staff are working hard to stop contraband and that the Justice Secretary has asked for a review of tools to tackle the problem, while new laws now allow up to two years’ imprisonment for those who smuggle packages over prison walls. A nearby resident, who declined to be named, said she had seen packages thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, expressed concern but not fear, and noted the prison is inviting the community to discuss safety measures.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December after being struck by Brian Wright, 55, who drove a VW Golf that failed to stop at a red light. Wright, a former lollipop lady for 20 years and mother of three, told Luton Crown Court he was blinded by the setting sun and denied causing serious injury, though he apologized and admitted he had “turned her world upside down.” The judge paused the case for five minutes to allow him to compose himself. Blackburn is now in residential care, and the trial continues.

Muir, a 24‑year‑old Scottish middle‑distance runner, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast because her veterinary medicine exams in May clash with the April event. She finished fourth in the 1500 m and sixth in the 5000 m at the World Athletics Championships, clocking a new outdoor personal best of 14 min 52.07 s. After a week off, she will return to university and continue training, hoping to target the World Indoor Championships in March and potentially future Olympics. She remains proud of her performance, noting the tough competition and her five races in ten days, and expresses confidence that the Scottish team will succeed even in her absence.

Trevor Deely, a 22‑year‑old from County Kildare, vanished after a Christmas party in December 2000 and was last seen walking home. A search of a three‑acre wooded area in Chapelizod, Dublin, began early Saturday, with Gardaí planning excavations that could take weeks. Earlier this year detectives reviewed the case, enhancing CCTV footage that shows Deely speaking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked, as he returned to fetch an umbrella. The footage, released in April, has prompted an appeal for the unidentified man—who may also appear in later footage on Haddington Road—to come forward, but he remains unrecognized as of the latest update.

Del Potro, ranked 165th after a two‑year injury layoff, upset Swiss player Stan Wawrinka 3‑6 6‑3 7‑6(7‑2) 6‑3 at Wimbledon, marking his first Grand Slam since 2014 and earning praise for his comeback after three wrist operations; he will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. Australian Nick Kyrgios, also in Murray’s half, rallied from 2‑1 down to beat Germany’s Dustin Brown 6‑7(3‑7) 6‑1 2‑6 6‑4 6‑4 in a rain‑delayed match and will meet Spanish 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with the winner facing either Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Lopez himself recovered from two sets down to defeat Fabio Fognini 3‑6 6‑7 6‑3 6‑3 6‑3, while 10th seed Tomas Berdych and 12th seed Jo‑Wilfried Tsonga secured straight‑sets victories over Benjamin Becker and Juan Monaco respectively.

Tunisia was almost expelled from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after a dispute with CAF over a controversial penalty in a 2015 quarter‑final against Equatorial Guinea, but the federation issued an apology and the ban was lifted; Morocco’s participation was initially barred but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a CAF ban and reduced a $1 million fine to $50 000, allowing the country to enter the 2017 qualifying draw; both nations, after resolving their conflicts, are preparing for the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia set to face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A and Morocco facing Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé in Group F, and Tunisia’s successful campaign would mark its thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

McLaren, once a dominant force in Formula 1 with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers’ championships and eight constructors’ titles, has fallen into a slump since 2013 when chassis design lost its edge and the partnership with Honda’s power‑unit proved unreliable; the team’s recent results are modest, with only a handful of points and a fourth‑place grid finish expected. Historically, McLaren’s golden era began in the 1980s with the legendary 1988 season driven by Senna and Prost, continued through the late 1990s with Hakkinen and Mercedes engines, and saw further successes in 2007 and 2008, though scandals such as the 2007 Ferrari data breach and the 2009 “lie‑gate” incident marred the era. The team’s fortunes have cycled between triumph and decline, with Ron Dennis’s takeover in the 1980s and again in 2009 attempting to restore competitiveness. Alonso’s return in 2015, driven by a renewed Honda partnership, and Dennis’s confidence that the current car is among the best, underpin hopes that McLaren will soon reclaim championships and challenge Mercedes’ dominance.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, and police later found patrons still inside, with receipts indicating alcohol was served until 04:49 BST; the Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar’s closure for three months.
