Colleen O’Neill (43) and James Thomas (44), both from Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours—O’Neill faced two counts and Thomas one. The defence solicitor noted lax adherence to licensing laws, and the judge criticised O’Neill’s “appalling record,” noting he lacked power to impose custodial sentences; O’Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single‑season three‑point record by making eight threes in a 116‑105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers, scoring 45 points, nine assists, and helping the Warriors erase a 13‑point deficit with Klay Thompson’s 26 points; Curry entered the game four shots shy of his 272‑th mark set two years earlier. Lamarcus Aldridge poured in 27 points and six rebounds while Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists for Portland. In a separate game, the Chicago Bulls, led by Pau Gasol’s 16 points and 15 rebounds, rallied from a 19‑point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89‑78, with Derrick Rose and Mike Dunleavy each scoring 12 points and the Bulls moving back into the No. 3 spot in the Eastern Conference; the Heat were hampered by Hassan Whiteside’s 19 points and 16 rebounds and Dwyane Wade’s 4‑for‑20 shooting.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood, as they had been led to believe he was a competition winner. The Dutch free‑kick specialist, known for uploading videos of his dead‑ball exploits, showcased his skills in front of the Liverpool stars, scoring a top‑corner free‑kick that left the stand‑in keeper helpless. The players watched him shoot, and van Velzen enjoyed the experience of playing with his idols, even revealing Balotelli’s infamous slogan and noting Balotelli’s famous t‑shirt worn during Manchester City’s 6‑1 win over United in October 2011.

Oophorectomy, the removal of ovaries, has been shown to markedly lower mortality in women with BRCA1‑mutated breast cancer, with a 62 % reduction in breast‑cancer death and a 65 % overall death reduction in a Canadian study of 676 patients; the benefit is greatest when performed within two years of diagnosis (73 % reduction) and persists for 15 years, though it does not confer the same advantage for BRCA2 carriers. Angelina Jolie, a BRCA1 carrier who underwent oophorectomy after a double mastectomy, exemplifies this approach, which is now being considered as part of initial treatment discussions for early‑stage breast cancers, especially estrogen‑receptor‑negative disease. BRCA1/2 mutations confer a 50–80 % lifetime risk of breast cancer, are more common in Ashkenazi Jewish women (≈2.3 %), and are associated with aggressive, drug‑resistant tumors; genetic testing is available for those with a strong family history or suspected mutations.

On Easter morning, Amtrak train No. 80, the Carolinian, traveling north from Charlotte to New York City, struck and killed Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33) in Durham, North Carolina, as they lingered on the tracks. The couple, who may have lived in a homeless camp and were found with a grocery cart, were pronounced dead at the scene. No passengers were injured, though one passenger fell ill during the delay. The train, operating on Norfolk Southern property, was delayed for about 2 hours 45 minutes before continuing to its next stop in Raleigh, 25 miles away.

Carlos Toro, a 66‑year‑old former Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, spent 27 years as a key DEA informant in the United States, helping to bring down figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, yet never received the promised U.S. citizenship; now retired due to declining health, his temporary visa expired on January 1, leaving him technically undocumented and unable to claim Social Security benefits, while the DEA has refused to assist him and he fears death if deported back to Colombia, prompting him to seek a green card or passport and even consider hiding.

ICANN, the U.S. regulator of internet addresses, is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd., a Canadian company that launched the new “.sucks” top‑level domain and has sold high‑profile names such as youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, and yahoo.sucks to celebrities and brands for around $2,500 a year, with some resellers offering them for $2,000. The company began accepting registrations on March 30 from trademark holders and celebrities before opening the domain to the public, and has been accused of a “shakedown” scheme that forces figures like Kevin Spacey to pay to have their names removed; Spacey is among those who have paid to delete his.sucks domain. ICANN, after initially approving the TLD, has backtracked following complaints from an advisory panel of industry groups—including Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay—and has sent letters to the U.S. FTC and Canada’s Office of Consumer Affairs to determine whether Vox Populi’s actions violate regulations, threatening to declare the registry in breach of contract if found illegal. The advisory body argues that the planned future opening of.sucks to average consumers is a key part of the coercive scheme.

In 1988 a still‑born baby boy was discovered wrapped in a blanket in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, and was buried anonymously; a support group later funded a headstone naming him Peter. In 2021 the boy’s body was exhumed for a periodic review, and DNA taken from his leg bone matched a relative in the national database, leading police to identify and arrest his mother, who had concealed her pregnancy and delivered the baby alone. She was charged with infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained the baby was stillborn; investigators found no evidence of foul play. The mother remains on bail while CPS decide whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial, and the case, unsolved for 27 years, was closed thanks to advances in DNA technology.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered by a High Court judge to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi in Bath, Somerset. Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks would not pay the fare and drove him back to the taxi rank to “teach him a lesson”; when Hicks objected, the driver continued, prompting Hicks to jump out at over 20 mph, resulting in devastating brain damage, epilepsy and lifelong care from his mother. The judge ruled Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages—estimated at roughly 50 % of the family’s requested amount, plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment—though the exact sum will be decided in a later hearing, with both parties allowed to appeal.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as several storms produced multiple tornado reports, including one about 6 mi northwest of Goddard (less than 15 mi west of Wichita) that moved northeast and missed the city but posed risks to nearby communities. CNN severe‑weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly. Additional sightings came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna (125 mi southwest of Wichita). The storms also affected Missouri, where a tornado may have touched down in Potosi (≈70 mi from St. Louis), causing wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, roof damage, and a water‑overtaken street. Nearby towns such as Leadington and Farmington reported dark clouds and baseball‑size hail. The National Weather Service forecasted more storms for Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi River valley, Tennessee River valley, and the southern Great Lakes. CNN’s Sean Morris and Anneclaire Stapleton reported the story.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth straight win and a title shot after losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago. Rockhold plans to play the “bull,” cutting off Machida’s movement, controlling the pace, and using his striking and grappling to dominate, while Machida’s small striking window and limited ground game give Rockhold a larger advantage. Both fighters express mutual respect for each other’s skills, with Rockhold noting Machida’s status as a top martial artist and Machida confident he can upset Rockhold and earn a title shot. Rockhold’s recent victory over Michael Bisping and Machida’s win over CB Dollaway set the stage for the matchup, and both fighters have trained extensively, with Rockhold running marathons and Machida preparing with a full camp.

A light twin‑engine aircraft landed gear‑up at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding along the runway as its propellers ricocheted off the tarmac and the wings bounced; the pilot, 85‑year‑old Chris Georgaklis, immediately re‑engaged the engines, pulled off the runway, and flew the damaged plane 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where it landed safely, accompanied by his dog Buddy. The incident, captured on video by a nearby observer who noted the severe propeller damage and the pilot’s quick recovery, is being investigated by the FAA, with the most common causes cited as human error or mechanical failure.

Manuel Pellegrini has admitted he is disappointed with Manchester City midfielder Yaya Toure’s performances this season but vows to back him until the end of the campaign, even as the club signals it will consider offers for Toure in the summer as it seeks to overhaul an ageing squad. Toure, who has two years left on a £220,000‑a‑week contract, insists he is not ready to leave and rejects the idea of a break, while City’s poor form (18 points from the last 39) and a looming match against West Ham—where captain Vincent Kompany may miss the rest of the season—add pressure. Goalkeeper Joe Hart has urged players to take responsibility for the team’s disappointing results, and Pellegrini stresses that the players are chosen by him. Meanwhile, former West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warns left‑back Aaron Cresswell not to repeat past mistakes as he attracts interest from Chelsea and City, noting Cresswell’s potential to help clubs meet home‑grown quotas and recalling the limited impact of former City players Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65‑year‑old Sicilian mafia “godfather of Uxbridge” who had lived in Britain for over two decades, was convicted in absentia by an Italian court in 1999 and sentenced to seven years for mafia association. After a protracted extradition battle that saw him arrested in London in 2013 and a judge initially refusing extradition on health grounds, he lost a February appeal and was ordered to return to Italy. However, his sentence expired in October 2014, and an Italian court of appeal has now declared the conviction extinguished because it is too old to sustain a prison term. Consequently the European arrest warrant will be withdrawn, allowing Rancadore to remain in the UK; the case will still be reviewed by the Italian Supreme Court, while the Crown Prosecution Service has acknowledged procedural errors that contributed to the delay.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7‑2 co‑favourites in the seven‑runner line‑up for Saturday’s Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, where he will be ridden by Ap McCoy in what is expected to be McCoy’s final Grade One ride. The field also includes Irish raider Special Tiara, Nicky Henderson’s sprinter Sacre (to be ridden by Nico de Boinville after Barry Geraghty’s injury), Mick Channon’s Somersby, and three other rivals. McCoy’s final day as a professional jockey will not be fully booked until Friday morning, and he had shocked the racing world by announcing his retirement after previously winning with Mr Mole at Newbury in February.

Virginia Trimble Ritter’s daughter Marcia was raped and strangled to death by Jerome Sidney Barrett in 1975, with her body discovered 33 days later in a garage under a shower curtain, showing signs of sexual assault and a fractured neck bone; the case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 after a DNA match, convicted in 2009 of second‑degree murder, and sentenced to 44 years. Ritter, who had declined to view crime‑scene photos for decades, finally asked to see them last year, persisted against investigator Mickey Miller’s advice, and was shocked by the images of her daughter’s mutilated body, prompting her to express a desire for revenge and regret for not seeing the photos earlier.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one, says winning the Masters is a career‑long goal that would complete his career grand slam, making him only the sixth player to hold all four major titles. He reflects on his 2011 Augusta collapse as the most important day of his career, learning from the experience and bouncing back to win the U.S. Open, U.S. PGA, The Open and the PGA Championship in 2012 and 2013. Despite only one top‑10 finish in six Masters appearances, he remains determined to claim his first green jacket, believing the course is a sanctuary that helps him cope with pressure. McIlroy also notes personal distractions last year, including a cancelled wedding and a legal dispute, yet he remains focused on using Augusta to achieve his ambition.

The week’s top stories ranged from a New York area rainstorm that produced four rainbows photographed by fashion‑CEO Amanda Curtis, to a rising trend in rural China of hiring exotic dancers at wakes amid a crackdown on vice. Hollywood buzz included RDJ’s frustration over a UK interview, Ewan McGregor’s new role as Lumière in *Beauty and the Beast*, and Johnny Depp’s striking appearance in the *Black Mass* trailer. Viral trends featured a lip‑plumping challenge using a jar with the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge, a 102‑year‑old Alice Barker’s time‑travel film project, a controversial prom‑posal involving bombs that sparked accusations of racism, and quirky pregnancy and photobomb announcements—one referencing *The Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air* and another involving a military dad. All of these stories captured significant online attention.

Hundreds of children were hospitalized last year in England after being born brain‑damaged by fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), with 272 youngsters admitted over the past 12 months, though the true number may be much higher. World Health Organization research estimates that at least one in 100 UK babies—about 7,500 each year—could suffer learning, behavioural and physical problems such as deformed limbs from prenatal alcohol exposure. Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome warns that children with FAS never improve and the condition is vastly under‑diagnosed. A 15‑year‑old named Niamh Brown, diagnosed at age five, illustrates the lifelong challenges, and her adoptive parents founded the FOASD Trust in 2007. Prenatal alcohol can also cause liver, kidney, heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. While the government advises pregnant women not to drink and allows up to two units no more than twice a week if they do, Ms Mitchell argues the guidance should be changed to recommend abstinence entirely.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31‑year‑old ex‑juvenile offender nicknamed “Boomerang Boy” or “Homing Pigeon Boy” for repeatedly returning home after crimes, was arrested after a failed robbery at Shildon Post Office and stores on 15 March. He burst in at 8 pm, brandishing an axe and demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty; owner Sab Dhillon tackled him, causing him to fall and break shelves, while Dhillon’s wife Sam struck him twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. Police arrived minutes later and arrested McKerry, who had previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in prison. McKerry’s criminal history began at age 12 with shoplifting, leading to 80 arrests by age 15 and convictions for aggravated vehicle‑taking, indecent letters, and burglary; he once stole 22 charity boxes while disguised as a woman.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31) and Darren Smalley (35)—were charged in Nova Scotia with gang rape and sexual assault causing bodily harm after an alcohol‑fueled party at the Shearwater naval base, where they had returned from a hockey game. In a Dartmouth courtroom they were granted bail of over £2,000 each but were required to surrender their passports, remain on the Stadacona naval base, stay employed by the Royal Navy, cannot leave Nova Scotia, cannot contact the victim (a Halifax woman in her early 20s) or six witnesses, and must not resign without court permission. They will be tried in Canada, with a return to court scheduled for May 27, and the case is still in early investigation stages, with potential for additional charges; the British high commission is assisting Canadian authorities.

Valerie Jackson’s four‑year‑old son RJ suffers from Netherton’s syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that leaves his skin red, inflamed and scaly, requiring constant application of Vaseline and moisturisers to prevent drying and pain; the condition, affecting roughly 1 in 200,000 births, has no cure and can lead to infection and weight‑gain problems. The Jacksons, who live in Las Vegas, have faced social stigma, bullying, and denial of entry to play centres, and were shocked when a passerby mistakenly reported Valerie to police for child abuse after seeing RJ’s scalded‑like skin, prompting armed officers to surround them in a Walmart; the police later apologized. Valerie, who discovered her son’s diagnosis through a Facebook group for Netherton’s patients, has had to manage RJ’s care while dealing with ignorance and taunts from adults, yet remains determined to explain the disease and protect her son.

Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” campaign, featuring a bikini‑clad model Renee Somerfield on London Underground posters, sparked widespread backlash, with over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority. Transport for London removed the posters after the three‑week paid period, citing the negative reaction, while the company defended the unphotoshopped image as targeting fitness‑conscious consumers. The controversy drew social media outrage, a protest in Hyde Park on May 2, and a bomb threat to Protein World’s head office, prompting police investigation. Despite the backlash, the brand’s head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, insisted the campaign was “fantastic” and would not change its advertising approach, as the ASA continued to assess the complaints amid rising protein powder sales in the UK.

Rail firms announced a series of fare increases, with some routes slated to rise by as much as 87 % from 17 May, prompting Prime Minister David Cameron to write to First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review the plans. Cameron, who has pledged a real‑term fare freeze for the next parliament, is particularly concerned about the 87 % hike on the London‑to‑Cotswolds line that passes through his Witney constituency, where an off‑peak return from Charlbury to London would jump from £33.30 to £62.40. FGW says the change will bring the North Cotswolds route in line with its other services and offers cheaper advance‑single tickets, but other rail operators are also raising prices: an off‑peak first‑class single from Crewe to Northampton will rise from £30 to £37, a Virgin anytime return from Stafford to Liverpool will increase from £26.50 to £33, and a Virgin first‑class day return from Manchester to Stoke will go from £29 to £35.30. Virgin notes that most of its hikes affect “trains‑only” fares, which are at least 20 % cheaper than rivals, and claims its overall West Coast increase is only 1.65 %, below the industry average, while Trainsplit.com reports a 40 % rise in many “anytime” and “off‑peak” returns in January.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his wife Elaine, 54, were attacked at their Oldham home on 18 April when thugs threw stones at the front window and then hurled a brick that shattered the front door and struck Young in the left eye, leaving him permanently blind in that eye after emergency surgery; the couple, newly married three weeks earlier, were writing thank‑you cards when the assault occurred, and police have opened an investigation with no clear motive, suspecting the attackers were simply “yobs messing around.”

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one‑year contract extension after a successful return from injury, having missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident that claimed his father Keith’s life. The former England U‑19 international underwent ankle surgery but made his comeback during Derbyshire’s pre‑season tour of Abu Dhabi, and is now available for the start of the season, with the club committing him until the end of 2016. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton’s exceptional character and hard work both on and off the field, expressing confidence that the new contract will help him continue his good form and express himself on the field this summer.

Five‑year‑old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed with aggressive neuroblastoma that had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs and bones, and he underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, a kidney‑tumour operation, a stem‑cell transplant and weeks of radiotherapy at Christie Clinic, Manchester. During treatment he created a Ninja Turtle mask to keep him still and to give him courage, a story that attracted worldwide headlines, a box of Ninja Turtle gifts from Nickelodeon, and a Cancer Research UK Little Star award; he is now declared cancer‑free, will have regular follow‑ups, and his parents hope he will soon return to full‑time school. The passage also explains that neuroblastoma is a rare childhood cancer of specialised nerve cells, affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, and is the second most common solid tumour in children.

Tim Sherwood urges 19‑year‑old Jack Grealish to prioritise his Aston Villa career over international prospects after Grealish’s standout performance in Villa’s FA Cup semi‑final win over Liverpool, a match that has drawn interest from both the Republic of Ireland and England; Sherwood, who has seen similar dual‑national dilemmas with players like Nabil Bentaleb, stresses that Grealish must continue to cement his place in Villa’s first team before deciding, noting that Grealish’s father Kevin also believes club football should come first, and that Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at season’s end, with a friendly on the horizon that could see him play for both sides.

Private‑jet landing fees vary widely, with some airports charging thousands of dollars per arrival; the trend is driven by a growing market of 2.5 million US and 705,000 European private flights in 2013, worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. High‑fee hubs include Japan’s three most expensive airports—Haneda (£4,559), Narita (£3,728) and Kansai (£3,594)—followed by Toronto Pearson (£3,461), Darwin (£3,059), Bristol (£2,929), Chubu Centrair (£2,863), Dublin (£2,729), LaGuardia (£2,630) and Salzburg (£2,530). Popular routes such as Los Angeles‑Las Vegas (£2,890) and Milan‑Rome ($5,880) illustrate the cost of private travel, while major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix trigger the busiest weekends, with round‑trip estimates from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl at £38,000–£54,000. The list of top ten landing‑fee airports highlights unexpected appearances, including the UK’s Bristol and the US’s LaGuardia, and underscores how even smaller airports like Salzburg and Darwin can command high fees for private jets.

Katie Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort in Clackamas County, Oregon, frequently takes her dogs Cooper the Labrador and Daisy the small pup to fast‑food spots, most notably a McDonald’s drive‑thru where Cooper devours an ice‑cream cone in one bite while Daisy takes a few licks; the clip has amassed more than seven million views. Some viewers have criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs the creamy treat, but she defends it by noting Cooper’s good health and that he has had ice cream weekly. She has also posted a video of the pair at Starbucks for a “pup‑uccino,” a cup of whipped cream with no coffee, which Cooper again consumes in one go.

Gary Locke, the former Hearts manager, has been appointed permanently as Kilmarnock’s manager after a successful interim spell, signing a three‑year contract. He joined the club as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer, stepped up when Johnston resigned in February, and has lost only once in seven matches at Rugby Park. Locke will speak at a press conference on Friday morning, and he has signed the deal with chairman Jim Mann.

Jessica Kemp of Eustis says teachers at Seminole County Elementary threatened to suspend her five‑year‑old autistic son Logan for using Doterra essential oils, claiming the scents of lavender, chamomile and sandalwood were distracting to other students; she applies the oils to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Kemp received a letter from the local school board stating the oils had created a “problem” for staff and students, yet she insists the use has a positive impact and will continue to fight the decision. On Thursday, Lake County School District announced it would not suspend Logan, citing the use of the oils as a health issue.

The Sandpiper complex, a beach‑side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach that operates from May to November, was devastated by a fire that began around 3 p.m. on Wednesday, burning through 90 condos, melting paint on nearby buildings, and producing black smoke visible from three miles away. Despite the deployment of 12 fire crews and the use of cranes, firefighters could not penetrate the structure, which eventually collapsed. Residents such as Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber reported losing everything, while witness Dave Rose described the flames. Westhampton fire chief Ross Donneson noted the offshore wind helped visibility, and investigators are looking into whether the blaze started near a car parked by the complex.

Queen Elizabeth II, now 88, was seen riding her black fell pony Carltonlima Emma through Windsor Great Park, choosing a silk scarf over a helmet—a habit she has maintained since childhood when she first rode a Shetland pony named Peggy. Though her knee injury has cut back her time in the saddle and forced her to stop presiding over trooping the colour, she remains an avid equestrian, breeding fell ponies at Hampton Court and a highland pony stud at Balmoral, with her grandchildren, notably Prince Edward’s children, also riding her horses. The passage also traces the fell pony’s long history—from Neolithic moorlands to Roman trade goods, Viking pack animals, and modern family riding—highlighting its hardy, docile nature and its rise as a popular riding pony in the 1950s.

An argument over noise between Brisbane neighbours ended in tragedy when 55‑year‑old Leon Yeaman was killed by a single punch to the head from 28‑year‑old Phillip Pama during a row outside their North Brisbane homes; Yeaman was reportedly making loud music in his yard at about 9 pm on Thursday, while Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am warehouse shift, was sleeping. Pama, who has no prior violent history, was granted conditional bail on Friday after the incident, with a court order requiring him to surrender his passport, observe a 6 pm‑2 am curfew, and report to police twice weekly. Paramedics could not revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead around 11 pm, and Pama faces a manslaughter charge with the case set to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52‑year‑old music teacher in Shatura, tried to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15‑year‑old pupil Damian Vanya after he ended their affair and began dating a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (about £1,400) and demanded the boy be beaten, have his limbs broken and bleed out before she “finished” him. Police set up a sting, an undercover officer posed as the killer and a hidden camera recorded the exchange; Simonova handed over money and was arrested in her car, now facing 15 years in prison on attempted‑murder charges. The teen had previously been showered with gifts by the teacher before the breakup.

Chelsea manager José Mourinho, a father of two, says he talks to God every day but never about football or with his wife, focusing his prayers on personal matters and family. He maintains a clear separation between his professional and private life, describing himself as a good family man and friend who supports people he doesn’t even know. Mourinho has worked as an ambassador for the World Food Programme, citing his awareness of poverty. Though he rarely attends church—only when he feels the need, especially in Portugal—he remains a strong believer. The article notes Chelsea are top of the league and that Mourinho was fined £25,000 earlier this season for claiming a campaign against the club after Cesc Fàbregas was booked for diving. His son, José Mário, celebrated Chelsea’s Capital One Cup win with teammates.

Bob Barker returned to host “The Price Is Right” for the first time in eight years on the April 1 episode, stepping in for Drew Carey. At 91, Barker handled the opening “Lucky Seven” price‑guessing game before handing over the reins to Carey, showing he still performed flawlessly after his long absence.

Off‑duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 a.m. on Friday in the 3200 block of D Street SE, Washington, D.C., after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight; he faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin, who is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch that handles U.S. diplomatic activities, is scheduled to be arraigned that afternoon, though no attorney has been listed. His arrest follows a separate incident in which a high‑ranking supervisor was put on leave amid misconduct allegations, and the Inspector General is also investigating a March 4 incident involving two senior officials allegedly driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

Atif Saeed, a 38‑year‑old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life in the city’s safari park to photograph a hungry male lion from about ten feet away. He left his car, crept toward the lion armed only with a camera, and captured a few frames before the shutter’s click alerted the animal, which aggressively lunged at him. Saeed had to retreat quickly to his car, and he later reflected that he would not repeat such a dangerous stunt.

New York City police released an image of a faded heart‑shaped tattoo with the name “Monique” on the right leg of an unidentified woman who died on March 22 in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious, could not be revived, and was pronounced dead that evening. The tattoo, described as a ribbon‑shaped name inside a heart topped with a rose, is being used to help identify her while investigators await a medical examiner’s report on the cause of death; anyone with information is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800‑577‑TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, returned from the UK in 2009 and, unable to afford a traditional property, bought a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent a year and a half building a solar‑powered, two‑bedroom home on its bed. The structure, made of wood and steel with a wood‑fired stove, stained‑glass windows, and a loft for their cat, sits on a lot they purchased in Nelson and is powered mainly by solar panels, with gas for heating and hot water and water from a nearby spring. The project cost about $25,000, left them nearly self‑sufficient, and they now enjoy a cozy, nature‑surrounded dwelling and plan to build another similar home.

Research by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University shows that kindergarten students who share iPads in class score about 30 points higher on early literacy tests than peers who either use a personal device or have no device, suggesting that collaborative learning around shared technology, rather than individual use, boosts literacy. The study involved 352 students in a Midwestern suburban district and highlights that schools may need to rethink tablet use in early grades to maximize effectiveness, a finding she will present at the 65th International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai, Sichuan, has become an internet sensation after a video showed it learning to walk on its front trotters, wobbling yet regaining balance while foraging and mingling with its fully‑legged siblings; the farmer, Ms. Duan, noted the anomaly when feeding the litter, and the clip has attracted thousands of viewers, echoing earlier Chinese animal stars such as a Liuzhou zoo rabbit that also walks on its front paws.

Todd Phillips, a front‑outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone’s car spun while exiting the pit box on lap 25 during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, clipping Phillips’ leg; Phillips received stitches at the infield care center and was released. The race was hampered by traction issues from heavy rain, and Dracone, a 19‑year‑old Italian, failed to finish, ultimately placing 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his 29‑year‑old dancer wife Cicera Alves de Sena in Rio de Janeiro, smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her face five times after accusing her of being a “slut” and expressing jealousy over men admiring her. The brutal act was captured on CCTV, and a neighbor reported hearing an argument before gunshots. Severiano fled in a stolen car, but police recovered four handguns, a shotgun and a bullet‑proof vest, and he was arrested; he now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, a 41‑year‑old journalist and author of the best‑selling book *I Quit Sugar*, revealed in a candid interview that anxiety, combined with stress, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation, pushed her to a point where she considered her life not worth living and nearly took her own life. She described feeling alone, lacking a husband or children, and seeing no way out, while noting that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that anxiety is becoming the “new depression.” Wilson now accepts her anxious nature, reports having found some peace, and urges recognition of the link between anxiety and depression to better address the rising rates of mental illness among Australian women, citing a Beyond Blue report that one in three women will experience anxiety in their lifetime and providing contact details for help.

Elena Curtin, a 23‑year‑old Portland woman who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second‑degree assault after she struck her boyfriend’s former girlfriend with a crowbar when the ex was found using heroin in Curtin’s bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was “completely justified in her outrage.” Curtin had previously been harassed and threatened by the ex, who had a history of drug use and had repeatedly tried to involve the boyfriend in addiction. The boyfriend, the father of Curtin’s child, had struggled with heroin in the past but has since reconciled with Curtin, who now lives with her parents; the boyfriend has not been involved in the child’s life. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.

Gemma the pit bull, filmed at her California home, is shown being fed treats while her owner attempts to trick her with a broccoli spear; she immediately shows disgust, chomps the vegetable, and spits it out on the floor, prompting a hope that the children she lives with won’t imitate her dislike of greens. Other videos depict Gemma simply sleeping and relaxing with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website that was meant to lead to its Young Entrepreneur Awards page—now shut down—redirected visitors to a pornographic site that had taken over the address after the awards were scrapped in 2011. The bank removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, and assured the public that its website remains secure, while noting that its internet‑banking service still allows customers to check balances, transfer funds, and apply for loans and insurance.

A 13‑year‑old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 before 7 a.m. after a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, where he and his 9‑year‑old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second‑floor bedroom. During an 11‑minute call he calmly instructed the dispatcher to go up the back hallway steps to a black door, soothed his sister who feared they would die, and told her to stay low and breathe. Prince George’s County firefighters entered the house, broke a window, and rescued the siblings; firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out the window to another rescuer, who then gave his gas mask to the girl. The siblings were taken to a children’s hospital with non‑life‑threatening injuries, while the other family members—Marcus’s older brother, mother, and step‑father—escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae, specifically Noctiluca scintillans, have illuminated beaches along Australia’s east coast, with vivid images captured in Jervis Bay by photographer Andy Hutchinson who called the sight a “beautiful supernatural scene.” A similar glow was seen at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014, and oceanography experts have said there is no cause for concern. Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales explains that the single‑cell phytoplankton blooms in spring and autumn, occurs naturally 90 % of the time, preys on diatoms, and emits light as a defensive mechanism.

New genetic tests such as Endopredict analyse tumour samples sent to a lab after surgery, providing a risk score for breast‑cancer recurrence within days; a low score can be as low as 5 %, comparable to or better than the benefit of chemotherapy, allowing patients to forgo the drug’s severe side effects. While most women still receive chemotherapy routinely, experts argue that recurrence risk varies and that many could safely avoid treatment, with the test’s cost (~£2,500) potentially offset by savings if adopted by the NHS. Surgeons like Hemant Singhal and Professor Kefah Mokbel support the test’s use to give patients informed choices, as illustrated by 49‑year‑old Becca Cornford, who after a second breast cancer diagnosis and a low Endopredict score was advised that chemotherapy offered little additional benefit and that regular monitoring could catch any return early.

More than 25 women have been air‑lifted from Royal Navy ships because of pregnancy, with HMS Ocean alone accounting for five emergency evacuations over nine years and HMS Illustrious (nicknamed “HMS Lusty”) also sending a woman home; other vessels such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise and HMS Richmond had similar emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman said a strict “no touching” rule is in place at sea, implying most pregnancies were conceived before boarding or during leave. The data came nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to command a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member, leading to her replacement and an investigation. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, making up about 9 % of personnel in 2014, and in May 2023 the first female submariners joined the service. Nearly 100 British soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan for pregnancy (99 between 2006‑2013, 16 in 2013, 18 in 2011) and 102 were evacuated from Iraq; strict rules ban mothers‑to‑be from war zones, and pregnant servicewomen are returned at the first convenient opportunity, often on flights reserved for injured troops, with no mandatory pregnancy tests.

A drone carrying a plastic bottle with traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s Tokyo residence, prompting police to investigate its origin; the drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a 50‑centimeter frame, was deemed not immediately harmful but raised concerns about potential drone‑based terrorism, prompting Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga to warn of possible attacks at future events such as the Olympics and G7 summit and to call for continuous review of drone regulations, especially since flight restrictions are limited around most Tokyo government sites.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang Province, China, carries his 84‑year‑old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer’s, on the back of his motorbike to work every day, tying a sash around both of their waists to keep her from falling. After his father’s death and with no other family to care for her, he began this routine, waking her at 5 am, riding the four kilometres to his bank job slowly, and checking on her during the hour‑long commute and at work where she has her own room. He feels a duty to reciprocate the care his mother gave him, and the arrangement has touched many across the country.

A 2012 study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking in the United States rose 17.2 % from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by women, and that binge‑drinking rates among women increased more than sevenfold relative to men, with Santa Clara County women’s binge rates up 36 % and nationwide binge rates at 18 % versus 8 % heavy drinkers. County‑level data show wide variation (e.g., Menominee, Wisconsin, 36 % binge vs. Madison County, Idaho, 6 %). Despite these rises, overall alcohol consumption has stayed roughly constant. The study links the trend to changing social norms that make heavy drinking more acceptable for women, rising disposable income among affluent professionals, lower real‑price alcohol, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol‑control policies, noting that 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 were alcohol‑related and the cost of excess drinking exceeds $220 billion annually.

Doctors are performing caesarean sections in England too often, putting mothers and babies at risk of infections, death and long‑term health problems, warns the WHO and UN public‑health agency, which says the ideal rate should be 10–15 % but the current rate is over 25 % and has doubled since the early 1990s. The procedure, which costs the NHS £2,369 versus £1,665 for a natural birth, is frequently carried out even when medically unnecessary, contrary to NHS guidelines that allow it for non‑medical reasons such as anxiety (tokophobia) or previous complications, and NICE’s 2011 recommendations that permit it for anxious women. WHO highlights that up to one in ten caesareans can cause infections and that the practice diverts funds from other patients.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after owner Mark Conklin discovered her sitting in his summer home on Court Street in Edgartown; she allegedly broke in, lived there for at least a week, and sold or gave away items in a yard sale. Conklin found her claiming ownership, and she fled in a gray Nissan pickup when he called police. Police later found a broken window covered by a blanket and discovered that Filkins had taken items such as deck chairs, a Weber grill, side tables, lamps, posters, pots, pans, linens, and a painting. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, and is scheduled to appear in court on May 14. The police are asking anyone who received stolen items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Police recovered Bella Crooke’s lost iPhone at Albury police station on the NSW‑Victoria border after she reported it missing from a friend’s birthday party; the unlocked phone was used by officers to post selfies, puns and humorous updates on her Facebook page, encouraging her to pick it up and reassuring her that it was safe and fully charged. The posts, which included pictures of the phone in a “holding cell” and jokes about its battery, were shared by Bella’s friends who dubbed the officers “legends.” When Bella arrived at the station, she was recognized from her Facebook profile and did not need to provide her name to reclaim the device, after which she added a password. Police also replied to texts from friends in a similarly lighthearted manner.

A five‑day‑old baby hippopotamus was caught in a violent fight between two adult males in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa, and was hurled into the air, dragged across the water, and died hours later; its mother watched in horror while tour operator Stacey Farrell also witnessed the incident, noting that the mother had stayed with her herd to keep the calf safe, but the sub‑adult male grabbed the calf, forcing the mother to attack and ultimately causing the calf to be flung and killed.

A three‑bedroom flat in Knightsbridge is listed for £575,000 but has only three years left on its lease, meaning the annual cost would be about £191,000 (≈£15,000 a month), roughly the local rental rate; if the lease were extended it could be worth up to £6 million. The same price is also being offered for a 1,990‑sq‑ft unmodernised maisonette in Egerton Place, which also has a three‑year lease and needs renovation, while a larger 2,500‑sq‑ft maisonette on the same street is listed for £595,000. The freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, and extending a 90‑year lease could cost between £3.35 million and £4.5 million. Agents note the rarity of such short‑lease properties in Knightsbridge, warn of the high premium to extend the lease, and highlight that the properties could fetch £2,750–£3,000 per sq ft once modernised, potentially reaching £6–£7.5 million in value.

Starbucks experienced a nationwide computer outage on Friday evening that disabled point‑of‑sale registers at about 8,000 stores across the U.S. and Canada, prompting baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods while some locations closed early to avoid distributing free products; the glitch began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast, affected 7,000 U.S. and 1,000 Canadian stores, and was later attributed to a failure during a daily system refresh, with the company stating the issue was resolved and stores would reopen for “business as usual.” The incident sparked a flurry of social‑media posts from customers sharing photos of free frappuccinos, mochas, and lattes, and coincided with a 4.4 % rise in Starbucks shares following record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Terrorist training and radicalisation are taking place in rural West Wales, with Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire identified as key sites by the Wales Extremism and Counter‑Terrorism Unit; Detective Constable Gareth Jones notes that such activity is hidden behind ordinary community participation and stresses that terrorism is not limited to cities. Historical incidents cited include Abu Hamza’s 1998 training of 10 extremists in the Brecon Beacons, 2005 white‑water rafting photos of 7/7 bombers Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer, a 2010 Cardiff al‑Qaeda‑inspired gang plot, and the conviction of Michael Adebowale for the murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby, who had studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead near Llangybydder. Additional figures—Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai and Abdul Miah—were photographed meeting Mohammed Chowdhury and Shah Rahman in a Welsh country park, with the institute reportedly set up by Iraqi clerics. Jones underscores the importance of community intelligence in identifying and countering such threats.

A juvenile Omura’s whale, a species once thought extinct and first recorded in Western Australia and only the second sighting in Australia, washed up on a remote Exmouth beach after Cyclone Olwyn. The 5.68‑metre female was identified through DNA profiling, prompting the environment minister to highlight the find’s importance for understanding a species described only in 2003 and known to inhabit tropical and subtropical waters such as Indonesia, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan. The whale’s distinctive anatomy—53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin—will be studied after the carcass is buried and the skeleton recovered in a few years for scientific research and potential museum display.

The article argues that hormones influence political decision‑making, citing Cheryl Rios, a Texas marketing CEO, who claims women’s hormones make them irrational and unsuitable for the presidency, specifically criticizing Hillary Clinton while suggesting Bush’s war was testosterone‑driven; it then shifts to a broader critique of gender bias, noting studies that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks, citing Adam Grant and Sheryl Sandberg’s work on workplace bias, and arguing that bias against women limits their potential despite equal or greater representation in education and the workforce, concluding that ending gender stereotypes benefits companies, families, and society, and correcting a prior error about Canada’s first female prime minister.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is auctioning more than 200 antiques—including a 1960s hand‑painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, early Victorian furniture, a yew longbow with a mother‑of‑pearl handle, portraits, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and 17th‑century books—for an estimated £100,000 as he downsizes his Cotswold home. The sale, run by Dominic Winter in South Cerney, Gloucestershire on Saturday, will feature 238 lots and is a reflection of Hardy’s lifelong passion for classic literature and military history, a passion that also shaped his acting career (notably as Winston Churchill, a vet in *All Creatures Great and Small*, and Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films). Hardy, who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and has published works on the medieval longbow, expressed sadness at parting with his collection but hopes new owners will enjoy it as he has.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a Florida man on the run after police named him a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead at their Winter Garden home when an out‑of‑state family member called a well‑being check. Shemansky failed to attend a supervised visit with his son on the same day, and neighbors say his divorce and a domestic‑violence injunction filed by his estranged wife may have pushed him to commit the crime. He is already on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar disorder and was involuntarily committed after an attempted suicide. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not yet confirmed the method of death; Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication after reportedly asking for water at the trailer park office. His wife is preparing to protect herself if he arrives at her home, and anyone with information is urged to contact authorities.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council awarded Eugene, Oregon, the rights to host the 2021 World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process by citing a unique strategic opportunity to hold the event in the United States for the first time. Eugene had previously lost its bid for the 2019 championships, which went to Doha, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF that the city could stage the event. IAAF President Lamine Diack highlighted the collaboration of public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public as key to this decision, noting that it departs from normal procedure but serves global sport development. The passage also references the 2007 Osaka championships, which were similarly awarded without a bid, and notes Mo Farah’s gold medal in the men’s 10,000 m at the 2013 Moscow championships.

Leonie Granger, a 25‑year‑old aspiring model, lured 56‑year‑old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to a London casino and then to his flat, where she let her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler enter. The trio tied Hassan up, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home for hidden cash. Granger was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and received life sentences with minimum terms of 36 years. The court described the attack as “pitiless and wicked,” and the defendants were also found guilty of robbery, conspiracy to falsely imprison, and related offences.

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea’s midfield playmaker, has entered a well‑known post‑Christmas slump, with his form dropping sharply after a strong start to the season. He was one of the weakest performers in Spain’s 2‑0 loss to the Netherlands, earning only four out of ten from a Spanish paper, and has managed just one Premier League assist in his last five games, falling short of Thierry Henry’s 20‑assist record. Despite a brief resurgence in January and an assist for Diego Costa in a 3‑2 win over Hull City, Mourinho remains concerned about Fabregas’s fatigue and durability as Chelsea chase the title, needing up to six wins from nine remaining fixtures to secure the championship.

West Ham are close to signing 17‑year‑old Jamaican striker Deshane Beckford after a two‑week trial impressed academy coaches, with the forward also attracting offers from Belgian clubs and other European teams and being touted as one of the Caribbean’s hottest prospects; meanwhile the club announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will start at £289 to help fill the 54,000‑seat venue for the 2016‑17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into a violent assault on 40‑year‑old huntsman Mike Lane, joint master of the Tedworth hunt, three months after the incident, citing insufficient evidence despite a dossier of evidence—including names and car registration numbers—and a video that captured the face of the attacker. Lane was beaten by balaclava‑clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes during a January 24 attack at Everleigh near Amesbury, where 30 riders and hounds were chasing an artificial scent; he was knocked to the ground, kicked in the head, suffered a concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling and memory loss, and has paid £500 for dental treatment. The attackers sprayed hounds with citronella, approached from 250 yards away, and used abusive tactics, with one kicking Lane and another swinging a rope with an iron bar. The suspect’s photograph was released but remains unidentified. Lane, Karen Fieldsend, and Tedworth vice‑chairman James Cameron have expressed anger at the police decision, and the Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings so that perpetrators can be identified and prosecuted. Wiltshire Police say the case is recorded as undetected and may be reopened if further evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, born in 1978 and known as “Azzam the American,” was an American citizen who converted to Islam in 1995, left the United States for Pakistan in 1998, and became Al Qaeda’s chief English‑language propagandist, appearing in videos that threatened attacks on U.S. cities, criticized U.S. presidents, urged lone‑wolf attacks, and praised extremist actions; he was indicted in 2006 on treason and material‑support charges, was listed among the FBI’s most wanted terrorists, and was killed in January 2015 in a U.S. counter‑terrorism strike that also killed fellow U.S. citizen Ahmed Farouq, while another U.S. hostage, Warren Weinstein, died in the same operation.

A five‑year‑old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become a viral sensation after a video shows him scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, skills he has practiced since age two‑and‑a‑half. The clip has attracted millions of viewers and sparked widespread admiration across China, with netizens praising his talent and comparing it to professional players, while some express envy or disbelief. Mai’s performance has positioned him as a rising basketball star in a country where the most famous player to date is Yao Ming.

Tom O’Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key activist for the paedophile information exchange (PIE), has joined the media‑pressure group Hacked Off and attended a rally in the Houses of Parliament on 25 February to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, formed after the phone‑hacking scandal, campaigns against the independent press standards organisation and seeks a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson inquiry. O’Carroll’s support is embarrassing for Hacked Off, given PIE’s 1974 founding to legalise child sex, its alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to lower the age of consent and legalise incest, and O’Carroll’s own 1981 conviction for corrupting public morals; he later wrote a blog confirming his attendance at the rally chaired by comedian John Cleese.

Bondi’s Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a beach‑side catwalk for Mercedes‑Benz Fashion Week Australia, where the Ten Pieces label showcased a monochrome capsule of ten unisex garments designed to be worn in 20 ways; models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop while guests enjoyed nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria, all under a warm 28 °C day that drew crowds from the balcony, the road above, and the beach itself.

Amir Khan, the 28‑year‑old Bolton‑born boxer, spent a Friday with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa on a family trip to a safari park in Northern California, where he posed with giraffes, sea lions and fed a rare white tiger. Earlier that week he confirmed his next bout will be against former light‑welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation that he might face British rival Kell Brook, Adrien Broner or Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16‑year‑old Palestinian who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name added to Jerusalem’s Mount Herzl memorial wall for fallen soldiers and terrorism victims; his family and the victim‑rights group Almagor objected, arguing he was not a terror victim and that his name should not be listed alongside soldiers, leading Almagor’s CEO Meir Indor to write to the National Insurance Institute demanding removal, which the institute complied with after the father’s complaint, while a judicial panel continues to hear evidence against the three suspects.

Lionel Hutz, a California‑based YouTube user, filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden in an attempt to use the feline’s belly as a pillow. The footage shows the cat licking its fur, the boy plopping himself on top, then the cat immediately getting up and moving to another spot, prompting the boy to follow. This sequence repeats a few times until the cat finally leaves, after which a later video shows the boy and cat reconciling, with the boy gently feeding the cat handfuls of treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, but one witness, 32‑year‑old former drug dealer Robert Kushner, has already faced consequences: he lost his varsity basketball coaching position at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past marijuana sales. Kushner, who was hired in 2010 after a background check, admitted to a 2007 arrest in which undercover officers allegedly stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him, and he also revealed a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI. He claims the 2007 charges were expunged and that he has moved past that period, expressing remorse and a desire to do right for the kids. The trial involves more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government against a group of undercover officers charged with racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing. Kushner maintains his innocence regarding the 2011 charges and says he never intended to deceive the school, while his summer league coaching work is praised by a director. Lawyers for the accused officers argue the case relies on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex‑cop.

An explosion at a controversial paraxylene plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, injured six people—five by broken glass—and sparked a large fire that was brought under control by over 600 firefighters; no toxic chemical spill was reported. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, and residents nearby posted photos and reports of the incident. The plant, which had previously exploded in July 2013 without casualties, was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated to a more remote site in 2007 following pollution protests that have sometimes turned violent.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager, has publicly defended his habit of keeping his socks low and wearing children’s shinpads, insisting it is a lifelong superstition that he will not abandon despite referees urging him to change. He explained to the BBC that he has not yet suffered a shin injury and hopes to avoid one. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3‑3 draw against QPR, a tough relegation‑scrap match, and expressed pride in the manager’s confidence in him, hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22‑year‑old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has been reported by her grandmother to suffer global irreversible brain damage; she is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive, does not react to visitors or familiar voices, her eyes do not follow people, and she has a tracheostomy. Two days after her father Bobby Brown announced that she was “awake” and watching him, an attorney for the family said her condition has improved but that the quality of her life and the type of life she will lead remain uncertain, noting she will have a long life and is beginning a difficult rehabilitation process. Bobby Brown, emotional on stage, and his wife Alicia Etheredge‑Brown confirmed that she has left the ICU, opened her eyes, and that her rehabilitation will be long and hard.

Russia leads the Fed Cup tie 2‑0 after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Germany’s Sabine Lisicki 4‑6, 7‑6(4), 6‑3, while Svetlana Kuznetsova earlier beat Julia Goerges in straight sets; both matches featured serve issues, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki committing 63 unforced errors, and Russia now needs one win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and secure its first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are warned of further flooding and damage as another east‑coast low is expected to hit the state later this week, bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday; meteorologists note the system will differ from last week’s three‑day storm, likely sparing Sydney but affecting the far north and the Hunter region, which suffered severe flooding and high winds. The State Emergency Service is overwhelmed, with over 4,000 of 24,196 clean‑up jobs still pending, and has urged communities—especially in the Hunter—to prepare homes and families for additional weather, while 1,000 personnel, including 200 from other states, are deployed to assist. Weather forecasts for Sydney, Newcastle, Gosford and Wollongong predict showers and possible late showers, with temperatures ranging from 13 to 22 °C.

Nina Moric, a 38‑year‑old model who appeared in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loco” video, posted photos of bruises on her arms and denied reports that she had attempted suicide. She said she collapsed at home on Saturday night because of low blood pressure, fell and hit her head, was taken to hospital, and is now recovering at home after a brief stay. Italian media had claimed she had tried to kill herself in 2009 and that her mother found her in her Milan apartment, but Moric insists the stories are inaccurate, noting her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso was in Naples at the time. The article also notes her former marriage to jailed paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who was convicted of blackmailing celebrities.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times found that 12 % of 2,200 Britons would name a future daughter of Kate and William “Diana,” the late Princess of Wales, with Alice and Charlotte each receiving 9 %. If the baby were a boy, 13 % would choose “James” and “Alexander” would be second. About a quarter of respondents wanted a girl, while only 3 % hoped for a younger brother. The poll also showed 68 % support for William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job, and social media users expressed strong enthusiasm for the “Diana” name.

A suicide bomber detonated near a protest group in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 and wounding dozens, including an Afghan lawmaker; the Taliban spokesman denied responsibility and no other group claimed the attack, which occurred around 10 a.m. as protesters were heading to join a larger rally against the provincial governor, according to police and eyewitness accounts.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club’s final contract offer, according to his agent Dinorah Santana. The 31‑year‑old Brazilian right‑back, who has spent seven successful seasons with the club and won four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, could not agree on a new deal that would have required him to play 60 % of matches. Santana confirmed that negotiations are over and that Alves will depart the Nou Camp.

Pablo Osvaldo, the 29‑year‑old Argentine striker on loan from Southampton who has already scored three goals in six games for Boca Juniors, is urging Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him in Buenos Aires. He says the duo would fit Boca’s style, that the Bombonera fans would love them, and that Pirlo’s world‑class midfielding and Totti’s Roma legend status would make them popular in Argentina. Osvaldo believes their “South‑American style” would be perfect for the club and that the stadium would go crazy for their arrival.

18‑year‑old amateur jockey Lee Lewis Ferguson, who was mucking out stables at Paul Nicholls’ yard on Thursday morning, suffered a spectacular double‑somersault fall from the favourite Merrion Square at Wincanton at 4:20 pm, leaving him with a cut on his nose and making him an internet sensation after the video was viewed hundreds of thousands of times; he watched the replay, noted that other jockeys looked away in horror, and despite some abuse from fellow riders, he has returned to riding, gained a few hundred Twitter followers, and joked that he might pursue a gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, celebrated the release of *Avengers: Age of Ultron* by posting an Instagram photo of himself in an Iron Man costume, echoing the film’s premiere at Westfield London and the star‑studded cast of Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who began his career with Wasps in 2002, spent eight seasons there before moving to Stade Français (2009‑2011), Ricoh Black Rams in Japan (2011), and the Highlanders in New Zealand (2011‑2012) before returning to Wasps in 2012; since his return he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 England caps.

Wide‑leg trousers are the defining SS15 trend, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans and a nod to the seventies. Fashion insiders like Louise Redknapp praise the style as a welcome relief, noting that the key to pulling it off—especially for shorter figures—is a high‑heeled shoe and a simple top to balance the voluminous leg. Denim is the easiest way to adopt the look, with Gucci’s SS15 runway featuring flared denim, while Celine and Stella McCartney showcased dressier, billowing bottoms. Topshop’s Miller jean and Finery London’s affordable versions give high‑street options, and the silhouette works year‑round, as seen when Poppy Delevingne wore it at the AW15 Chloe show. For inspiration and shopping, astylealbum.com offers curated looks.

The University of Michigan chose to go ahead with a campus screening of “American Sniper” as part of its UMIX social‑events series, despite a petition signed by more than 200 students who opposed the film’s portrayal of the Iraq war and its potential negative impact on Middle‑Eastern communities, noting Detroit’s large Arab‑American population. The decision was reversed after backlash and a counter‑petition, and Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper declared the cancellation a mistake, reaffirming the university’s commitment to freedom of expression and student choice; the screening will proceed, with an alternative “Paddington” showing offered, and the move was praised by football coach Jim Harbaugh.

On April 3, two French tourists aged 18 and 24 set a quokka on fire with an aerosol spray on Rottnest Island off Perth, singeing the animal but not killing it; detectives seized video evidence, questioned the men, and evicted them from the island. Both were charged with animal cruelty and are scheduled to appear before Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, which are native to small islands off Western Australia’s coast—including Rottnest and Bald Island near Albany—were the victims of this reckless act.

102‑year‑old Alice Barker, a former dancer in New York nightspots such as the Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen footage of herself despite having been filmed; her photographs and memorabilia were lost over time. Mark Cantor of jazz‑on‑film.com and volunteers compiled a video of early “soundies” (music videos) and showed it to Barker at her nursing home, where she was delighted to finally see herself dancing.

A recent OSV survey of 1,100 adults found that 31 % of men and 75 % of women have never washed their own cars, with only 12 % of those who do doing it regularly; just 5 % have ever asked their children to wash for pocket money.  Drivers tend to use local forecourt car washes, a trend attributed to Sunday shop openings, more live football, the rise of hand car washes, and the difficulty of cleaning large 4×4s.  Car washing spikes during holidays – Easter saw an estimated 15 million owner‑cleaned cars – and one in four wash only to get out of the house.  Frequency varies by city, highest in Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield, lowest in Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh, and by brand, with Audis, Toyotas and BMWs most often washed by owners and Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes least.  OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley lamented the loss of the once‑national Sunday car‑washing tradition, noting that time constraints, larger cars and cheaper alternatives now dominate.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard’s influence at Liverpool, saying he helped Skrtel settle when he joined in 2008 and that Gerrard remains “one of the best players in the world”; Skrtel noted that Liverpool will be a different side without Gerrard but believes the club has players who can fill the void if given the right support. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with the aim of ending his career in the final on his birthday (May 30) before moving to LA Galaxy, and both he and Skrtel could return to the lineup after serving three‑match bans for violent conduct in a March defeat to Manchester United.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole‑in‑one on the 130‑yard fourth during Augusta National’s par‑3 contest, becoming the first to ace that hole on the course; the same day Camilo Villegas later matched him with five aces, a record that tied the 2002 mark. Nicklaus, who played alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, had earlier become the youngest green‑jacket wearer in 1963, won his sixth major in 1986, and is one of only five men to complete the career grand slam.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as several storms produced multiple tornado reports, including one about 6 mi northwest of Goddard (less than 17 mi west of Wichita) that moved northeast and missed the city but posed risks to nearby communities. CNN severe‑weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly. Additional sightings came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna (125 mi southwest of Wichita). The storms also affected Missouri, where the National Weather Service said a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, about 70 mi from St. Louis; residents reported wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, roof damage, and a street overtaken by water. Nearby towns such as Leadington and Farmington saw dark clouds and hail described as “baseball‑size.” The Weather Service forecasted more storms for Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi River valley, the Tennessee River valley, and the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73‑year‑old reserve deputy for the Tulsa County sheriff’s office, was charged with second‑degree manslaughter after he fatally shot Eric Harris during a weapons sting on April 2, claiming he intended to use a taser but mistakenly fired a gun; he pleaded not guilty and the judge allowed him to take a family vacation to the Bahamas, a decision that angered Harris’s family, who view it as apathy. Bates has apologized, and his lawyer, Clark Brewster, says the case will be heard in court rather than the media, with a preliminary hearing set for July 2. The family’s lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and a friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz, while Tulsa World reported that supervisors were instructed to forge Bates’s records and were reassigned if they refused; the sheriff’s office denies these claims. Bates’s lawyer released training documents to demonstrate proper law‑enforcement training, and two deputies involved in Harris’s arrest were reassigned after threats to them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against José Aldo on July 11, during which he has revealed a new tiger‑face tattoo on his stomach, following a gorilla‑heart design on his chest. He has publicly criticized Aldo’s motivation, claiming the champion is reluctant to face him and that McGregor is more driven to win the belt, which he seized from Aldo during a promotional tour in Dublin and displayed to 5,000 fans, underscoring their tense rivalry as the fight approaches.

Tony Abbott, the Australian prime minister, drew criticism after he skolling a schooner of beer at a university of technology Sydney event, an act that anti‑drinking campaigners say glorifies binge drinking and equates masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert condemned the display as problematic, arguing it promotes a culture where drinking is measured by speed and quantity rather than socialising, and warned that such performances can erode personal limits. Opposition leader Bill Shorten mocked Abbott’s “learning to drink beer without lemonade,” while health minister Sussan Ley defended the PM, suggesting that if more people exercised as hard as Abbott, the country would be healthier. The incident, which saw Abbott finish the beer in about six seconds amid cheers, sparked debate over whether public figures should model responsible drinking and reflected shifting attitudes toward alcohol in Australia.

Indiana’s HIV outbreak has surged after Gov. Mike Pence approved a 30‑day needle‑exchange program in Scott County, a rural area north of Louisville that normally sees about five HIV cases per year. Since the program began on March 26, 5,322 clean syringes have been distributed to 86 participants and 1,400 used syringes returned, yet confirmed cases rose to 120 with 10 preliminary positives—up from 106 the week before—prompting officials to expect further increases as testing expands. The outbreak centers on intravenous drug users, mainly those using the powerful painkiller Opana, and is linked to high hepatitis C rates, which the CDC says often co‑occur with HIV. Pence, who opposes needle exchanges as an anti‑drug policy, may extend the program beyond April 25, while Senate President Pro Tem David Long and House Public Health Committee Chair Ed Clere support broader legislation that would allow 23 high‑HCV counties to establish similar programs; the bill passed the House on April 7 but faces a hearing before the legislature adjourns on April 29. Funding remains a concern, as the federal government has barred public money for such programs and Pence’s order did not include funding, raising questions about the program’s long‑term sustainability.

An obsessive Arsenal fan tested his girlfriend Saskia with a 50‑point exam on the club, scoring her 43.5/50 (87 %) and promising not to dump her; she posted the results on Twitter, prompting praise and criticism from other fans, while the boyfriend’s feedback highlighted specific weak spots (e.g., Q17, player positions, Tottenham remarks) and he marked correct answers in capitals with an angry face for mistakes. The test included multiple‑choice, table‑completion, and essay questions about Arsenal facts, and Saskia’s creative answers earned her double marks on some items, ultimately earning her an “A” and keeping the relationship intact. The story attracted mixed reactions online, with some users lauding the boyfriend as a legend and others joking that he had taken things too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66‑year‑old former Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, spent 27 years as a DEA informant in the United States, providing key information that helped bring down drug lord Carlos Lehder and ex‑Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega; despite never being paid, he was promised U.S. citizenship, which has not materialized, leaving him technically living illegally after his retirement and health decline, and now facing deportation; he fears death if returned to Colombia, has been denied citizenship assistance by the DEA after going public, cannot collect Social Security benefits without proper documentation, and has received a $5,000 payment from a former colleague after the agency refused to help, while his temporary visa expired on January 1 and he is in limbo, considering going into hiding.

A 14‑year‑old girl from Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, was allegedly gang‑raped by five men and later set herself on fire with kerosene, sustaining 70 % burns and now fighting for her life in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital; the accused have been arrested. The incident has come amid heightened scrutiny of sexual assault in India, following the ban on a documentary about the rape‑murder of student Jyoti Singh and widespread protests over similar violent cases, including brutal attacks in Nagaland that have sparked public outrage and calls for stronger protection for women.

Louis van Gaal, Manchester United’s manager, has said he dreams of beating Manchester City in the Old Trafford derby but will have to do so without Robin van Persie, who is still not fit after ankle trouble, and also without Luke Shaw for the same reason. He praised the squad’s overall fitness but stressed that match fitness is different, and highlighted the importance of the game for a chance to finish second or third in the league and avoid a Champions League qualifying tie.
