Van Gaal urged his players to dream of victory, noted the recent City win at Crystal Palace, and emphasized learning from the 1‑0 loss at City earlier in the season, while also expressing appreciation for the United fans’ support.

Arsenal and Liverpool supporters staged a protest at the Emirates Stadium during a lunchtime Premier League match, leaving seats empty for the first ten minutes to draw attention to the high cost of tickets—starting at £64 for a sold‑out game—amid the league’s £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans from both clubs displayed banners inside and outside the 60,000‑capacity ground, including a message reading “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket,” and a banner outside reading “football without fans is nothing.” Kelvin Meadows of Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Roy Bentham of Spirit of Shankly condemned the prices as “extortionate” and urged tangible reductions aligned with working‑class wages, noting that old rivalries were being set aside as supporters united to demand change and that further protests were expected after the match.

A newborn named Star Reader in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed with biliary atresia—a life‑threatening blockage of the bile ducts—after persistent jaundice prompted liver tests. An initial Kasai procedure failed, and with neither parent a suitable donor, her mother’s twin sister Shanell offered a partial liver transplant. Shanell donated part of her liver, and after a November operation and six weeks in hospital, Star recovered and returned home, now requiring regular blood and liver function tests and lifelong anti‑rejection medication. The family, especially Jade Reader, expressed deep gratitude for Shanell’s self‑less donation, which saved Star’s life.

Chelsea’s players, including 17‑goal‑man Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake, took part in Audi’s football challenge against teammates Loic Remy and Willian. In the first round Hazard and Ake won 5‑3 by firing balls into a car boot from close range. The second round had them shoot from long range into a convertible Audi, again winning 6‑0. In the final round, where most points were contested, Remy and Willian emerged victorious, but Willian’s long‑range effort smashed a wing mirror on an Audi, a mishap shown in a clip at the end of the video.

Former New Hampshire Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, caused a December 7, 2013 highway crash that killed Vermont couple Amanda Murphy (24, eight‑month pregnant) and Jason Timmons (29) and their unborn child; he drove his pickup across a median at over 100 mph, plowing into their SUV and shearing its top. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus’s death, faces 12–24 years in prison, and is also subject to a wrongful‑death lawsuit. He has cited ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis as factors, but during sentencing he denied being suicidal. His wife, Deborah, described him as a man of ethics and integrity, while his attorneys highlighted his high‑level roles at PPG, Sprint, Delphi and GE and a severance package exceeding $1 million. The crash was initially charged as reckless manslaughter, later upgraded to negligent homicide.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second‑degree murder for poisoning her five‑year‑old son, Garnett‑Paul Spears, with salt while he was hospitalized in New York. She received a 20‑year‑to‑life sentence, below the maximum 25 years to life that prosecutors sought, after a judge noted her mental illness and the crime’s cruelty. Spears’ ex‑husband, Chris Hill, publicly attacked her on Facebook, demanding she be placed in the general population and wishing her death in prison, while also calling her “crazy” and “unemotional” at sentencing. Prosecutors argued Spears abused her son’s medical conditions to gain attention and loaded his feeding tube with lethal salt, whereas Spears’ lawyer claimed innocence, blamed hospital negligence, and plans to appeal. Spears had been held at Westchester County Jail while awaiting sentencing and did not testify at trial.

Australia will receive an updated influenza vaccine that now includes protection against the H3N2 and B/Phuket strains, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter; the vaccine stocks arrived a month later than expected, but experts say the modified formulation is worth the wait. From April 20, free, government‑funded shots will be available to high‑risk groups such as the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, while Dr. Alan Hampson urges everyone to get vaccinated, noting that the new vaccine also covers H1N1 and should better match the circulating strains, helping to prevent further deaths and protect vulnerable people in families.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield, Illinois, are defending the historic site against a harsh National Geographic review that called its interior “all the historical character of an office lobby” while Illinois faces a financial crisis that threatens the state historic preservation agency; Gov. Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the agency and consolidating it into another department, and a $1.1 million cut last year has reduced the tomb’s hours and staff, prompting concerns from the Lincoln Monument Association and the agency’s spokesperson that further cuts could jeopardize the site’s management. Despite the criticism, the agency reports that the tomb and its receiving vault have received more than $2.5 million in recent repairs—including interior plaster, paint, bronze and marble renovations, lighting upgrades, waterproofing, and landscaping—leaving the structure in “excellent physical condition”; the tomb, designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead, was dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, reconstructed in 1899 and 1930, and today features a circular structure topped with an obelisk, black and tan marble interior, bronze trim, and a family burial chamber beneath an inscription, with visitors noting its beauty despite the National Geographic critique.

The passage reviews the revival of 1990s and early‑2000s fashion staples—wide‑leg rave jeans, bucket hats, camouflage prints, double denim, UGG boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture velour tracksuits, coloured sunglasses, corsets, and harem trousers—highlighting how each trend once dominated pop culture and is now resurfacing with contemporary celebrities. It cites Rihanna, Beyoncé, Kylie Jenner, Paris Hilton, Kristen Bell, Miley Cyrus, Nicki Minaj, Selena Gomez, Kim Kardashian, and Elle Macpherson as modern adopters, noting the shift from impractical or nostalgic styles to current runway and street‑style reinterpretations.

Rainbows lit up the New York sky after heavy rain, captured by fashion‑CEO Amanda Curtis; in rural China, the use of exotic dancers at wakes is being banned as part of a vice crackdown; RDJ grew frustrated when a Channel 4 interviewer probed his private life; the Kardashians sparked a new lip‑plumping trend with a #kyliejennerchallenge hashtag; 102‑year‑old Alice Barker, with filmmakers, revisited the past; a controversial prom‑posal referencing bombs drew criticism for alleged racism; Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumière in a new “Beauty and the Beast”; Johnny Depp’s “Black Mass” trailer shows him in a dramatically altered look; a pregnancy announcement referenced “The Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air”; and a military dad photobombed his son, earning praise for originality.

The Miami Open has turned into a cake‑filled celebration as Serena Williams reached her 700th career victory, prompting a giant cake presentation, while Andy Murray also received a cake after his 500th win. Williams beat Sabine Lisicki 7‑6, 1‑6, 6‑3 to reach the semi‑finals, but her hopes of a sister showdown were dashed when Venus lost to Carla Suárez Navarro. The world No. 1, who gave away the second set before securing revenge for her 2013 Wimbledon shock loss to Lisicki, will now face Simona Halep in the semi‑finals, who had defeated Sloane Stephens 6‑1, 7‑5. The passage also notes Williams’ backhand play in the quarter‑final, her handshake with Lisicki, and Halep’s celebration after beating Stephens.

Mangu Ram, an 82‑year‑old Hindu healer who fled Punjab in 1947, now lives in a slum on the outskirts of Jammu and has spent seven decades denied citizenship rights, a fate shared by roughly 100,000 West Pakistan refugees (WPRs) in Jammu and Kashmir. Because state law only grants citizenship to those born in undivided Kashmir, WPRs cannot own property, vote in state elections, or access state‑run training colleges and jobs, leaving three generations in poverty despite the state’s relative prosperity. The BJP’s recent electoral gains and its pledge to normalise WPR status have sparked hope, but activists such as Labha Ram Gandhi warn that if rights are still denied the community may resort to violence. The situation reflects a broader tension between the region’s Muslim majority and the Hindu minority refugees, whose lack of legal status keeps them second‑class citizens.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is still weighing a potential summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, after the club’s president Naoki Ogane confirmed a roughly £4 million offer and Chelsea’s interest in loaning him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season. Muto, who scored the winner against Shonan Bellmare, said he wants to “think carefully” and choose a club where he can play regularly and develop, while Chelsea manager José Mourinho acknowledged the player’s potential but stressed the club’s focus on financial fairness and winning matches. FC Tokyo’s former coach Ranko Popović praised Muto’s intelligence, speed, confidence and unique qualities, noting he could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge.

Australia’s recent decision to select overseas‑based players for the World Cup is praised as a modern, merit‑based approach that contrasts sharply with England’s stubborn policy of excluding players who play abroad, a stance defended by coach Stuart Lancaster. The article cites examples such as Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell at Toulon, Steffon Armitage’s rise in France, Nick Abendanon’s improvement after moving to France, and Jonny Wilkinson’s enhanced performance overseas, arguing that these players should be chosen regardless of club location. It claims that England’s refusal to pick such talent undermines the team’s chances, diminishes player confidence, and is unfair to players who thrive abroad. The piece urges the RFU and Premier Rugby to lift restrictions, emphasizes that the World Cup should feature the world’s best players, and concludes by applauding Australia’s inclusive selection while noting that the Springboks still pick Bryan Habana from Toulon.

Firechat, which has been downloaded more than five million times, uses Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (and a similar Android Bluetooth feature) to create local wireless mesh networks that let users send messages, photos and files without an internet or cellular connection, typically within about 30 feet (9 m) and with a maximum hop distance of roughly 200 feet (61 m). The app offers “everyone” and “nearby” chatrooms, sends data securely and anonymously, and is useful in places with no signal such as planes or subways. To extend the limited range of these mesh networks, Open Garden has developed Greenstone, an egg‑shaped beacon that acts as a booster for Firechat, holding up to 1,000 recent messages, lasting about a year on a single battery, and passing messages between Firechat nodes when they come within about 20 feet (6 m). Greenstone is still in development, works only with Firechat, and is intended for resilient communication in communities, hospitals, festivals, protests, and other situations where connectivity may be sparse or overloaded.

Lillian Bustle, a 5'3" burlesque performer from New Jersey who weighs 240 lb, gave a TED talk in which she argues that “fat” should be seen as a neutral, honest self‑descriptor rather than an insult, and that body‑positive language can counter the 66 % rise in workplace size discrimination and the early‑onset desire among girls to be thinner. She cites studies showing that exposure to diverse body types increases acceptance and even preference, and she uses her own burlesque career—started in 2012—to demonstrate how performing in a glamorous, fat body can shift audiences’ perceptions. Bustle encourages people to recall past moments of courage to combat insecurity, and her talk, posted on YouTube three weeks ago, has garnered nearly 38,000 views, mostly positive feedback and personal thank‑you messages, with only a few negative comments. She also references fellow performer Beelzebabe and stresses that body diversity challenges society’s narrow beauty standards.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger who has spent most of the season on the bench, was photographed on a different kind of bench for a Lanvin photoshoot alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Özil, and runway model Olga Sherer, with the club’s official tailor since 2013. The 26‑year‑old appeared on the bench during Arsenal’s 0‑0 draw with Chelsea at the Emirates Stadium and was named on the substitutes’ list for 17 of the club’s 33 Premier League matches, coming on for the final six minutes of that game. He is hoping to make his first start since the 3‑0 win over West Ham on March 14, as Arsenal prepare to face Aston Villa in the FA Cup final at Wembley on May 30.

Fans of blockbuster films such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas can bid on a 417‑item collection of props and puppets created by legendary makeup artist Rick Baker, with the auction taking place at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online on PropStore.com on May 29; the set, worth an estimated $746,100, includes high‑value pieces like the Alien Edgar Bug ($40,000), Mikey costume ($30,000), and Worm Guy ($10,000), as well as lower‑priced items such as the Two‑Face mask ($1,500), Grinch costume ($8,000), and Frozen Thug statue ($4,000), and spans more than 50 productions—including An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, Mighty Joe Young, Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker, and the Thriller music video—while Prop Store’s Brandon Alinger highlights the event as a no‑reserve live auction offering collectors a chance to own a piece of Hollywood history.

Seven‑year‑old Carwyn Scott‑Howell of Talybont-on‑Usk, Wales, died after becoming separated from his mother and sister while skiing in the French Alps; he entered dense woodland, fell from a 164‑foot drop, and was found by police following his footprints, which ended in sliding marks. The family described him as a daring, outgoing, competent skier who loved the mountains and farm work, and said his death has left a “vast void” in their hearts. Carwyn had been on a holiday at the Flaine resort, where he had been enjoying a run with his family before the tragedy, and his mother, Ceri, 44, searched desperately for him. Friends, schoolmates, and the local community in Brecon have expressed deep grief, with his school teacher calling him a lively, likable pupil and a county councillor noting the community’s support for the family. The boy’s body is ready for repatriation, but the family remains in the Alps.

Laura Scurr, a 15‑year‑old from Whitley Bay, suffered a severe anorexia that began when she was nearly 13 stone and felt pressured to be a “size zero”; she hid food, lied to her mother, and ate only a piece of fruit a day, eventually collapsing from starvation and spending a week on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital before receiving support from eating‑disorder organisations and CAMHS. She has since recovered, spoken publicly about the bullying and societal pressures that drove her to extreme dieting, and now participates in the Miss Teen GB competition, which promotes confidence and rejects size‑zero stereotypes. Her mother, Sue, described the shock of seeing her daughter’s health deteriorate and the realization of the broader pressures on young girls, while the passage also outlines general facts about anorexia, its prevalence in the UK, and resources for help.

Liverpool unveiled its 2015/16 home kit at Anfield, the first design from New Balance after a record‑breaking £300 million four‑year deal that replaced Warrior. The gingham strip, bearing the “Hold Nothing Back” slogan, the memorial flame and number 96, features all‑white New Balance, Liverbird and Standard Chartered logos and a new collar. Players – Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, Simon Mignolet, Philippe Coutinho, Adam Lallana and Jordan Henderson – presented the kit to fans, with legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush in attendance. Sterling, who rejected a £100 k‑a‑week offer and was linked to Arsenal, was urged by supporters to stay, and Liverpool’s management reiterated that he will remain for the season. The launch coincided with talks of the FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa and the club’s ongoing campaign.

The University of Manchester team, led by Dr Sarah Bridle, has released the largest high‑definition map of dark matter to date, covering roughly 0.4 % of the sky (about 150 times the area of the full moon) and showing red regions of higher dark‑matter density and blue regions of lower density. The map, produced from 130 million galaxy images taken with the Dark Energy Camera on the 4‑metre Victor M. Blanco telescope at Cerro Tololo, uses precise measurements of galaxy shapes to trace gravitational lensing and reveal the clumpy distribution of dark matter, filaments, and voids that influence galaxy formation. It is the first in a series of maps that will ultimately cover 12.5 % of the sky over five years, creating a 3‑D view of dark matter and dark energy and allowing astronomers to test cosmological theories and probe the nature of dark energy. The survey, now in its second year and slated for completion in 2018, required supercomputing resources to process the data and was unveiled at the American Physical Society meeting in Baltimore.

Manchester United have officially approached 21‑year‑old Memphis Depay, the PSV Eindhoven star who has scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie matches and helped the club win its first Dutch title in seven years, with manager Louis van Gaal eager to sign him as one of his first summer acquisitions. Depay, a former Netherlands international who earned his first cap under van Gaal in 2013 and was part of the 2014 World Cup squad, has attracted interest from Tottenham, Paris‑Saint‑Germain and other top European clubs, but PSV has rebuffed offers and is now negotiating larger sums. The winger, who began his career at VV Moordrecht and Sparta Rotterdam before joining PSV at 12, is praised for his pace, dribbling, powerful right foot and potential to rival stars like Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo, though he remains a young talent still learning the game.

Chelsea secured a 3‑1 win over Manchester City’s youth side at the Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham opening the scoring and adding a second volley, while Dominic Solanke netted a late third to seal the victory. City’s youngsters, including Kean Bryan, Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts, and Brandon Barker, had moments of promise but were largely contained by Chelsea’s midfield and defensive pairings, notably Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke‑Salter. The match highlighted Chelsea’s attacking flair and City’s need for more cohesion, with key performances from Abraham, Solanke, and the defensive duo of Tomori and Clarke‑Salter.

Marco Rubio, the Florida senator running for president, said people are born with a sexual preference and that same‑sex marriage is not a constitutional right, insisting that the definition of marriage should be decided by state legislatures rather than courts. He stated he is not opposed to gay marriage but believes it should be between one man and one woman, and that he would attend a same‑sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares about even if he disagrees with the decision. As a Catholic, he views divorce as wrong but would still love someone who is divorced. Rubio’s campaign has already attracted more than $51 million in donor commitments amid a crowded Republican primary field.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, a Spanish‑Latvian couple who met in Riga in 2011, have been cycling around the world for almost a year, covering nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days and passing through 16 countries. After quitting restaurant jobs in Manchester, they travel on a shoestring budget of under three euros a day, spending about 2.74 euros on food and relying on free accommodation, camping, Couchsurfing, and Warmshowers for lodging. They have camped 161 nights, used Couchsurfing 66 nights, and Warmshowers 44 nights, and occasionally receive meals from locals or dumpster‑dive for food. Their route began in London, went through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, and they plan to continue into Asia and eventually cycle across the American continent.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 sued James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, after a photo‑booth at their wedding printed the racist caption “poor n ***** party” on some pictures; the bride’s sister only learned of the incident months later. Attorney Cathy Hale represents the couple, who claim Evans failed to apologize and told them to sue, and they are pursuing a claim under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract, seeking an apology rather than monetary damages. Evans denies the allegations, says there is no evidence linking the company to the offensive caption, and claims the couple showed no mental anguish. Mediation is set for tomorrow, with a trial scheduled for July if no settlement is reached.

Mike Brown, the England full‑back for Harlequins, has suffered a recent concussion after the France match and has adopted a cautious recovery plan, refusing to rush back and acknowledging the risk of extended absence like that of Johnny Sexton or Geoff Parling; he withdrew from the Ireland game at the end of February and is monitoring symptoms through staged tests, citing increased awareness from World Rugby online modules. Meanwhile, Northampton wing George North has been advised by leading medics not to play again this season after four rapid concussions, and Ireland’s Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks earlier in the term. Brown’s experience underscores the importance of recognising concussion symptoms and prioritising player safety.

Smartphone use and the blurring of work‑home boundaries are blamed for a decline in couples’ sex frequency in Britain, according to Cambridge statistician David Spiegelhalter in his book *Sex by Numbers*. He reports that the average heterosexual couple now has sex about three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990, and cites factors such as more people living alone and constant connectivity that erode private time. Spiegelhalter echoes research by Catherine Mercer of the British National Survey, who notes that competing demands and late‑night work emails push sex lower on people’s priority lists.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized status symbols that could fetch up to £1.2 million, are now falling out of favor in China, with many being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hot‑pot meat and leather. The decline is linked to the government’s anti‑corruption crackdown, which has stopped wealthy businessmen from gifting the dogs to officials, and to bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in major cities such as Beijing, Shanghai, Zhengzhou and Tianjin. Animal‑welfare workers rescued 20 mastiffs in cramped cages en route to a slaughterhouse, finding a third already dead, no food or water for three days, and several with broken bones, a fate feared for hundreds more. Gangs and unscrupulous breeders are also offloading poor‑quality, cross‑bred dogs, while urbanization has made the large, 80‑kg, traditionally herding breed less suitable for city life. The breed’s boom began in 2005, but the market collapse has left a glut of unsellable dogs and a sharp drop in demand.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half reporting first incidents before age 18; the harassment ranged from insults, whistling and unwanted flirting to sexual assault and rape, and six in ten women feared being attacked, leading to altered routes, schedules and clothing and effectively excluding them from the public arena. The report, presented to the French women’s rights ministry, highlighted the invisibility of many unreported attacks and called for a campaign to curb sexist or threatening behaviour on buses and trains, while leaders such as Pascale Boisard and Ernestine Ronai urged that women be educated that such conduct is not normal, that aggressors and witnesses be addressed, and reminded that sexual assault carries a five‑year prison term and a €75,005 fine.

Direct Line’s #everydayfix competition invited design teams to create prototypes for common daily emergencies identified in a 2,000‑person survey, where the top problems were lack of sleep, lost keys, traffic delays, lost documents, parking, printer failures, phone battery, toilet paper, customer service, and forgotten bank cards. Three shortlisted solutions—Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to ensure sleep; Forget Me Lock, a key‑mounted indicator that shows whether a door is locked; and Nipper, a tiny mobile charger powered by any household battery—were showcased, and participants can vote for their favourite on Twitter using the hashtag, with the winner slated for a Kickstarter launch. Other proposed ideas that did not make the final cut included a bone‑conduction helmet for cyclists, a parking‑space alert pin, and an app that forwards messages when a phone dies.

Vera Baird, the Northumbria Police and Crime Commissioner, is under a Ministry of Justice investigation after she allocated more than £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs, with Chief Constable Sue Sim—who sits on the charity’s top table—also involved. The funding, authorised after the Home Secretary allowed PCCs to commission victim‑support services, has been criticised as a conflict of interest and “inappropriate,” with Labour’s Keith Vaz calling it a “soap opera” and arguing that PCCs should not use public funds for organisations in which they have a stake. Baird insists all MOJ procedures were followed, while Sim has announced her retirement in June amid past bullying allegations and a broader concern that the charity’s partial run by a former bullying‑accused chief constable may deter victims from seeking help. The MOJ will investigate whether conflict‑of‑interest rules were breached.

Three men and a woman were convicted for a brutal assault on 53‑year‑old Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive images in a basement on Brighton Ave in Philadelphia’s Mayfair neighborhood; the attackers—Corry “Corey” Campbell (21), his girlfriend Sandra Ng (19), and friend Carl Halin (18)—were sentenced to 20 years, 23 months, and 20 years respectively, while David Thomas (28) awaits sentencing and Jennifer Pratt (40) awaits trial; the incident, lasting about 42 hours, was filmed, involved the use of a tattoo gun, needles, ink, marijuana, prescription drugs, and resulted in Valecce suffering multiple broken bones, severe injuries, and lasting psychological trauma.

Manchester United have officially approached 21‑year‑old Memphis Depay, the prolific PSV Eindhoven winger who has scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie matches and helped the club win its 22nd title, with manager Louis van Gaal eager to sign him as one of his first arrivals; Tottenham had previously turned down a £15 million bid, but United, Paris‑Saint‑Germain and another major club are now in the running with larger offers. Depay, who began his career at VV Moordrecht and Sparta Rotterdam before joining PSV at 12, is known for his pace, close control, dribbling, powerful right‑foot shooting and ability to cut inside from the left wing, though he can still make poor passes or hold the ball too long. He earned his first Dutch cap in 2013, was part of the 2014 World Cup squad that finished third, scored the winning goal against Australia, and was nominated for the tournament’s best young player award. Van Gaal, who used Depay in the 2014 World Cup, and former Dutch star Phillip Cocu have praised his potential to rival players like Arjen Robben and even Cristiano Ronaldo at a young age.

Chelsea secured a 3‑1 victory over Manchester City’s youth side at the Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham opening the scoring and adding a second volley to give Chelsea a first‑half lead, while Dominic Solanke sealed the win with a late goal. City’s attack, featuring players such as Kean Bryan, Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts, and Brandon Barker, struggled to break through a solid Chelsea defense that included Christian Haug, Fikayo Tomori, and Jake Clarke‑Salter. Despite a few promising chances, City failed to level the score, and Chelsea’s commanding performance was highlighted by Abraham’s two goals and Solanke’s decisive finish.

Marco Rubio, the Florida senator running for president, said on CBS’s “Face the Nation” that people are born with a sexual preference and that same‑sex marriage is not a constitutional right, arguing that states should decide the definition of marriage through their legislatures rather than courts. He added he would attend a same‑sex wedding of a family member or staffer even if he disagreed with the decision, emphasizing respect for loved ones’ choices. Rubio also noted his Catholic view that divorce is wrong but that he would still love someone who is divorced. He has received significant donor support, exceeding $47 million, as he enters a crowded Republican primary field.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian cyclist Ilze Zebolde (31) left restaurant jobs in Manchester and are now cycling around the world on a shoestring budget, covering almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days across 16 countries, from London through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia‑Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the Americas. They carry about 130 kg of gear, rely on free accommodation (161 nights pitched, 66 nights on Couchsurfing, 44 on Warmshowers), and spend less than €3 per day—about €2.74 on food, which they supplement with free meals, dumpster‑diving, and wild fruit. Their blog, thecrazytravel, documents their journey, and they describe their adventure as a dream of discovery without a set agenda, aiming to stay on the road for the coming years.

Mike Brown, the England full‑back for Harlequins, has suffered a series of concussions—including a knockout in February’s England‑Italy match and a headache after the France game—and has adopted a cautious recovery plan, refusing to rush back and acknowledging that increased awareness from World Rugby’s online modules helped him decide to pull out of the Ireland game and avoid a prolonged absence like that of Johnny Sexton or Geoff Parling. He remains unsure when he can return but is determined not to risk further injury, urging teammates to heed symptoms. Meanwhile, Northampton wing George North has been advised by leading medics not to play again this season after four rapid concussions, and Ireland’s Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks earlier in the term.

Smartphone use and the internet’s rise are blamed for a decline in couples’ sex frequency in Britain, according to Cambridge statistician David Spiegelhalter’s book *Sex by Numbers*. He reports that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex about three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes the drop to people living alone and, more realistically, to the erosion of boundaries between work, home and social life, which leaves less quiet time for intimacy. He cites researcher Catherine Mercer, who notes that competing demands and late‑night work emails push sex lower on people’s priority lists.

Once prized status symbols, Tibetan mastiffs—large dogs that can weigh up to 80 kg and were once sold for as much as £1.2 million—have fallen from favor in China, with anti‑corruption crackdowns and city bans on dogs over 50 kg driving demand down. The resulting glut has led to many dogs being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hot‑pot meat and leather, a fate revealed when animal‑welfare workers rescued 20 dogs in cramped cages, some dead or injured, and reports suggest hundreds more are similarly doomed. Breeders, pressured by profit, have cross‑bred the breed, degrading its quality, while gangs steal stray dogs for sale to abattoirs. The decline follows a boom that began in 2005, when the breed was seen as a luxury status symbol, and urbanisation has made them ill‑suited to city life.

Direct Line’s #everydayfix competition invited design teams to create prototypes for common daily emergencies identified in a 2,000‑person survey, where the top problems were lack of sleep, lost keys, traffic delays, lost documents, parking, printer failures, phone battery, toilet roll, customer service, and forgotten bank cards. Three shortlisted solutions—Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to improve sleep; Forget Me Lock, a key‑attached device that turns green or red to show whether a door is open or locked; and Nipper, a tiny mobile charger powered by any household battery—were showcased, and the public can vote for their favourite on Twitter; the winning design will be funded via Kickstarter. Other proposed ideas that did not make the final cut included a bone‑conduction helmet for cyclists, a parking‑space alert pin, and an app that forwards messages when a phone dies.
